DOC.HEAD: Station Airs Half-Hour of Silence to Promote Reading
DOC.TEXT: A television station broadcast a half-hour of silence to encourage families to read. Viewers who tuned to WLWT at 7 p.m. Friday for the syndicated program ``Inside Edition'' instead saw the message, ``Please take this time to read.'' There was no sound. The program was called ``Read Every Day System,'' or REDS, and preceded the telecast of a baseball game between the Cincinnati Reds and the Montreal Expos. It was part of an educational project by the station that has included half-hour prime-time specials and public service announcements on education, station manager Cliff Abromatz said. He said the station plans similar telecasts in the future. ``They probably won't be half-hours, but they will be projects designed to get children to read,'' Abromatz said. He declined to say how much the station lost by not selling advertising during the half-hour, which is one of its most profitable time periods.

DOC.HEAD: Harvard Honors Colombian Journalists for Coverage of Drug Trade
DOC.TEXT: Colombian journalists who have risked their lives to cover the drug trade are being honored by Harvard University's Nieman Foundation. The 1990 Louis M. Lyons Award for Conscience and Integrity in Journalism has been awarded to Colombian reporters, both living and dead, who have covered the drug industry and its effect on that country, the foundation announced Friday. Luis Gabriel Cano, 67, president of El Espectador, a Bogota newspaper, will accept the award this fall. El Espectador has lost many of its staff to death or exile and had its newsroom bombed by narco-terrorists last September. The Committee to Protect Journalists, a New York-based human rights group, has documented the killing of 20 reporters and editors in Colombia by agents of drug lords in the last five years. However, Cano and other Colombian journalists estimate that 50 news organization employees, including business employees, have been killed, the foundation said. Among those murdered was Cano's brother, Guillermo Cano, El Espectador editor-in-chief and a columnist. ``Mr. Cano has lost his brother and several of his associates to the narco-mafia assassins, and recently suffered a major bombing to the paper's installations which caused $2.5 million in damages, seriously jeopardizing the paper,'' T. Roberto Eisenmann Jr., editor of La Prensa in Panama and a former Nieman fellow, wrote in nominating Cano for the award. ``Yet Cano struggled on, realizing that if his newspaper fails in its efforts, his country's institutions might crumble, giving way to narco-mafia dominance. His courage is especially inspiring for our profession.'' A committee of the 21 members of the Nieman Fellow Class of 1990 chose the Colombians for the award, which is named in honor of former Nieman curator Louis M. Lyons. The award carried an honorarium of $1,000. Cano will travel to Cambridge to accept the award on behalf of his Colombian colleagues.

DOC.HEAD: Home After 20 Reach Mount Everest Summit
DOC.TEXT: U.S. members of the Mount Everest International Peace Climb returned home Friday after placing 20 climbers on the summit of the world's highest peak. Expedition leader Jim Whittaker said placing American, Soviet and Chinese mountaineers side by side on the summit was a model for the superpowers to emulate. ``We have a bond that will never stop,'' said Whittaker, who in 1963 became the first American to reach the top of Everest. ``My proudest moment was when we put the first group on the summit. To have that vision become a reality was a wonderful moment.'' The first of the 20 climbers reached the 29,028-foot summit on May 7, and were followed by the others over the next few days. Tibetans who assisted in the climb also reached the summit. Previously, the record number of climbers to reach the top of Everest with a single expedition was 17. The climbers said they collected about two tons of garbage while on the mountain from previous expeditions as well as their own. Some was buried, some was burned and some was carried off the mountain to be recycled in China, said Dan Branley, a spokesman for the climb. The expedition, which began in February, cost more than $1 million. It was being paid for by U.S. corporate sponsors, including the L.L. Bean camping gear company of Freeport, Maine.

DOC.HEAD: Injured Earth First! Activists Arrested in Bomb Blast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Judi Bari ...,' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with comment by Cherney, Bari's attorney; picks up 5th graf pvs, `The two ...' INSERTS 1 graf after 12th graf, `Some in ...,' to UPDATE with Friday night gathering at police headquarters; picks up 13th graf pvs, `Sims said ...' Earth First! is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Two activists for a radical environmental group were arrested Friday in connection with a bomb blast that ripped their car apart, but the duo and their supporters painted them as victims, not criminals. ``The evidence is strong they were transporting this device and that's why they were arrested,'' said Oakland Police Lt. Mike Sims at a Friday news conference. ``Based on our determination of the placement of the device in the car, we believe they should have known it was there. We believe it went off accidently.'' But in an interview from his jail cell, Darryl Cherney, who was arrested along with Judi Bari, hotly denied carrying any explosive devices and insisted that police investigate who was trying to kill the pair. `` ... We are demanding ... that the Oakland Police Department and the FBI seek out this assassin and bring whoever it is to justice immediately,'' said Cherney, 33, describing himself and Bari as victims. Bari's attorney, Susan Jordan, said her client also denied any involvement with explosives during a meeting at Bari's hospital bedsise. Bari, 40, required surgery at Highland Hospital for a fractured pelvis and suffered other injuries, and was in listed stable condition Friday. Cherney, who suffered minor injuries including a head cut, was treated and released Thursday night. The two Earth First! supporters were being held for investigation of possession and transportation of explosives. Cherney was booked into city jail, and Bari was under guard at the hospital. Jordan said that it's ``inconceiveable that they would destroy their movement by doing that. It's always easy to charge somebody who's unpopular.'' Jordan added: ``If you had a bomb, wouldn't you be careful enough not to place it where it could injure you?'' The bomb exploded on an Oakland street just before noon Thursday as Bari and Cherney were driving to a rally at the University of California-Santa Cruz. The blast blew out the windows and the rear driver's side door of Bari's station wagon. Other doors were blown open and the roof was bowed upward. ``I don't believe it,'' said Mark Huntington, a friend of the pair and an Earth First! supporter. ``If the police produced evidence and put it on TV, I still wouldn't believe it. I think they planted it. ... The FBI has a lot of reasons to get rid of Darryl and Judi.'' About 30 supporters of Earth First! on Friday maintained a vigil outside Police Department headquarters in downtown Oakland, vowing not to leave until Cherney and Bari were freed. Some in the crowd played guitars and held signs reading ``Stop Blaming the Victim,'' ``Trees Not Bombs'' and ``The FBI Did It''. As many as 200 supporters gathered outside the police station Friday night, wearing Earth First! t-shirts and singing folk songs. Sims said authorities served three search warrants and found evidence in several places that led to the arrests. Thursday night, police searched Cherney's van and a Berkeley house occupied by several members of another environmentalist group, Seeds of Peace. Bari and Cherney had visited the house Wednesday night, and Cherney's van was parked outside. The pair, described by friends as dedicated pacifists, were key figures in planning ``Mississippi Summer in the California Redwoods,'' an environmentalist effort to halt what they describe as excessive logging of old-growth timber in northern California. Both were in the San Francisco Bay area to drum up support for the summerlong campaign. The effort, patterned after the ``Mississippi Summer'' civil rights protests that drew thousands of college students to the South in 1964, has heightened tensions along the northern California coast, where environmentalists and the logging industry have long been at odds. Although Bari and Cherney's supporters said the two activists are committed to non-violent change, Earth First! has become known for tactics that include sabotage and vandalism, including ``tree spiking'' _ driving spikes into soon-to-be-harvested trees to damage logging equipment. Daniel Barron, an Earth First! organizer from San Francisco, said about a dozen people have received anonymous death threats such as one that was signed ``Committee for the Death of Earth First!'' One threat included a picture of Bari with the cross hairs of a rifle sight drawn across her face, said Betty Ball of the Mendocino Environmental Center. But environmentalists have not been the only targets. At Louisiana-Pacific Lumber Co., spokesman Shepard Tucker said a pipe bomb exploded two weeks ago at a mill in Cloverdale. An investigation into that incident is continuing, said the Sonoma County sheriff's department.

DOC.HEAD: US May Deny Romania Trade Benefits Because of Election Abuses
DOC.TEXT: The State Department is raising the possibility that Romania may be denied U.S. trade benefits because of electoral irregularities both during the campaign and on election day. Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said the issue of granting Romania most favored nation trade status is under review as a result of the alleged abuses. That status would entitle Romania to have the lowest possible tariff rates for its U.S. exports. The late President Nicolae Ceausescu renounced the trade benefits two years ago because of insistent U.S. demands for the protection of human rights as the price for continuation of these privileges. According to some estimates, Ceausescu's action cost Romania $250 million yearly in U.S. exports. Romania receives no U.S. economic assistance, but an $80 million food aid program was began earlier this year. Official returns from last Sunday's election showed that acting President Ion Iliescu won 85 percent of the vote and that candidates from his National Salvation Front won almost 68 percent in the balloting for the bicameral legislature. The Front has been in charge of Romania since the communist regime was ousted last December. Its candidates consist mostly of former communists who had a falling out with Ceausescu. Ms. Tutwiler said ``serious distortions'' during the campaign included ``organized acts of intimidation and violence directed primarily against the opposition candidates and their sympathizers.'' In addition, she said, the Front had virtually unrestricted use of government resources for campaign purposes. Opposition parties, meanwhile, did not have equitable access to public television and were prevented from having reliable delivery of their campaign literature. As for election day irregularities, Ms. Tutwiler said there were instances of ``inadequate physical control over ballot boxes, inappropriate `assistance' to some voters inside the voting booth, and questions over the status of certain printed ballots and voter identity cards.'' She accused the Romanian government of failing to take ``sufficiently vigorous steps'' to remedy the distortions or to discourage acts of intimidation and violence. On the other hand, she said that the overwhelming number of Romanians were able to cast their ballots without visible coercion. ``We lack substantiating evidence that these voting day irregularities were of sufficient weight to have altered the outcome of the elections,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: New Group To Oppose Spread Of Bigger Trucks
DOC.TEXT: Huge trucks, with double or triple trailers, could make driving more dangerous if allowed to spread to more of America's highways, a new private group says. ``We have good cause to be afraid of these rigs,'' Gerald Donaldson, a board member of Citizens for Reliable and Safe Highways, said Friday. ``What the trucking industry wants is ever-increasing size of trucks and ever-increasing weight of trucks.'' Leaders of the group, abbreviated as CRASH, announced its founding at an outdoor news conference, with a 100-foot triple-trailer truck placed in front of the Capitol dome as a backdrop. The American Trucking Association, in a statement, said it is not now seeking federal legislation to allow more widespread use of very long trucks, with triple trailers or two 48-foot trailers. They currently are restricted to certain highways in 13 Western states. The association said CRASH was making ``an attempt to cloak the rational discussion of trucking productivity in manufactured safety hysteria.'' It said CRASH was ``inspired and funded, at least indirectly'' by the railroads, which it said were trying ``to prevent increases in trucking productivity and to enact unfair, burdensome truck taxes.'' Paul Loveday, vice president of Itel Corp., which owns and leases railroad boxcars, told the CRASH news conference that his company gave $150,000 to get the organization started. Other directors include former California Gov. Edmund G. ``Pat'' Brown, former Transportation Secretary John Volpe and Joan Claybrook, former administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. ``If you look down the list of our board of directors, I don't think you'll see anyone on that list who's a tool of industry,'' Loveday said. A statement distributed by CRASH said studies found double- and triple-trailer trucks were more likely to be involved in crashes. The trucking association said Transportation Department statistics found bigger trucks to be as safe or safer than normal trucks. Claybrook said the group would try to influence the highway bill Congress is expected to draft next year. She said CRASH also would push for stricter controls on drivers who use drugs or alcohol, laws requiring devices on trucks to record their speed and hours of operation automatically, and rules to get poorly maintained trucks off the road.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Plans To Plead Case For Keeping United Germany In NATO
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says he will use next week's summit with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to make the case for keeping Germany in NATO. The president, vacationing at his family compound at this oceanfront resort, late Friday night signed a $4 billion spending package that includes $720 million in emergency aid for Panama and Nicaragua. The measure finally passed Congress in the wee hours Friday morning. Bush signed it at 10:19 p.m. after an Air Force jet rushed it to Pease Air Force Base in New Hampshire and it was driven to his home here. The president did so despite misgivings about what the White House regards as pork-barrel add-ons by Congress and concerns about restrictions on his ability to enter into international agreements affecting NATO. In a statement, Bush said the $720 million will help ``restore peace and ... support the emerging democracies in Panama and Nicaragua.'' But he expressed ``regret that the Congress has used this important legislation to enact many special interest provisions that are not in response to dire emergencies.'' He also criticized Congress for cutting $2 billion from defense programs to offset about half of the $4 billion-plus cost of the spending bill. In a pre-summit interview with French television, Bush said it is not his problem whether Gorbachev is being hemmed in on arms control and troop cutbacks by the Soviet high command. ``I gather he's in pretty strong control now, but facing enormous problems,'' Bush said in the interview Thursday. The White House released a transcript Friday. ``But it's not my role to figure out whether Gorbachev is having a problem with his right or his left. It's mine to deal with what's on the table. And what's on the table is a strong Soviet leader, clearly in charge, with whom we have a lot of business items,'' he said. ``I will approach him and make my case for a (united) Germany in NATO,'' he said. In Moscow on Friday, Gorbachev said after meeting with French President Francois Mitterrand that if the West insists on making Germany a member of the Western military alliance, he would be forced to take ``a fresh look'' at its polities on arms control and European security. The White House declined comment on Gorbachev's warning, spokesman Doug Davidson said. Bush hit the golf links with weekend guest Transportation Secretary Sam Skinner shortly after arriving Friday. He was expected to spend today jogging, playing tennis, boating and getting in another 18 holes. Bush had called the presidents of Panama and Nicaragua before leaving Washington on Friday to assure them help soon would be on its way. The measure he signed provides $420 million for Panama, rebuilding after U.S. economic sanctions and an invasion of American forces last December to topple Manuel Antonio Noriega. Nicaragua's new government, led by U.S.-backed President Violeta Chamorro, will receive $300 million. The spending bill includes $1.2 billion needed to make up a shortfall in food stamp funds for the current fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30; $545 million for veterans benefits; $166 million for Head Start; $432 million for fighting forest fires; $110 million for the Census; and $33 million for NASA. It also includes $75 million to meet refugee needs around the world, $45 million in anti-narcotics aid to Bolivia and Peru, $30 million for aid to Caribbean countries and $30 million for Africa. The final version dropped $10 million that the Senate wanted to spend to build a new U.S. embassy in Lithuania. Bush complained the legislation would ``infringe upon my constitutional authority over the conduct of diplomacy'' by requiring him to give Congress 30 days' notice of agreements involving NATO. He said he would regard those provisions as merely ``advisory.'' Bush, who will not return to the White House until Monday, had no special pre-summit briefings planned. His chief of staff John Sununu, national security adviser Brent Scowcroft and press secretary Marlin Fitzwater did not even accompany him to Maine. In addition to Skinner and his wife, Honey, the Bushes' weekend guests included Houston friends Charles and Sally Neblett, and son Marvin Bush, his wife Margaret and their children, Marshall and Walker.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Mayor Loses Round In Court; Says He's Ready For Trial
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry says he's ready to go to trial now that a judge refuses to drop the drug and perjury charges against him or to throw out medical and videotaped evidence that he allegedly used drugs. Defense attorneys argued on Friday that the government engaged in prosecutorial vindictiveness by bringing six new drug charges against the mayor May 10. They also argued that the government engaged in impermissible conduct by having a cooperating government witness lure Barry to the Vista Hotel on Jan. 18, where he allegedly smoked crack cocaine. The mayor unsuccessfully sought to have the 14 criminal charges against him dismissed and videotape and hair sample evidence against him suppressed. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson ruled that there was no evidence of vindictiveness. He also ruled that Barry's actions at the Vista were voluntary, and not coerced by the government. Defense R. Kenneth Mundy used statements by a cardiologist to suggest that the FBI had endangered Barry's life by setting up the sting operation. But ``no violence occurred, and no coercion was employed,'' said Jackson. The judge did order the government to provide Barry with a list of the alleged co-conspirators and the times and places of the alleged cocaine possessions. Jackson also gave Barry until Tuesday to decide whether to seek a separation of the six charges brought May 10, which would result in a second trial at a later date. A June 4 trial is scheduled on 10 counts of cocaine possession, one count of conspiracy and three felony charges of lying to a federal grand jury. ``I feel very good about today,'' Barry said after the day of pre-trial courtroom arguments, which he attended. ``We're ready to go to trial.'' The judge said the videotape of the hotel bedroom was lawfully obtained with the permission of the hotel room's occupant, ex-model Rasheeda Moore. Mundy said a hair sample taken from Barry after his arrest at the Vista Hotel should be excluded. It tested positive for cocaine residue. Mundy said the residue could be from someone else and that ``so far, it's not a crime to be in a room'' where another person uses cocaine. But the presence of cocaine in body specimens indicates relatively recent ``ingestion'' of a substance, said Jackson, and ``may permit an inference of both a present familiarity ... and a willingness to be using it again.'' Jackson said he will reserve a ruling on whether the hair sample will be admissible evidence at trial.

DOC.HEAD: Campbells Creek Says It Has Been Portrayed Unfairly
DOC.TEXT: Residents of rural Campbells Creek figure their town went down a notch in the eyes of outsiders when they were accused of bullying a local florist rumored to have AIDS. On Friday, after state and county officials said Bill Grealis may have made up stories of beatings and threats against him, residents said they had been in the spotlight long enough. ``I think it really gave us a black eye,'' said Anna Belle Reynolds, 56, who operates a clothing store in Campbells Creek. ``I just want to see this over with ... There's been a lot of negative publicity. It's been a real worry to me,'' she said. Grealis, 41, checked into a psychiatric ward in nearby Charleston on Thursday, state officials said. Grealis had said he was terrorized by people in the small mining community of 300 since last December, after he lost 50 pounds from prostrate problems and split with his wife of 22 years. Grealis said he was nearly forced into bankruptcy and at one point considered suicide because of the alleged smear campaign. He said the tires of his van were slashed and ``AIDS'' scrawled on the side of the vehicle. A week ago, Grealis said he was robbed, struck in the head and had his left arm slashed by an unknown assailant. No arrests were made. On May 14, Grealis and state Attorney General Roger Tompkins announced at a news conference that Grealis was free of AIDS. The florist posted his clean bill of health on the shop window. But on Thursday, prosecutor Bill Forbes disputed the man's accusations and said he may have wounded himself. Carrie Webster, a spokeswoman for the state attorney general's office, said the case is being investigated. Grealis, who still contends that several of the attacks were real, could not be reached for comment Friday. Officials at the hospital where he is staying said they would not let him speak with reporters. Rosalie Morris, 51, who works at Fas-Chek Super Market in Campbells Creek, said many outsiders were unfairly basing their opinions of the entire town on the incident. ``We get a bad reputation and there's a lot of good people up here,'' she said. ``It's like anywhere else. There's good and bad people.'' Morris and others, however, said they wouldn't hold a grudge against Grealis ``if the doctor really proves him sick.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Vanessa Williams, who lost the Miss America 1984 crown when it was disclosed she posed nude for Penthouse magazine, says in a new magazine interview that relinquishing the title ``was like a death in the family.'' ``People sent flowers. The press camped out on our lawn. People spray-painted obscenities on the driveway of the local A&P,'' the first black Miss America said in the June issue of Gentlemen's Quarterly. ``But the hardest part was telling my parents about the pictures,'' she said. ``I cried and told them I was sorry. They said there was nothing to be sorry about.'' With the help of her husband and business manager, Ramon Hervey, Williams has developed a musical career. She achieved a breakthrough in 1988 with the release of her rhythm and blues album ``The Right Stuff,'' which featured three hit singles.

Paul McCartney will not be appearing at the Yale Bowl after all, responding to residents of the area near the stadium who bitterly opposed the concert. Mayor John Daniels initially blocked plans for the concert, citing the residents' concerns, but later changed his mind after requiring the promoters to meet a long list of conditions. The concert had been set for late July, but McCartney's manager, Richard Ogden, said Friday it had been shelved. ``Paul is very sensitive to community concerns of this sort and has no desire to be the catalyst for such a deep and divisive controversy within the city,'' Ogden said.

A supermarket tabloid has paid undisclosed damages to Tom Selleck's father for publishing statements falsely attributed to him in an 1982 article detailing his son's alleged ``love secrets.'' The Globe, a Florida-based weekly, published an apology this week as part of a settlement of a $6 million libel lawsuit filed seven years ago by Robert Selleck. The terms of the settlement were not disclosed. The lawsuit concerned a Dec. 14, 1982, story headlined, ``Tom Selleck's Love Secrets _ By His Father.'' Other headlines promised, ``His father reveals all'' about ``why Tom Selleck can never become a happy lover.'' Robert Selleck denied making any statements about his actor son's love life. ``Although he spoke to a reporter, Mr. Selleck did not write the article for the Globe, did not make certain of the statements in the article, did not reveal any of his son's confidences and did not reveal any of his son's `love secrets,''' The Globe wrote in the apology. The Globe said it regretted the inaccuracies in the article and apologized to the Selleck family for any harm or embarrassment they caused.

Thomas Monaghan, owner of Domino's Pizza Inc. and the Detroit Tigers, wants to help rebuild a cathedral in Nicaragua. Monaghan has invited 1,500 friends and associates to a June 11 fund-raiser at Domino's headquarters near Ann Arbor to raise funds for rebuilding a cathedral destroyed in a 1972 earthquake in Managua. Nicaragua Cardinal Obando y Bravo, seeking financial support in the United States, first contacted Cardinal Richard Law of Boston, who referred him to Monaghan. ``Obando and Law contacted Mr. Monaghan because they knew he was a Catholic business leader, and they knew he would be interested because he's already helping to build chapels in Honduras,'' said Monaghan's daughter, Maggie. The Managua cathedral will cost $2 million to fix. Since 1988, the Domino's Foundation has financed two chapels in rural Honduras.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also moving on sports wires
DOC.TEXT: A son of the late Pittsburgh Pirates superstar Roberto Clemente returned to the city for a benefit concert to raise money for a sports project in Nicaragua. Luis Clemente, a 23-year-old keyboard player from Puerto Rico, is scheduled to perform his own compositions Saturday night at the ``Grand Slam Jam'' at a Pittsburgh night club. The concert will raise money for the Pittsburgh-San Isidro Roberto Clemente Sport Project, which supplies baseball equipment for children in Nicaragua. The former Hall of Famer died in 1972 in an airplane crash while taking supplies to earthquake victims in the Central American country.

Funk rock singer, songwriter and producer George Clinton was arrested for investigation of cocaine possession after a small amount of the drug allegedly was found in a car he was in, authorities said. Clinton, 45, former leader of the Funkadelics, a funk rock group of the 1970s, was arrested early Friday with Archie Ray Ivy, 39, of Inglewood, said sheriff's Deputy Bill Linnemeyer. Deputies stopped Ivy's 1977 Mercedes Benz because its headlights were off, said Linnemeyer. He said deputies spotted the cocaine on the car's floor between the two men. Clinton, a Michigan resident, was en route to his hotel after a recording session, Linnemeyer said. Both men were booked and bail for each was set at $2,500. Arraignment was tentatively scheduled for Tuesday in Inglewood Municipal Court. During the 1970s, the Funkadelics and other permutations of the band, including Parliament Funkadelic, recorded albums including ``Funkadelic,'' ``Free Your Mind,'' ``Maggot Brain'' and ``One Nation Under a Groove.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Army Accused Of Killing 114 People; Contras Break Off Disarmament Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with NEW charges of death toll of 14 Contras and 100 civilians, govt promises investigation. Pickup 7th graf `Lara branded...'; DROPS outdated 11th graf `The high...'; ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Contra rebels broke off disarmament talks Friday, accusing the Sandinista-dominated army of killing 14 disarmed guerrillas and 100 civilians in northern Nicaragua. The conservative government of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, which succeeded the leftist Sandinista administration a month ago but left Sandinistas in charge of the military, promised to look into the report. Contra Commander Oscar Sobalvarro and other rebel leaders issued a communique initially charging that five disarmed Contras were killed and nine others were missing after a May 18 army massacre near Waslala in Matagalpa province, 150 miles northeast of Managua. Defense Ministry spokesman Carlos Lara called the charges ``totally false.'' A rebel delegation raised the later charges of 14 Contra and 100 civilian dead in a Friday night meeting with the government, said Roberto Ferrey, one of the government representatives. ``If the charges bear out, the government is prepared to order an exhaustive investigation and punishment sanctioning whoever turns out to be responsible,'' said Ferrey. He said Mrs. Chamorro ordered an on-site investigation with the participation of Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo. The rebels learned of the incident Thursday, the same day that disarmament talks with the government got under way, Sobalvarro said in a news conference. ``The talks with the government are suspended indefinitely, until the incident is investigated and those guilty of the massacre of the demobilized rebels are punished,'' the Contra commander said. Lara branded the charges ``part of a Contra propaganda campaign aimed at creating mistrust and insecurity among those who are trying to demobilize and disarm according to agreements with the government.'' A May 4 agreement between Contras and the government set a June 10 deadline for 11,000 rebels to give up their weapons. But the Contra high command suspended disarmament on May 19, and fewer than 1,500 fighters have been demobilized to date. Sovalbarro said Friday the high command will continue to withhold orders for disarmament. The Contras, backed by the United States, fought the leftist Sandinista government in a 10-year war that left 30,000 dead. Rebel fighters said they would give up their arms when Mrs. Chamorro, backed by the United States, took over the presidency from Sandinista President Daniel Ortega on April 25. But the high command changed its mind, saying its troops were not receiving enough food, housing, jobs and security measures from the government. The Contras say their chief concern is the threat of the army, which is controlled mostly by Sandinistas.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Wants To Shuffle Defense Money To Avoid Firing Employees
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney plans to shuffle millions of dollars among the Pentagon's accounts to keep as many as 68,000 of its employees from losing their jobs. Traditionally the defense secretary would make such a move with the consent of key members of Congress, but Cheney says he plans to go ahead with this regardless of whether all the necessary lawmakers agree. ``We want to protect military personnel from the effects of shortages in the manpower accounts,'' he said Friday. ``Last fall, Congress said it expected us to pursue this kind of reprogramming, and that's what I've been trying to do for the past five months.'' The Pentagon has asked for authority to move $852 million from other accounts to avoid the dismissal of military personnel by October. Such a shift of funds from one pocket to another is known in Washington jargon as a ``reprogramming.'' Such shifts of money are customarily submitted to the chairmen and ranking minority members of the House and Senate armed services committees and the corresponding Appropriations defense subcommittees. The Pentagon has estimated that without the reprogramming authority, 44,100 to 68,200 military personnel would have to be fired by Oct. 1. Between 32,000 and 36,000 people would be frozen in their current jobs, 57,000 to 67,000 promotions would be delayed, and 59,000 to 115,900 fewer men and women could be brought into the armed forces. Cheney said he has the agreement of seven of the eight lawmakers, with only Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, holding out. ``If no acceptable agreement can be worked out by the first week Congress is back from its recess, then I will use the authority I have to reprogram the necessary funds,'' said Cheney. ``I have agreed to make one more good faith effort and try to reach a solution to which all eight chairmen and ranking members of the key committees can agree,'' he said. Congress will return from recess June 5. Aspin was traveling and unavailable for comment. A committee source, speaking on condition he not be identified, agreed the Pentagon has the authority to move the funds around but said there has been ``a gentlemen's agreement'' to consult with Congress. ``What Cheney is doing is trying to break the gentlemen's agreement,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Club Med Taking Over Former Black Sea Resort for Top Communists
DOC.TEXT: Club Med hopes Western tourists will soon be frolicking at a Black Sea resort once the exclusive domain of Communist Party bigwigs in Bulgaria. Officials of Club Mediterranean, the French resort empire, said Friday that a contract will be signed within a few days with Bulgarian Tourism Minister Stoyan Zhulev to transform the resort into one of its trademark vacation villages. The 600-bed resort, located 10 miles from the Black Sea city of Varna, is scheduled to open under Club Med management in 1991. The officials said they are negotiating similar agreements with Romania, and have other projects on the drawing board for the Soviet Union and Hungary.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General Took Lie Detector Test in Leak Inquiry
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh took a lie-detector test during an investigation into leaks to the media from the U.S. Justice Department, The New York Times reported today. Thornburgh was believed to be the first attorney general to ever take a polygraph exam, Bush Administration officials who were not identified told the Times. He passed the test, which was conducted last September, the Times said. The investigation involved Thornburgh's attempt to find the source of an unauthorized disclosure to CBS News about an FBI inquiry into financial irregularities at Rep. William H. Gray, D-Pa. Thornburgh took the polygraph at the request of Edward S.G. Dennis Jr., head of the Justice Department's criminal division, after investigators decided they needed to test all officials who had access to the information about Gray, the Times said. Two of Thornburgh's top aides, David Runkel, his press secretary, and Robert S. Ross Jr., his executive assistant, failed lie-detector tests and were reassigned to lesser positions in the Justice Department, the Times said. Neither was implicated as the primary source of the news leak, the newspaper said. Two weeks ago, the Justice Department's second-highest official, Donald B. Ayer, resigned in protest over what he said was an attempt by Thornburgh to shield the aides from the inquiry. Thornburgh told the Times he considered the matter closed and that he and his staff had been cleared of any wrongdoing. Nobody answered the telephone Friday night at the home of a Justice Department spokesman, Dan Eramian, but the Times said department officials had declined to comment.

DOC.HEAD: Marxist Rebels Force Peruvian Shoppers to Loot Stores
DOC.TEXT: Communist rebels armed with assault rifles and dynamite forced shoppers to loot two large downtown stores, police said. A band of 20 guerrillas rounded up employees of a department store and a shoe store on Friday and ordered shoppers to take whatever they wanted, police said. The guerrillas, members of the Cuban-inspired Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement, left five sticks of dynamite in front of one of the stores before escaping into the capital's streets filled with rush-hour crowds. Ten of the rebels were armed with assault rifles and submachine guns, while the rest carried sticks of dynamite, police said. The Tupac Amaru band took up arms in 1984. It is smaller and less radical than the Maoist Shining Path guerrillas who control much of Peru's mountain and jungle regions. More than 18,000 people have died in political violence in the last decade.

DOC.HEAD: 50 Penguins Found Dead in Hold of Taiwanese Trawler
DOC.TEXT: The bodies of 50 endangered penguins were found floating in the flooded hold of a Taiwanese fishing trawler that ran aground, environmental officials said. The carcasses of the Jackass penguins had been individually packaged in plastic bags, the officials said Friday. The fishing trawler An Hung ran aground on the rocky southwestern coast of South Africa early Tuesday, and 15 crewmembers were rescued by helicopter. One was found dead on the beach Tuesday. The Jackass penguin is unique to the southern African coast and is protected under South African law. Its population has diminished after centuries of being hunted. Its natural habitat has been diminished by fishing and the collection of the guano the bird uses to build its nests.
1 a.m. EDT: 0.

DOC.HEAD: Poet Mark Strand Gets Laureate's Post at Library of Congress
DOC.TEXT: Poet Mark Strand, an English professor at the University of Utah, has been named the new poet laureate consultant in poetry at the Library of Congress. Strand will start his one-year assignment in September. He will receive $35,000 to give a poetry reading and a lecture during the year, to work with students and to advise Librarian of Congress James H. Billington on new library acquisitions. He will succeed poet Howard Nemerov, who served for two years. Strand also is a short-story writer, editor, translator and author of children's books, The position of consultant in poetry was created 54 years ago. Congress voted in 1985 to expand the title to designate its holder as the equivalent of poet laureate of the United States. A former Fulbright Scholar, Strand taught at 14 colleges and universities before he joined the University of Utah faculty in Salt Lake City in 1981. Among his awards are the Edgar Allan Poe prize in 1974 and the National Institute of Arts and Letters award in 1975.
DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Who Ditched Plane Over Atlantic Faces FCC Disbarment
DOC.TEXT: The Washington attorney who ditched his plane in the Atlantic Ocean last summer has been ordered to show why he shouldn't be disbarred from practicing before the Federal Communications Commission. In the meantime, Thomas L. Root has been suspended from practicing law before the commission, the FCC said Friday. The commission said it took the action because the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia entered an order April 12 disbarring Root by consent. FCC rules require that attorneys practicing before it not be under any disbarment order. Telephone calls to Root's office Friday went unanswered. In March, Root was indicted on 33 counts of fraud and other crimes involving radio stations he was representing before the FCC. The federal indictment accused Root of defrauding the government and five clients in FCC proceedings on permits to construct FM radio stations throughout the United States. Root gained notoriety last July when his single-engine plane ran out of fuel and plunged into the Atlantic off the Bahamas following a six-hour, 800-mile flight that began near Washington. He told authorities that he had been unconscious for most of the odyssey, but Navy fighter pilots flying alongside the plane reported seeing him move in the cockpit. When he was taken to a Florida hospital, Root was found to have suffered a gunshot wound to the abdomen. Less than a week after the crash, Sonrise Management Services of Columbus, Ga., sued Root for $584,000, claiming he failed to perform work and double-billed a client. Root filed for bankruptcy court protection from creditors in October 1989, claiming he had $1.64 million in liabilities.

DOC.HEAD: The King is Definitely Dead _ And It's Suicide?
DOC.TEXT: This is no supermarket tabloid, it's the cover of Life magazine: ``Thirteen years after the death of ELVIS PRESLEY new evidence points to an inescapable conclusion _ SUICIDE.'' The King of Rock 'n' Roll _ rumored to be alive ever since his August 1977 death _ actually killed himself with a massive drug overdose, Presley's controversial biographer claimed Friday. Writer Albert Goldman's story for Life is based in part on information from Elvis' stepbrother, who was among the first to see Presley's body after the singer died in his Memphis mansion, Graceland. ``It's the dream gone to nightmare. It's perfect, it's the archetypal rags to riches to rot story,'' Goldman said as advance copies of his magazine cover story were released to the media. A private autopsy conducted following Presley's death put the cause of death as a heart attack. Through years of rumors about his death, including some saying Elvis staged his own funeral, the Presley estate has stuck with that finding. A phone call to Graceland for comment on Goldman's claim from the Presley estate was not returned. Goldman stunned and infuriated millions of Presley fans around the world with his 1981 biography, ``Elvis,'' which portrayed the King as an obese, impotent, drug addict incapable of taking care of himself. Another unflattering Goldman biography, ``The Lives of John Lennon,'' had the same effect on his fans. In ``Elvis,'' Goldman asserted that Presley had died of an accidental overdose. But he said subsequent conversations with David Stanley, Elvis' stepbrother and a fixture at Graceland, convinced him that Presley committed suicide. Stanley says he knew all along it was a self-inflicted death, but he had trouble accepting it. ``I was willing to protect Elvis as far as last year. But with the constant bombardment of Elvis is alive stories, I came to the conclusion that the best way to deal with things was reality,'' Stanley said Friday at a news conference at the Time & Life Building. The day he died, Elvis had consumed three packets of assorted drugs at once along with some codeine; the doses were usually spread out over eight hours, Stanley said. Goldman points to Elvis' physical deterioration, his drug addiction and his depression over a tell-all book written by ex-bodyguards Red and Sonny West with Steve Dunleavy as three factors in the alleged suicide. Dunleavy, a reporter for Fox's ``A Current Affair,'' called the allegations ``absolute garbage'' in an episode of the program that aired Friday. Goldman said Presley had also attempted suicide once before _ on the eve of his marriage to Priscilla Beaulieu. Stanley, himself a recovering drug addict, said that two days before Elvis' death, the King indicated that he was not much longer for this world. ``He stood up in his bed, and started hugging me and crying. Then he told me, 'David, I'm never going to see you again. The next time we meet will be in a different place,''' Stanley recalled. Goldman said Stanley's story prompted more research, and he quickly became convinced Elvis had killed himself: ``I began to see, uh-oh, boy, you've got the last 18 months wrong. Because this guy was three-quarters dead before he blew out the flame.'' Robert Pondiscio, a spokesman for Life, said the magazine's editors did not believe it was necessary to take extraordinary steps to verify Goldman's research because of his background as the singer's biographer. Routine fact-checking was done, he said. ``Albert Goldman is Elvis' biographer of record, for better or worse,'' Pondiscio said. ``This is the type of story that can't be ignored.''
2 a.m. EDT: 0.

DOC.HEAD: Proposal Would Admit Homosexuals As Reform Rabbis But Advise Reticence
DOC.TEXT: Reform Judaism, one of the three major Jewish branches in the United States, is considering lifting age-old barriers against ordaining homosexuals as rabbis. But homosexual rabbis would be warned about dangers of making their sexual preference public. Reform Judaism, with 1.5 million members nationwide, would be the first U.S. Jewish branch to take allow homosexual rabbis. Adoption of the new ordination guidelines would go against traditional Jewish emphasis on procreation and aversion to homosexuality, dating to pre-biblical times. The proposal was drafted by a 17-member committee of the Central Conference of American Rabbis, representing the nation's 1,560 Reform rabbis, after four years of study, hearings and debate. Rabbi Joseph B. Glaser, the conference's executive vice president, said Friday he expects the proposal to be approved during the group's convention June 24-28 in Seattle. ``It's a well-balanced statement, finely tuned and sensitive to our concerns,'' he said. It ``sets a middle ground,'' approving ordination of homosexuals in a roundabout way. ``We ordain people who are qualified and decent and we're saying if they happen to be gay, it's not any business of ours. We're not making an issue of it. We're saying it's not an issue.'' The proposal urges that ``all rabbis, regardless of sexual orientation, be accorded the opportunity to fulfill their sacred vocation which they have chosen.'' But rabbis who are homosexual would be cautioned about making their orientation public, as it ``can have grave professional consequences.'' ``The unique position of the rabbi as spiritual leader and Judaic role model make the acceptance of gay or lesbian rabbis an intensely emotional and potentially divisive issue,'' the proposal said. Glaser said there was an ancient and ``basic Jewish abhorrence of homosexuality'' derived from Judaism's emphasis on procreation and perpetuating the human seed. ``That was the first commandment,'' he noted, citing God's injunction in the Book of Genesis to ``be fruitful and multiply'' _ something impossible in homosexual unions. The Conservative wing of U.S. Judaism, with 1,300 rabbis and 1.5 million followers, advised Reform colleagues against the new stand. The Orthodox branch, representing an estimated 1 million followers, also strongly condemns homosexuality. An estimated 2 million American Jews are not affiliated with any of the three branches of U.S. Judaism. The proposed Reform policy says: ``All human beings are created betselem elohim (in the divine image). Their personhood must therefore be accorded full dignity. Sexual orientation is irrelevant to the human worth of a person.'' The proposed new stand is based on a recently announced admissions policy of Reform Judaism's Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion of Cincinnati and New York. Glaser said, ``There probably are quite a lot of homosexuals already in the ministry, as rabbis, ministers and priests.'' Citing scientific uncertainty about the origins of all homosexuality, the statement says, ``There are some people for whom heterosexual, monogamous procreative marriage is not a viable option or possibility.'' It adds: ``The majority of the committee reaffirms unequivocally the centrality of monogamous, heterosexual procreative marriage and its special status as kiddushin (sanctified marriage). ``Therefore, in the case of a person for whom sexual identity is a matter of choice, the majority of the committee affirms that heterosexuality is the only appropriate Jewish choice.'' A committee minority maintained that even where choice is possible, ``homosexual relationships are equally'' legitimate and that ``the relationship, not the gender of people, should determine its Jewish value.''

DOC.HEAD: Investor Ordered to Pay $2 Million for Criminal Wetlands Violation
DOC.TEXT: A commodities dealer was ordered to pay $2 million for destroying 86 acres of wetlands on his hunting retreat and, in what the judge called ``restitution for birds,'' was barred from hunting wild fowl. The penalties were the largest financial sanctions ever levied against a person in an environmental criminal case, Assistant U.S. Attorney Jane Barrett said. Multimillionaire investment counselor Paul Tudor Jones II, 35, pleaded guilty Friday in U.S. District Court to one misdemeanor count of violating the Clean Water Act for filling in the wetlands on his Maryland property with 1,400 cubic yards of gravel without a permit. Under a plea bargain, Jones was fined $1 million, ordered to pay $1 million in restitution to the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation and ordered to restore the 86 acres he destroyed, Barrett said. U.S. District Judge Frederick Smalkin also banned Jones from hunting migratory birds anywhere in the United States through 1991. He was placed on 18 months probation and restricted from developing 2,500 acres of his 3,272-acre estate. Jones faced up to one year in prison. Wetlands are considered crucial to the health of Chesapeake Bay because they filter pollutants and provide habitat for wildlife. ``The message this sends is clear _ that those who destroy wetlands will be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law. That is very good news for the Chesapeake Bay and other coastal waters,'' said William Baker, president of the Chesapeake Bay Foundation. In a statement Friday, Jones said the problem arose because he had gotten erroneous advice. ``We believed, in error, that our experts had properly addressed the complex issues related to habitat development in wetlands,'' he said. Breckinridge L. Willcox, the U.S. attorney for Maryland, said the case is the largest wetlands case ever filed in the United States. Jones bought the waterfront estate, now valued at $20 million, in August 1987, Barrett said. The property included 1,742 acres of marshlands and wetlands at the time. The property is northwest of the Black Water National Wildlife Refuge, a sanctuary for geese and duck and home to one of the state's largest populations of bald eagles. Prosecutors said Jones was warned repeatedly in 1987 by his own consultant, Gregg Moore, to stop work at the site until he received permits from the Army Corps of Engineers. The corps told the project manager, William Ellen, in February 1988 after inspecting the site twice to stop filling in the wetlands until a permit was obtained, according to court documents. Ellen, 44, of Matthews, Va., was indicted Friday on six counts of violating the Clean Water Act for filling the wetlands at Tudor Farms without permits and one count of violating the Rivers and Harbors Act by placing fill material in navigable waters without a permit, the U.S. Attorney's office said. Jones owns Tudor Investment Corp., which deals in commodities and financial futures trading. He topped Financial World magazine's 1988 list of the 100 highest-paid people in the investment business, with earnings of $80 million to $100 million in 1987. He reportedly made another $30 million in 1988.

DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 7th graf to provide first reference for Alexander.
DOC.HEAD: Federal Government Suing Ohio For Overcharging Army For Millions
DOC.TEXT: The federal government wants Ohio's National Guard to return the $2 million it allegedly overcharged the Army and to pay some $6.4 million in penalties and damages. In a rare lawsuit filed against the state, the Justice Department said Ohio ``routinely knowingly mischarged and overcharged the National Guard Bureau for the costs of labor through several different fraudulent practices.'' The $8.4 million lawsuit, filed under the False Claims Act, accuses the Ohio state government of overcharging the Army's National Guard Bureau for the costs of labor, utilities and materials at Camp Perry in northwest Ohio. Under the law, the federal government may seek treble damages _ in this case $6 million _ for alleged overcharges. The suit also seeks $2.4 million in penalties for 229 alleged instances of false claims between 1980 and 1987. The False Claims Act is commonly used against private contractors for overbilling the government for goods and services. Its use against a state government is ``extremely rare,'' Justice Department spokesman Michael Robinson said on Friday. Brig. Gen. Thomas Schulte, an assistant adjutant general of the Ohio National Guard, said: ``I haven't seen the complaint so I can't comment. We'll have our attorneys take a look at that and go from there.'' Maj. Gen. Richard C. Alexander, adjutant general of the Ohio National Guard, declined to comment directly on the suit, but said the Guard had reached a settlement with the Army in 1988. ``A Defense Contract Audit Agency audit ... had a finding against us of $4.1 million in disallowed costs going back to 1978,'' Alexander said Friday night. ``Rather than take the matter legally, we were suggested to informally settle with the Army. We did that. There was an agreement to pay the federal government $1 million over a five-year period. ... DCAA made no move and the Justice Department came in.'' D. Michael Crites, U.S. attorney for the southern district of Ohio, said Friday night that the Army has no authority to settle cases involving the False Claims Act. ``This suit is a necessary action to ensure that the government, and in turn the taxpayers, get what they pay for,'' said Stuart M. Gerson, assistant attorney general for the civil division. Among other things, the lawsuit accuses Ohio of billing the National Guard Bureau $315,568 between 1981 and 1987 for the costs of annual rifle matches that were staged by the Army's director of civilian marksmanship. ``In spite of the fact that the state knew that these costs had been billed to, or were to be billed to, the director of civilian marksmanship, the state submitted vouchers for the same costs to the National Guard Bureau,'' said the complaint filed in federal court in Columbus. The National Guard Bureau was charged $315,568 between 1981 and 1987 for expenses that were also paid by the director of civilian marksmanship, the complaint alleged. The lawsuit also accuses Ohio of mischarging or overcharging the Pentagon $498,500 worth of labor costs between 1978 and 1987. The state charged the National Guard Bureau for the overtime of federal workers it had assigned to perform tasks unrelated to the Army's use of the camp. The suit also charges that the state billed the National Guard Bureau $270,666 for fuel oil and electricity for heating buildings that were not used by the Army.

DOC.HEAD: Controversial Photo Exhibit Moving On
DOC.TEXT: A photo exhibit by the late Robert Mapplethorpe was ending its seven-week run today at an art gallery that was indicted for displaying it. More than 75,000 visitors viewed ``The Perfect Moment,'' a display of 175 photos, at the Contemporary Arts Center. Five of the photos depicted homosexual acts and two showed frontal nudity of children, prompting a Hamilton County grand jury to indict the gallery and its director, Dennis Barrie, on misdemeanor obscenity charges last month. The case remains unresolved. Judge David J. Albanese of Hamilton County Municipal Court has yet to rule on pretrial issues, including what evidence may be admitted in the trial and whether the grand jury received proper instructions from prosecutors. The indictments fueled public interest in the exhibit. Lines during the last week at the arts center were long, as usual. Robert Brasier, a gallery attendant collecting admission fees, said the museum had more than 4,600 patrons Thursday and Friday. ``This is like the first day,'' Brasier said Friday. Even before it reached Cincinnati, the Mapplethorpe exhibit prompted a national debate over freedom of artistic expression. The Hamilton County indictments were the first criminal charges brought in the dispute, however. ``Cincinnati has become a microcosm of what is happening all over America,'' Barrie said. In June, Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., showed copies of the most controversial photographs from ``The Perfect Moment'' to members of Congress, and the Corcoran Gallery in Washington, D.C., canceled its showing of the exhibit. But the exhibit was show in six other cities without incident. In Cincinnati, the exhibit had a preview showing April 6 for arts center members. When it opened for the public the next day, spectators included the grand jury, and police temporarily closed the gallery to videotape the photographs. U.S. District Judge Carl Rubin issued a temporary restraining order April 8, barring law-enforcement officials from closing the exhibit until the obscenity question was resolved in court. The exhibit now goes to the Boston Institute of Contemporary Art, where it is to open Aug. 1. Institute director David Ross said he expected a quieter reaction than Cincinnati's.
3 a.m. EDT: 4.

DOC.HEAD: Striptease Enjoys Same Protection as Ballet, Court Rules
DOC.TEXT: Striptease dancing may be bad art, but no matter how the dancers remove their clothes, they're still covered by the constitution, a federal appeals court ruled. The decision released Friday by the 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals found that Indiana cannot use a statute banning public indecency to prohibit nude dancing in taverns and strip joints. ``Though this dance is clearly of inferior artistic and aesthetic quality as contrasted with a classic ballet as the Dance of the Seven Veils in Strauss' `Salome,' the erotic message communicated to the viewers is present in both performances,'' said Judge Joel Flaum, who wrote the majority opinion in the 7-4 decision. Indiana authorities had not argued that the dancing was obscene, and the ruling did not protect forms of dance deemed obscene. However, ``that Strauss' `Salome' tells a compelling story and the nude dancing at the Kitty Kat Lounge may not is not determinative,'' Flaum wrote. ``Expression does not lose its protection for lack of a scripted plot.'' Three dancers and their employers, J.R.'s Kitty Kat Lounge and the Glen Theatre, both in South Bend, had challenged the Indiana law. In dissent, Judge John L. Coffey said the framers of the Constitution never intended for the First Amendment to protect nude dancing. ``No less than in the contexts of abortion and other important questions of present concern, we are required to permit the people of each state to establish, through their democratically elected representatives, the moral climate in which they choose to live and raise their children,'' Coffey wrote. A spokesman for Indiana Attorney General Linley Pearson said the decision would likely be appealed to the U.S. Supreme Court. ``Our office has been diligent in pursuing states' rights issues,'' said the spokesman, Dan Foley. ``We feel that community standards in Indiana are different from places like New York or San Francisco.''

DOC.HEAD: With PM-UN-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from Palestine Liberation Organization chairman Yasser Arafat's 50-minute speech Friday to the United Nations Security Council. He spoke in Arabic. An English translation was provided by the PLO.

``When the Palestine Liberation Organization supported by the Arab Group requested the convening of this urgent sesion of your august council, its request stemmed from the realization that the situation has reached an extremely dangerous and explosive point ... The situation now requires urgent action in order to enforce reverence for international legitimacy...

``It was not the insanity of an individual or his derangement, as the Israeli officials have claimed, that was responsible for the massacre of Black Sunday (in which seven Arab workers were killed by an Israeli gunman on May 20). The primary responsibility falls on the insanity and derangement of the whole system, a system which is haunted by mythical ghosts, by illusions of defunct racial superiority, and by the obsession with expansion and invasion which stems from the stupid arrogance of military superiority in order to create `Greater Israel' ...

``Over the last 30 months, 1,200 Palestinian martyrs have fallen by the bullets of the occupiers. More than 80,000 citizens have been injured as a result of variuous kinds of repression ranging from severe beatings, breaking bones, the use of rubber bullets, live ammunition, to the use of internationally prohibited poison gases which have caused more than 6,000 miscarriages and permanent handicaps to thousands of children, women and men, in addition to other kinds of terrorism and repression. Over 30 months the Israeli occupation forces have been waging a war of extermination on all fronts ...

``I see it as my duty to point out, most regrettably, the unlimited support on all levels given by the U.S.A. to Israel, which has encouraged it to continue the occupation and to escalate the terrorist and barbaric practice against the Palestinian people, challenging the decisions of the international community and impeding all peace initiatives in the Middle East region, including the U.S. proposals themselves...

``The Palestine Liberation Organization, which affirms its strategic commitment to peace, submits to your august body the following practical steps ... First, the designation by the U.N. secretary-general of a special and permanent envoy to work full time on the peace process and to conduct the necessary contacts to secure a peaceful, just and durable solution to the Arab-Israeli conflict or that the secretary-general undertake the duties of this mission on his own. ``Second, the adoption by your august body of a resolution to provide international protection to the Palestinian people, to safeguard their lives, properties and holy places in the occupied territories under the flag of the United Nations and by means of international emergency forces in addition to the deployment along with it of the U.N. observer force now stationed in Jerusalem, with the purpose of ending completely the Israeli occupation of our Palestinian land. ``Third, the adoption by your august council of a clear resolution and ensuring its supervision and implementation in order to stop settler immigration to the occupied Palestinian territories, a decision that will prevent completely the construction and expansion of Israeli settlements, military or civilian in the occupied Palestinian lands, particularly in Arab Jerusalem, in implementation of the relevant international resolutions. ``Fourth, that your august body call the representatives of the permanent members of the Security Council (United States, Britain, the Soviet Union, China, and France) to an immediate meeting to discuss the peace settlement, the peace process, and to prepare for the convening of the International Conference for Peace in the Middle East, in implementation of international resolutions. ``Fifth, to start adopting the necessary arrangements preparing for the imposition of sanctions on Israel in accordance with Chapter Seven of the U.N. Charter, as a response to the crimes committed by Israel against the Palestinian people in the occupied territories and as a consequence of its breach of the Fourth Geneva Convention relative to the treatment of civilians in time of war and also for its refusal to implement the relevant international international resolutions, and for its deliberate defiance and for impeding the peace process in the Middle East... ``Obligations and commitment to the human heritage and to the concepts of justice and righteousness to which that heritage have been dedicated, require that your esteemed council decides upon the formation of an international investigation committee from members of the council to investigate all the crimes against humanity which have been perpetrated by the Israeli government against the Palestinian people... ``In reaffirming that our choice of the path of peace is a genuine strategic alternative we also affirm our right to continue our resistance and our self-defense until an end is put to the Israeli occupation. That is a sacred right guaranteed to us by the law of human rights, the United Nations Charter, international decisions, and by the will of the Palestinian people. The heroic peoples' intefadeh will continue against the Israeli occupation until we wrest our right to freedom and national independence on our national soil.''
4 a.m. EDT: 6.

DOC.HEAD: American On Trial In Cuba For Drug Trafficking
DOC.TEXT: Cuban authorities have put an American on trial for drug trafficking, the Mexican government news agency Notimex reported. William Cooper, identified only as an ex-Marine who fought in the Vietnam War, went on trial Friday in the Cuban province of Guantanamo, Notimex quoted the Cuban National Information Agency as reporting. Cooper is charged with bringing 600 pounds of marijuana to Cuba in 1989, the report said, adding he was arrested in February last year when a boat in which he was traveling ran aground in eastern Cuba. Cooper declared in court that he turned to drug trafficking because he didn't have any money and he had to survive, Notimex quoted the Cuban agency as saying.
