``We ordain people who are qualified and decent and we're saying if they happen to be gay, it's not any business of ours.'' _ Rabbi Joseph B. Glaser, executive vice president of a conference of U.S. Reform Jewish rabbis, on a proposal to lift age-old barriers against ordaining homosexuals.

DOC.HEAD: Violence Mars Closing Days of Colombian Election Campaign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 20 grafs to ADD background on third presidential candidate killed. CORRECTS that two of three assassinations of presidential candidates blamed on traffickers, sted all three. Pickup 19th graf `In Medellin...'
DOC.TEXT: In the final days of a long election campaign marred by bloody attacks by drug traffickers and leftist guerrillas, a new wave of bombings and shootings has killed dozens of people. In the latest violence, a car bomb blast in a Bogota neighborhood late Friday night seriously injured four people and heavily damaged dozens of homes. A leading presidential candidate in Sunday's election proposed that cocaine be legalized in the United States and other countries to wrest profits from drug traffickers. ``The legalization of cocaine in the world would resolve the problem in Colombia,'' Alvaro Gomez, a center-right candidate for the National Salvation Movement, told a news conference. The election front-runner is Cesar Gaviria of the governing Liberal Party, who says there should be no negotiations with drug bosses. The other three candidates have proposed at least some kind of accommodation with them. No one immediately claimed reponsibility for the car bombing Friday night but suspicion fell on drug traffickers blamed for the deaths of more than 250 people since August. Two of three assassinations of presidential hopefuls have been blamed on drug traffickers. The Aug. 18 assassination of then-leading presidential hopeful Luis Carlos Galan, of the Liberal Party, prompted a crackdown in which authorities have extradited drug suspects to the United States and seized the property of traffickers. Government officials say the drug barons are apparently stepping up their terror attacks to scare people away from the polls on Sunday. The army said this week that leftist guerrillas also aim to disrupt the balloting. Since Thursday a wave of bombings and murders in the cocaine capital of Medellin has left 22 people dead and 27 injured. Eight bombs have exploded in Colombia in the last two weeks, killing a total of 34 people and injuring more than 320. The Medellin cocaine cartel has offered $4,300 for every police officer killed. So far this month, 33 have been assassinated, police said. The army and police said they were mobilizing about 230,000 troops to ensure peaceful elections. Bogota is an armed camp. Military checkpoints line major streets and highways, and armored personnel carriers mounted with machine guns patrol the cities. Soldiers are everywhere. It is difficult to have a conversation with a Colombian these days without the subject getting around to bombs and other terrorist acts. ``The violence is keeping people away from public areas and overwhelmingly reducing their activities. It might also keep people at home for the elections,'' Camilo Castellanos, a social scientist, told The Associated Press. A low voter turnout could wrest legitimacy from the winner. That may be exactly what the perpetrators of the violence are seeking in their campaigns to destabilize politics, officials say. The current president, Virgilio Barco, is barred by the constitution from seeking a second consecutive term. Security concerns have prevented many candidates from appearing in public, forcing them to conduct their campaigns through television and radio. ``These are the most tense and difficult elections in Colombian history,'' Antonio Navarro, the presidential candidate for the left-wing M-19 party, told reporters Wednesday. Navarro took over as M-19 candidate after his predecessor, Carlos Pizarro, was murdered in April by an assailant who shot him to death on a commercial jetliner over Bogota. It is unclear whether drug traffickers killed him. The other assassinated presidential candidate was leftist Bernardo Jaramillo, who was killed March 22. Police said he was killed by the Medellin cartel. In Medellin, five bodies, with hands and feet bound, were found Friday on a highway, the police spokeswoman said. The police have not been able to identify the victims. A 44-pound bomb exploded Friday morning at an office building in a wealthy Medellin neighborhood, the spokeswoman said. Three people were hurt, and nearby apartments and stores were damaged. She said one of the three assassinated police officers was shot to death on her way to work Friday morning. On Thursday, a powerful car bomb blew up at a police post outside the luxury Intercontinental Hotel, killing five people and injuring 22, police said. Three of the dead were police officers. The police spokeswoman said unidentified attackers also stormed a Medellin office Thursday night, fatally shooting three men and two women. That same night, four people were murdered elsewhere in the city, she said. Military spokesman Col. Eduardo Arevalo on Wednesday said the rebel National Liberation Army on Tuesday kidnapped two mayors, two mayors-elect, and three city councilmen in the northwestern state of Antioquia. The Bogota daily newspaper El Tiempo, citing military sources, reported this week that the National Liberation Army and another insurgent group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, are planning to sabotage presidential elections.

DOC.HEAD: Railway Strike Spreads to South America's Largest City.
DOC.TEXT: A strike against the government-owned railroad has spread to South America's largest city, and the president of the Federal Railroad System has quit to protest mass layoffs due to austerity cuts. In Sao Paulo close to 10,000 railroad workers walked off the job Friday, grinding commuter and cargo transportation to a halt. About 1 million commuters were forced to use other means of transportation or stay home. The trains are used mostly by poor residents of the outlying suburbs and slums to get to work in downtown Sao Paulo, with a metropolitan area population of more than 15 million. Many commuters crowded into the extra buses placed into circulation by the municipal government. Others resorted to car pools, hitched rides or simply stayed home. In Rio de Janeiro, Brazil's No. 2 city, 11,000 railroad employee stayed off away from work for the second day, said Genaldo Porfirio, public relations director of the Federal Railway System. Some 700,000 commuters were affected. The walkout also affected railway transportation in the states of Bahia, Santa Catarina, Rio Grande do Sul and Alagoas. The strikers are protesting a plan to fire about 18,000 of Brazil's 88,000 railway workers. Late Thursday the president of the Federal Railway System, Francisco Mario Chiesa, and his administrative director, Almir Braga, resigned over disagreement about the layoffs. President Fernando Collor de Mello recently annnounced a plan to fire close to 400,000 federal employees. He said the cuts were needed to end a $31 billion budget deficit, seen as a main cause of inflation that until recently galloped along at 4,000 percent. In Rio, oil workers also voted to strike June 6 in protest against the planned firing of 16,000 of the company's 60,000 employees. The Central Workers Union, a radical left federation of labor unions that claims to represent some 12 million workers, was planning a nationwide general strike on June 6.

DOC.HEAD: Former Hawaii Governor Says He Returned Cash Payment From Imelda Marcos
DOC.TEXT: Former Gov. George Ariyoshi denied a report that he accepted a $50,000 cash payment from Imelda Marcos when the former Philippine first lady visited Hawaii in 1982. In a written statement Friday, Ariyoshi said Mrs. Marcos tried to give him cash. But he said he returned the money. ``I have not done anything wrong and this unfortunate incident was not one of my making,'' said Ariyoshi, who returned here from Japan on Friday. The Los Angeles Times, quoting Mrs. Marcos' travel expense logs that were entered as evidence at her federal racketeering trial in New York, last Saturday reported that Ariyoshi received the payment three days after the Democrat announced his intention to run for re-election. Ariyoshi said he was unable to recall the date. ``But at some time, some gifts were left at Washington Place,'' Hawaii's governor's mansion, he said. Ariyoshi said he found money in an envelope inside one of the packages. ``I immediately decided to return it and rewrapped it,'' Ariyoshi said. ``I did not want to touch the money and I do not know how much there was.'' Ariyoshi said he returned the money to Mrs. Marcos and suggested she donate the money to agencies benefiting Filipinos in Hawaii. Mrs. Marcos has denied making the payment. ``Mrs. Marcos has stated that she never delivered any money to Gov. Ariyoshi and that's our position,'' said Ben Cassiday, an attorney for Mrs. Marcos. ``If Gov. Ariyoshi has a different position, that's fine. I have no idea of really what he's talking about.'' Mrs. Marcos is on trial in federal court in New York, charged with embezzlement and fraud. She is accused of helping her late husband, former Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos, steal more than $220 million from their country's treasury. State records show Ariyoshi, who served as governor from 1974 to 1986, did not report a payment from Mrs. Marcos as a campaign contribution. Either way, such a large contribution would be illegal. Ariyoshi's name appears on Mrs. Marcos' log in a July 1982 entry during a trip Mrs. Marcos made to the Soviet Union, Morocco and the United States, the Times said. On a page listing ``cash disbursements'' for July, 20, 1982, is a brief handwritten entry: ``$50,000 _ Given to Gov. Ariyoshi,'' the Times said. The logs are written in notebooks in which a private secretary to Mrs. Marcos, identified in testimony as longtime aide Fe Roa Gimenez, maintained a running account of expenses incurred by Mrs. Marcos and her entourage during trips abroad, the Times said. Ariyoshi, now a private attorney, is a longtime friend of Mrs. Marcos and her husband, who died in exile in Honolulu in September 1989. Ariyoshi was at Hickam Air Force Base in Honolulu to greet the Marcoses in February 1986 when they fled the Philippines after an uprising that swept President Corazon Aquino to power.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Panel Urges Cutting Related Emissions By More Than Half
DOC.TEXT: A U.N. scientific panel has called for drastic cuts in emissions that cause global warming, saying temperatures will otherwise rise faster in the next century than in the past 10,000 years. The report Friday by the respected committee could help shift international debate from whether global warming exists to how to combat it. The United States and Japan have been skeptical of the phenomenon and reluctant to take action. Global warming is the process by which so-called ``greenhouse gases'' _ such as carbon dioxide and chlorofluorocarbons _ collect on the outer edges of the Earth's atmosphere and trap heat within. The emission of some gases must be cut by more than half simply to stabilize the situation, or the warming will be even faster, the U.N. report said. As it is, the scientists predicted, the overall increase in temperatures in the next century will be greater than that of the previous 10,000 years combined. The rising temperatures could cause sea levels to rise more than two feeet by the end of the next century, they said. The report was one of three being prepared by working groups of the U.N.'s Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, which called on the expertise of about 1,000 scientists around the world. The two other working groups are preparing reports on the effects of global warming, including dangerous climatic change they say will cause rising seas; the spread of disease; and widespread starvation in poor countries. The three reports will be presented in November at the World Climate Conference in Geneva. The scientists said global temperatures will likely increase about 1.8 degrees Fahrenheit in the next 35 years and 5.4 degrees before the end of the next century. Sea levels were predicted to rise by 2.3 inches each decade. That would come to 8 inches by the year 2030, and more than two feet by the end of the next century. Martin Houlgate, a former chief scientist with Britain's Environment Department, said the study suggests that failing to take action could be dangerous. ``The implications of inaction are far more serious than the risks of taking action now and finding that not all our projections were sound,'' he said on British Broadcasting Corp. radio. Dan Lashoff of the Washington D.C.-based Natural Resources Defense Council, said with the new report, the Bush administration ``will no longer be able to pick its favorite scientific skeptics as an excuse for not reducing U.S. emissions.'' The United States has called for more study of global warming before it imposes measures to fight it. After the report's release, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher urged a ``giant international effort'' to deal with the threat. She pledged Britain to reducing projected carbon dioxide emissions by 30 percent by the year 2005. But the United Nations report said cuts in carbon dioxide emissions should be twice as large, and must take effect immediately. ``There must be immediate cuts of more than 60 percent in the output of long-lived gases _ carbon dioxide, nitrous oxide and chlorofluorocarbons _ to stabilize their concentrations at today's levels,'' the scientists said. Means of cutting the emissions include improving energy efficiency and substituting natural gas and other ``clean'' fuels for high-carbon fuels like coal and oil. Other suggested steps included: improving public transportation and traffic management; reducing industrial emissions; promoting tree planting and discouraging deforestation; and providing aid and training to developing countries to encourage the use of energy-efficient technologies. West Germany has proposed a 25 percent reduction in carbon dioxide by 2005. The Netherlands have agreed to stabilize emissions by 1995. France, Italy, Denmark and most of the other 12 members of the European Community favor a proposal that will be discussed at a meeting next month to stablize carbon dioxide emissions at 1990 levels by the year 2000.

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts from Global Warning Report
With PM-Global Warming
DOC.TEXT: Here are some excerpts from the report by the U.N. Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change Working Group I, entitled ``Scientific Assessment of Climate Change.'' The ``executive summary'' of the report was distributed Friday by the British Central Office of Information: We are certain of the following: _There is a natural greenhouse effect which already keeps the Earth warmer than it would otherwise be. _Emissions resulting from human activities are substantially increasing the atmospheric concentrations of the greenhouse gases: carbon dioxide, methane, the chlorofluorocarbons and nitrous oxide. These increases will enhance the greenhouse effect, resulting on average in an additional warming of the Earth's surface. The main greenhouse gas, water vapor, will increase in response to global warming and further enhance it. We calculate with confidence that: _Some gases are potentially more effective than others at changing climate, and their relative effectiveness can be estimated. Carbon dioxide has been responsible for over half the enhanced greenhouse effect in the past, and is likely to remain so in the future. _Atmospheric concentrations of the long-lived gases adjust only slowly to changes in emissions. Continued emissions of these gases at present rates would commit us to increased concentrations for decades to centuries. The longer emissions continue to increase at present day rates, the greater reductions would have to be for concentrations to stabilize at a given level. _The long-lived gases would require immediate reductions in emissions from human activities of over 60 percent to stabilize their concentrations at today's levels. Methane would require a 15-20 percent reduction. Based on current model results, we predict: _Under the IPCC Business-as-Usual scenario of emissions of greenhouse gases, a rate of increase of global mean temperature during the next century of about 0.3 degrees C. per decade (with an uncertainty range of 0.2 degrees C to 0.5 degrees C per decade). This is greater than that seen over the past 10,000 years. This will result in a likely increase in global mean temperature of about 1 degree C above the present value by 2025 and 3 degrees C before the end of the next century. The rise will not be steady because of the influence of other factors. _That land surfaces warm more rapidly than the ocean, and high northern latitudes warm more than global mean in winter. _Regional climate changes differ from the global mean, although our confidence in the prediction of the detail of regional changes is low. For example, temperature increases in southern Europe and central North America are predicted to be higher than the global mean, accompanied on average by reduced summer precipitation and soil moisture. There are less consistent predictions for the tropics and the southern hemisphere. _Under the IPCC Business-as-Usual Emissions scenario, an average rate of global mean sea level rise of about 6 centimeters per decade over the next century (with an uncertainty range of 3-10 centimeters per decade), mainly due to thermal expansion of the oceans and the melting of some land ice. This amounts to a rise of about 20 centimeters in global mean sea level by 2030, and 65 centimeters by the end of the century. There will be significant regional variations. There are many uncertainties in our predictions particularly with regard to the timing, magnitude and regional patterns of climate change.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Finds Nazi War Crime Suspect Innocent; Jewish Groups Call For Retrial
DOC.TEXT: In Canada's first war crimes trial, a jury has acquitted a man charged with manslaughter and other atrocities against thousands of Jews in Nazi-occupied Hungary during World War II. Jewish leaders called for a retrial. Imre Finta, 77, who had shown little emotion as he sat in the prisoner's box during the six-month trial, broke down and cried when he heard the verdict Friday. Finta had been charged with confinement, kidnapping, robbery and manslaughter in the rounding up and deportation of 8,617 Jewish civilians from Hungary in June 1944. ``Nobody believes Finta a Nazi,'' he said sobbing, after being cleared of all charges. ``I love the Jewish people. ... My (former) fiancee was Jewish.'' The Ontario Supreme Court jury of eight women and four men returned its verdict following 12{ hours of deliberations over two days. The native of Hungary, Finta became a Canadian citizen after the war and is now retired from the restaurant business in Toronto. He was a captain in the Hungarian police when the Jews were deported. Identification was a key question at the trial. Finta's lawyer Doug Christie said there was no proof Finta was the uniformed officer some witnesses claimed had been giving orders. The charges alleged Finta was in command when the Jews were rounded up at a brickyard in the village of Szeged, forced aboard squalid boxcars and transported to labor camps in other Nazi-occupied countries. The Simon Wiesenthal Center of Los Angeles said in a statement that it was ``deeply disappointed'' by the acquittal, adding it ``hopes that the judicial authorities will proceed with any and all appeals open to them in this case.'' ``We're in a state of shock,'' said Frank Dimant of B'nai B'rith Canada. ``It's exceptionally painful to us in light of the rising anti-Semitism internationally and in Canada.'' Dimant, executive vice-president of the group, urged Canadian federal officials to appeal the decision and said his organization's lawyers are analyzing legal grounds for a retrial. In 1986, Jules Deschenes, the former chief justice of Quebec Superior Court who headed a government inquiry into war crimes, said there was evidence to warrant immediate prosecutions against at least 20 war crime suspects in Canada. The following year, Parliament passed its war crimes legislation, which empowers the government to make retroactive war-crime charges in war-associated offenses that occurred in another country. Finta was the first person charged under Canada's 1987 legislation on war crimes and crimes against humanity. The two others charged under Canada's war crimes law _ Stephen Reistetter of St. Catharines, Ontario, and Michael Pawlowski of Renfrew, Ontario, near Ottawa, have not yet gone to trial. Reistetter, 75, is charged with kidnapping and unlawfully transporting 3,000 Jews from Nazi-occupied Czechoslovakia while he was a government official during the war. Pawlowski, 72, is charged in the 1942 deaths of 490 people in Byelorussia, the western Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Leader of Fading Ultrarightist Party Quits, Citing Extremists
DOC.TEXT: A ex-Nazi SS soldier whose ultrarightist party was a growing political force until recently has quit as party leader because he says extremists have taken over. Franz Schoenhuber, 66, said after resigning Friday that a ``small clique of extremist functionaries'' existed at top party levels and that he was not responsible for recent clashes between police and party members. Mainstream politicians in Bonn said his decision marks the near-certain demise of one of Europe's most controversial political parties, which went from a mushrooming political force to a fringe group in disarray. Otto Lambsdorff, head of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's junior coalition partners, the Free Democrats, said Friday, ``The remains ... of this party will soon scatter themselves into the wind.'' The Republicans' main office in Munich said Schoenhuber's former deputy, Johanna Grund, 56, will replace him until a new chairperson is elected. Schoenhuber led the Republicans to head-spinning fame last year, championing xenophobic and right-wing platforms to appeal to West Germans tired of competing with foreigners for scarce jobs and housing. Beginning with West Berlin in January 1989, the Republicans scored large gains in state and local elections and also won 7.2 percent in last June's elections for the European Parliament, landing Schoenhuber a seat there. The party claimed its membership climbed from 18,000 to 26,000 the past year. But the wind went out of Schoenhuber's sails after the East German revolution last fall and the sudden realization that German reunification was no longer just a dream. With every mainstream party embracing unification, the Republicans lost much of their nationalist appeal. In recent state elections, the Republicans mustered less than 2 percent of the vote. They slipped badly in national polls _ far below the 5 percent needed to gain seats in the federal parliament in scheduled Dec. 2 elections. In recent days, Schoenhuber repeatedly cautioned that the party was heading too far right and was becoming an extremist right-wing group. His charges drew fire from other party leaders. Schoenhuber said Friday he could not take further responsibility for the party following clashes between police and party members during recent rallies for Oct. 14 Bavarian state parliamentary elections. He said he himself was withdrawing as a candidate for parliament in those elections. Far-right political parties in West Germany have a history of fizzling out, unable to sustain strong membership in a nation where the Nazi past makes the electorate especially sensitive.

DOC.HEAD: Small Quake Rattles Southern Utah Town of Hurricane
DOC.TEXT: A small earthquake rattled dishes in Hurricane, authorities said. No damage was reported in the tremor Friday evening measuring 2.6 on the Richter scale, said Jim Pechmann, a research assistant professor at the University of Utah Seismograph Stations in Salt Lake City. Pechmann said the earthquake likely was centered along the Hurricane Fault running about seven miles northwest of this small town 270 miles south of Salt Lake City near the Utah-Arizona border. Pechmann said he spoke by telephone with several Hurricane residents who all reported feeling the quake. One woman told him that the dishes in her kitchen cabinets rattled. The Richter scale is a gauge of energy released by an earthquake, as measured by ground motion and recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one number in magnitude means the ground motion is 10 times greater. An earthquake of 3.5 magnitude can cause slight damage in the local area.

DOC.HEAD: Replacement Greyhound Driver Fired After Crash
DOC.TEXT: A replacement driver of a Greyhound Lines bus that crashed was fired after the company determined the accident was avoidable, a spokesman said. Spokesman George Gravley said Greyhound completed its investigation Friday and found that driver Bobby Williamson could have prevented the accident Thursday night that hospitalized eight of 46 passengers. Four of the injured passengers were released Friday from a hospital; the remaining four were in stable condition with cuts and bruises, hospital officials said. Williamson, 50, of Chicago, had told the state highway patrol a tractor-trailer forced the bus off Interstate 80 about two miles east of Wamsutter on Thursday. But passengers on the bus told the patrolman investigating the accident that Williamson was drowsy and had been drifting between lanes. The cause of the accident hadn't been determined by Friday afternoon, but Gravley said Williamson should have been able to control the bus even if he was forced off the road. ``We found the accident was preventable and was caused by driver error,'' Gravley said. ``We had two stories: One about the truck forcing him off the road and the story that he fell asleep. In one respect it doesn't matter. ``Once he went into the median, he should have been able to slow down and avoid the accident.'' Williamson was a replacement driver who began driving for Greyhound when members of the Amalgamated Transit Union went on a nationwidestrike against the bus company in March, Gravley saod.

DOC.HEAD: Heart Surgery Done on Girl Returned to Hospital After Abduction by Mother
DOC.TEXT: A 12-year-old girl abducted by her mother from a hospital two weeks ago underwent the heart surgery that her mother had objected to on religious grounds. Kimberly Winfield was in critical but stable condition after open heart surgery Friday to correct damage she suffered from rheumatic fever five years ago, doctors at Children's Memorial Hospital said. Doctors repaired a valve in Kimberly's heart and replaced another with an artificial valve, hospital spokeswoman Jean Benzies said late Friday. Caroline Winfield, 35, abducted the girl from the hospital on May 10. As a member of the Jehovah's Witnesses, Mrs. Winfield is opposed to any medical procedure that involve blood transfusion. Mrs. Winfield, a homeless, woman, surrendered several days later and Kimberly was returned to the hospital. Her mother was charged with child abduction. Kimberly had been a ward of the state since March, when she was found wandering the streets with Mrs. Winfield, said Dave Schneidman of the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services.
6 a.m. EDT: 7.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Aide Says Castro Taped Key Prosecution Witness
DOC.TEXT: A former aide to Manuel Noriega says Fidel Castro plans to turn over taped conversations with a witness in Noriega's trial that will assist the former Panamanian strongman in his defense. Maj. Felipe Camargo, an intelligence officer who held a variety of top positions under Noriega, made the statements to The Miami Herald from his prison cell in Gamboa, Panama, where he has been held since the U.S. invasion. Lead defense attorney Frank Rubino said he had not received any transcripts from Castro, although he said Castro provided him with defense material during a meeting in Cuba. Camargo said Castro had taped conversations with Jose Blandon, the former Noriega aide who broke with his boss in 1988 and later testified before Congress and to a federal grand jury against Noriega. Blandon was the chief witness to one important charge in the February 1988 drug-trafficking indictment against Noriega. He said Castro had mediated a dispute between the Colombian cocaine cartel and Noriega after a raid on a Panamanian drug lab that the traffickers had paid millions of dollars to protect. Camargo, who frequently traveled to Cuba on behalf of Noriega, said Castro disputes the charge, and was sending transcripts to the Miami defense attorneys to back up his claim. ``As a security measure, everything was taped,'' Camargo said. ``Fidel showed us that he had transcripts of various conversations with Blandon. ... He told us they prove that the affair with the Colombians was never discussed.'' After Blandon went public with his charges, Castro added a stenographer at all meetings with Panamanian officials, said Camargo. The Herald said Camargo is believed to be negotiating a plea bargain for a reduced sentence in Panama on 18 charges of brutality against prisoners, in exchange for his testimony on behalf of Noriega's prosecutors. Camargo refused to answer directly whether Castro had knowledge of the cocaine lab raid dispute, but said another highly placed Cuban, Manuel Pinero, head of Cuba's powerful Americas Department, talked to him about the incident. ``Pinero told me, `Don't get into trouble with the Colombians: They are very powerful people, very dangerous people,''' Camargo said.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Puts Damper on Holiday in East and Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Rain early today put a damper on the start of the Memorial Day weekend in portions of the East and Midwest. Cloudy skies ushered in the holiday elsewhere in the United States. Showers accompanied a warm front in Virginia, Maryland, Delaware and West Virginia. Rain also fell in Cleveland, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh, Washington, D.C., and St. Louis. Mostly sunny skies were forecast today in New England, California and parts of Utah, New Mexico and Texas. Miami had cloudy skies early today, as did Cincinnati, Hatteras, N.C., and Reno, Nev. Showers were predicted in Idaho and Washington state, with thunderstorms from Oklahoma to Ohio. A tornado touched down briefly Friday near Humbolt, Kan. Hail the size of golf balls dropped near Iola, Kan. Kentucky was hit by thunderstorms, including wind gusts of 62 mph in Brandenburg. Rainshowers and thunderstorms Friday also plagued Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Tennessee, Florida and Virginia. The high temperature Friday in the Lower 48 states was 105 degrees in Childress, Midland, Presidio and Lajitas in Texas. DOC.HEAD: State to Appeal Ruling That Allows KKK Members to Wear Masks In Public
DOC.TEXT: A judge has struck down a law that banned the Ku Klux Klan from wearing masks in public, saying the group was ``persecuted'' for expressing its racist views. State Court Judge Howard E. Cook ruled on Friday that the 1951 law prohibiting the use of masks in public violated the First Amendment and was unconstitutionally vague and broad. Assistant county solicitor David M. Fuller filed a notice of appeal 30 minutes after Cook ruled in favor of a Klan member, who had challenged the law by wearing the white headgear during a one-man demonstration. ``It saddens me because this order, if upheld, gives protection to some groups worthy of it, but it's going to afford the same protection to groups not worthy of it, such as the Klan,'' Fuller said. The ruling would give the Klan ``carte blanche to revert to how it operated in the '30s and '40s,'' Fuller said. Cook wrote in his decision that, ``Anonymity has been permitted (under the Constitution) when the group has been subject to potential harm to themselves and their family members, as well as the possibility of losing their jobs and the ability to earn a livelihood.'' Klansman Shade Miller Jr., 27, of Calhoun was arrested and cited for a misdemeanor during the February demonstration. He said during the trial he wore it because he feared for his safety and his family's safety if his Klan affiliation were known. Miller's attorney, Michael Hauptman, criticized the state for defending the ban and predicted Cook's ruling will hold up on appeal. ``The statute is clearly unconstitutional. The state would be better off in spending its resources drafting a constitutional statute rather than defending this one,'' Hauptman said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Stopped to Play Nintendo During Burglary Sentenced to Prison
DOC.TEXT: A man who was caught burglarizing a home because he stopped to play a Nintendo video game was sentenced to eight years in prison. Kelly Lee Hardyman, 20, pleaded guilty Friday to two burglary charges and was sentenced as an habitual offender. He also was ordered by Circuit Judge Robert Cates to serve 15 years of probation and undergo drug treatment and testing after his release. In January, a woman stopped by her house on her lunch hour and encountered Hardyman playing the family's Nintendo game. He had taken a small amount of money. Hardyman also was charged in a similar break-in where he also had stopped to play Nintendo. Hardyman, who has a history of burglary convictions, has told police he broke into houses partly because he was bored.

DOC.HEAD: Another Former Nazi Faces Visa Fraud Charges in Hawaii
DOC.TEXT: A former Nazi SS guard at the Auschwitz concentration camp was arrested for failing to disclose his Nazi past when applying for a U.S. visa. It was the second such arrest here in three weeks. Stefan Paal, 65, of Stuttgart, West Germany, was charged Friday with one count of visa fraud. U.S. Magistrate Bert Tokairin ordered Paal to be held pending a detention hearing scheduled for Tuesday. Paal arrived Thursday on vacation. A computer check by the Immigration and Naturalization Service showed he had served at the concentration camp in Poland during World War II, the U.S. Attorney's Office said. Another suspected former Nazi SS officer, Joseph Aloysius Goertz was arrested on visa fraud charges when he arrived in Honolulu on May 8. Goertz, 76, was freed on $100,000 cash bail but was ordered to stay in his hotel room at night and on weekends. Both men apparently were part of tour groups, the U.S. Attorney's Office said. Under U.S. law, former concentration camp guards cannot be issued U.S. visas under any circumstances. Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Burke said Paal's passport showed he had traveled to Thailand, Australia, New Zealand and Fiji before his arrival on a New Zealand Airlines flight. Paal acknowledged performing guard duty once or twice a week in 1943-44, and admitted he did not disclose his Nazi past when he applied for a visa, INS inspector Joseph Rogers said.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Tells Maltese to Cling to Catholic Heritage
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II crossed the Maltese archipelago today and urged the islanders to reject any challenges to the Roman Catholic Church's ban on abortion and other family teachings. On the second day of his pilgrimage here, the first ever by a pope to Malta, John Paul kept up his theme of reminding the Maltese of their centuries-long Catholic traditions. The Vatican says 98.9 percent of Malta's 350,000 people are Catholic. Abortion is illegal here, and courts do not grant divorces. John Paul crossed from Malta to Gozo, the second largest island in the archipelago, on a 60-foot catamaran. The trip took him by St. Paul's Bay, where Maltese say the apostle was shipwrecked in the year 60 and founded the first Christian community on the island. Papal spokesman Joaquin Navarro said John Paul stood on the bridge during the 18-minute trip across the blue Mediterranean waters, nearly calm except for an occasional whitecap. Celebrating his first Mass on Malta at a 17th-century shrine dedicated to the Virgin Mary, John Paul said that Maltese families must guard against the challenge posed by rapid development. ``Like many societies, yours is not immune to a kind of spiritual disorientation caused by rapid social changes and the attraction of value systems and modes of behavior which run counter to the deepest convictions which have molded your identity as a people,'' John Paul said, speaking in English. He called on ``all those responsible for the public welfare'' to reject as harmful to society ``everything that would ignore or deny God's plan for the family and lessen respect for the gift of human life,'' referring to abortion. About 1,000 people jammed into the small square in front of the basilica under a scorching sun for the Mass. With a holiday spirit prevailing, cannons boomed a noisy salute when word reached this town that the pope had docked in Gozo. Enthusiastic crowds rushed toward the white ``popemobile'' as it drove toward the Mass site. The visit comes after a long period of church-state tension under the previous Socialist government, which ruled from 1971 until narrowly losing the general election in 1987. The Socialist government barred private schools, including Catholic ones, from charging tuition. It also ordered the church to hand over property it could not prove it owned. New church-state accords are being worked out with the present Nationalist administration. Since arriving in Malta on Friday afternoon, the pope has made clear he expects the government to allow the church to play its historic leading role on the islands. The visit, the pope's 48th foreign tour, ends Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Huge Pro-Apartheid Rally in South Africa
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 7 grafs for 7-10 pvs, `De Klerk has...and English.' to CORRECT attribution on quote to Treurnicht, ADD that signiture drive can't force de Klerk to call new election, de Klerk quote. Pickup 11th, `One elderly...'
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of whites shouted their support for apartheid and white minority rule today at a mass gathering to challenge the government's mandate to share power with the black majority. ``The so-called `new South Africa' of forced integration which the government is forcing on us gives us no other choice but to defend our rights and our property at all levels of our community,'' Conservative Party leader Andries Treurnicht told the largest pro-apartheid rally since President F.W. de Klerk came to power last year. The Conservative Party had predicted up to 100,000 whites would attend the rally at the Voortrekker Monument, built on a hill overlooking Pretoria to commemorate the pioneering forefathers of the Afrikaners who constitue a majority of South Africa's 5 million whites. Journalists estimated the crowd at between 30,000 and 50,000. Treurnicht has called for a petition campaign to gather 1 million signatures calling for a new white election. He says the governing National Party would lose because white voters were misled in last year's parliamentary voting about the extent and speed of changes de Klerk intended to make. ``It is an unreasonable government which no longer represents the nation, which practices fraudulent politics,'' Treurnicht told the cheering crowd. He said the Conservative Party would try to win constitutionally as long as such a method was possible. But he warned the government: ``Do not force our people to stand in your path and to challenge you to walk over us ... We are serious. There is no boat waiting for us in the harbor.'' The Conservatives hope the signature drive will make de Klerk reconsider his policies, but he cannot be forced to call a new election before 1994. De Klerk has freed from prison African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, legalized the African National Congress and the Communist Party after 30 years of low-level guerrilla war, ended segregation of beaches and hospitals, suspended executions, reduced the influence of the military on national policy, and promised apartheid would be gone within five years. Treurnicht said the Conservative Party has nothing against people of other races who want to live in their own communities and follow their own culture and nationalism. He told the crowd their fight is with the Communists and the ANC, and denounced de Klerk for freeing Mandela from his life sentence for plotting the overthrow of the government. ``The ANC hates the Boer people and the white nation,'' Treurnicht said. ``They demand our land. They reject our right to exist.'' He said Mandela ``proceeds to provoke with his threat of violent struggle, nationalization, sanctions and a rejection of any notion of a people or a nation in his socialist future vision.'' De Klerk returned today from a European tour saying he had achieved success in explaining the new direction away from apartheid and discrimination. ``The new South Africa is already in the process of being born. Nobody can stop it,'' he said. ``Not through mustering of large meetings can anybody stop the process of the new South Africa.'' De Klerk was greeted at Johannesburg's airport by government officials and a multiracial police choir singing a song in Zulu and English. One elderly white man stood on the edge of the 1,000-strong airport crowd which had been bused in to greet de Klerk. The man held up a five-foot white cross and a sign saying, ``God stands up for the whites.'' The Conservatives want to retain white-minority rule in most of South Africa, contending that whites and blacks are incapable of living together because of cultural differences. The Conservatives favor the policy of separate homelands for black tribes and separate neighborhoods and public facilities for different races living in urban areas. The National Party began establishing the policy in law when it came to power in 1948, but government officials now say it is impracticable. Choirs sang hymns and nationalist songs to the accompaniment of organ music and bugle fanfares. About 200 commandos wearing khaki uniforms rode on horseback from central Pretoria to the amphitheater on a hill overlooking the city. Banners on the podium said, ``The white struggle will continue'' and ``The struggle for a free state has begun.'' People wore T-shirts saying, ``I love apartheid,'' with ``love'' represented as a big red heart. One sign at the back of the audience said, ``Hang Mandela.'' Scores of uniformed members of the white supremacist Afrikaner Resistance Movement wore guns and swastika-like symbols on their khaki uniforms. Their leader, Eugene Terreblanche, was not invited to address the rally. Ridiculing Treurnicht's call for 1 million signatures on a petition to force an election, Terreblanche has called for whites to assemble 1 million guns.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Told To Conduct More Tests After `Grave Doubt' Cast on Iowa Verdict
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, Congress called ..., to delete incorrect date. ^LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: The Navy and independent analysts will conduct new tests over the next two weeks in the hopes of determining exactly what caused the explosion aboard the USS Iowa that claimed 47 lives. Congress called for the testing _ and the Navy said it would comply _ in light of congressional findings announced on Friday that lawmakers said ``cast grave doubt'' on the Navy's official conclusion that a troubled sailor probably caused the blast a year ago. Officials of the General Accounting Office told members of the Senate Armed Services Committee on Friday that the Iowa explosion may well have been an accident. The Navy, in a report last September, concluded that gunner's mate Clayton Hartwig probably set off the April 19, 1989, explosion by inserting a chemical detonator between bags of powder. The lawyer representing Hartwig's family said the Navy should pay them the same amount it spent on its first investigation: more than $4 million. ``They ought to give the family at least that much to compensate for the hell they have put them through,'' Kreig Brusnahan said from his Cleveland office. ``I am more convinced than ever that we have a legitimate claim for intentional and negligent infliction of emotion distress against the Navy,'' Brusnahan said. Brusnahan expects to submit a claim to the Navy within 90 days. The Navy will have six months to respond. If the claim is rejected, Brusnahan said he will file with the federal courts. The Navy's chief of naval operations, Adm. Carlisle A.H. Trost, ordered on Friday that Vice Adm. Peter Heckman take over the renewed investigation. Heckman is director of the Navy's Sea Systems Command, which oversees the service's naval weapons and supervises how ships are run and built. Rear Adm. Richard Milligan, who supervised the first Navy inquiry, will not be involved in the new investigation and will instead remain at his post as a budget director in the Navy's planning and programing office. The Navy and the Sandia National Laboratories will cooperate on the new tests, and the Navy pledged on Friday to make the findings of their study public. In its report to Congress, the GAO cited tests conducted by analysts at Sandia that indicated that the Iowa explosion may have been caused by the ``unintentionally high-speed overramming'' of gunpowder bags. This meant the bags might have been rammed too hard and too far into the barrel of one of the ship's 16-inch guns. Congress sought advice from scientists at the Sandia lab in Albuquerque, N.M., because they found fault with the Navy's initial finding that Hartwig was ``most probably'' responsible for the killer blast. The Sandia lab had conducted tests on 8-inch guns which indicated that when an overram occurred with the gunpowder pellets in the bags jumbled from their normal straight-across pattern _ an occurrence that could easily happen, analysts said _ enough friction was produced to cause an explosion. As for the Navy's theory that a saboteur ignited the explosion, Sandia analysts said forms of some of the chemical constituents of the theorized ignitor were ``either commonly used in the turrets or are part of the maritime environment.'' The Navy, in reopening its investigation, ordered a halt to any firing of 16-inch guns aboard the service's four battleships. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said he expected Friday's testimony ``would expose significant shortcomings in the Navy's investigation and would cast grave doubt on the conclusions'' and that ``I believe that the testimony we have heard has done that and more.'' Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, who represents Hartwig's home state, said the Navy blamed the seaman ``because of its inability to find other reasons. That's wrong. The rush to blame Hartwig was flat wrong.'' Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., added: ``The Navy's conclusion is seriously undermined.'' But Sen. John Warner of Virginia, the ranking Republican on the Armed Services Committee, said, ``It's far too early to jump to any conclusions'' about a firing system that has worked tens of thousands of times since World War II. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said he would reserve judgment on the new reports until additional investigations are completed. Navy officials ``did the best job they could. Now there's new evidence, new information that warrants reopening the investigation,'' Cheney said.

DOC.HEAD: DEA Offered Reward to Bring Camarena Slaying Suspect to U.S.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `He apparently...', to CORRECT spelling of Ballesteros.
DOC.TEXT: The government offered a reward to the people who brought a Mexican doctor to the United States to face charges in the slaying of an American drug agent, a prosecutor acknowledged. A U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration spokesman Friday also admitted for the first time that the government made a $20,000 payment about 10 days after Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain was captured in Mexico to face trial in the 1985 slaying of DEA agent Enrique Camarena. A witness at a federal hearing in Los Angeles confirmed the $20,000 payment and said the DEA has paid an additional $6,000 a week in ``expenses'' since April 8 to the Mexicans who abducted the doctor, for a total of $62,000 so far. Another witness, DEA supervisor Hector Berrellez, testified that up to $50,000 was authorized for the capture of Alvarez. He said that DEA Deputy Director Pete Gruden knew of the plan. The seizure of the doctor from his office in Mexico has created a rift between the U.S. and Mexican governments. Mexico has demanded his return, saying his delivery to the United States violated its sovereignty. Alvarez, a Guadalajara gynecologist, was arrested April 3 after being brought to El Paso, Texas, to face charges he administered drugs to Camarena during the kidnapping, torture and murder of the drug agent and his pilot. The lawyer for Alvarez argued vehemently for dismissal of the charges against him. U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie asked for more legal documentation before he makes a ruling. ``This defendant is the third defendant in this case whose presence in this country is the result of forcible removal from his country,'' Rafeedie said. He apparently was referring to Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros, the Honduran drug dealer detained by U.S. agents after being arrested in Honduras and sent to the Dominican Republic, and Rene Martin Verdugo Urquidez, handed over to border patrol agents through a hole in the fence on the U.S.-Mexico border. Assistant U.S. Attorney William Fahey told Rafeedie that capturing a witness in such a fashion was ``not frowned upon'' in U.S. courts and that legal precedent would allow the case against Alvarez to proceed. Rafeedie said he would consider whether the court has ``a supervisory power'' to punish the government for actions even if case law does not make the actions illegal. ``There comes a time when the court has to draw the line on this type of conduct,'' the judge said. DEA spokesman Frank Shults in Washington denied that the government offered a reward or bounty for the people who captured Machain, saying the $20,000 payment was for ``services.'' He said it could have covered such things as rental of the plane that flew Alvarez to El Paso, Texas. But Fahey said: ``Clearly, the evidence is that a reward was offered and that expenses would be reimbursed.'' Former Mexican police officer Antonio Garate Bustamante, who is wanted by the Mexican government, testified he paid $20,000 in DEA money to the people who captured Alvarez, and was continuing to pay their expenses. Garate said he arranged for the doctor to be brought across the border with the approval of DEA officials. He said he found friends who would take on the job without advance payment. ``I told them that no money would be provided up front, and they would have no assistance from the DEA,'' he said. ``Whatever they were doing they were doing on their own.'' Testimony at the trial of three other men in 1988 showed that Camarena was tortured and interrogated by drug lords. Prosecutors maintain that Alvarez gave Camarena drugs to revive him for additional torture before his slaying. The drug lords reportedly were incensed because Camarena's undercover work had led U.S. and Mexican authorities to a desert marijuana plantation, where they seized 10,000 tons of the drug worth billions of dollars.

DOC.HEAD: Minor Complications From Cancer Surgery Afflict Former President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT date to 1985 sted 1975.
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan must cancel a trip to Europe and limit his activities for several weeks because of complications from cancer surgery in 1985, a spokesman said. But Reagan, 79, still plans to fly to San Francisco next month to meet with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev, spokesman Mark Weinberg said Friday. ``Several small adhesions have developed in President Reagan's small intestine, which his physicians believe are a result of his abdominal surgery in 1985,'' Weinberg said. Adhesions often appear after abdominal surgery and are rarely serious, said Zbigniew Petrovich, a specialist in colorectal cancer at the University of Southern California. When a patient has adhesions, the exterior wall of the bowels becomes attached to another part of the bowel, Petrovich said. In extreme cases, he said, surgery is required when the adhesions obstruct the bowel. ``But they are rarely that serious,'' Petrovich said. ``Surgery is not now contemplated. Hospitalization is not now contemplated,'' Weinberg said. ``President Reagan's physicians have advised him to limit his traveling for the next several weeks. Therefore, President and Mrs. Reagan's trip to Europe, planned for next month, will be postponed,'' Weinberg said. ``He is otherwise in excellent health,'' the spokesman said from the Reagan office in Century City. Reagan was seen by a doctor on Friday, but Weinberg didn't discuss any aspect of the visit. Reagan has had several intestinal surgeries in recent years. On July 13, 1985, doctors removed a 2-inch, cancerous polyp and 2 feet of Reagan's intestinal tract. Six months later, Reagan had three small benign polyps removed from his intestine, and six months after that, two small non-cancerous polyps were removed from his colon. Reagan underwent prostate surgery in January 1987. Six months later, two small benign polyps were removed from his colon.

DOC.HEAD: Precede TOKYO
Roh Invites Japanese Emperor To Make First Visit to Korea
LaserPhoto TOK3
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Roh returning home, clarifies Akihito, Kaifu comment, changes byline. Pickup 8th graf pvs, `About 20,000...'
DOC.TEXT: President Roh Tae-woo today said ``no amount of apology can be fully satisfactory'' for Japan's brutal colonization of Korea, but that Japan's expressions of regret are the basis for a new relationship. Roh returned today from a three-day trip to Japan, during which he invited Emperor Akihito to make the first Japanese imperial visit to South Korea. The invitation came after Akihito expressed regret for the colonization of Korea nearly half a century ago, and Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu extended ``honest apologies'' for Korean suffering in the colonial period. Roh, upon his arrival in Seoul, said it was time for the two countries to put the past behind them. ``Even if we may feel that the Japanese apologies do not fully live up to our expectations, we should accept them with magnanimity and generosity, now that Japan has forthrightly admitted its mistakes,'' he said at an airport news conference. During the colonial period, Japan tried to stifle Korean culture by banning Koreans from learning their language and forcing them to adoptJapanese names. Tens of thousands of Koreans were killed after being drafted for the Japanese war efforts. ``I well understand what feelings my fellow countrymen have about what went on between our country and Japan in the past. No amount of apology can be fully satisfactory,'' Roh said. Some Koreans said Japanese measures to clear up current sore points were more important than apologizing for the past. There are unresolved disputes over discrimination against Koreans living in Japan, aid to Koreans who remain displaced after being forcibly removed from their homeland to perform wartime labor for Japan, and assistance to Korean survivors of the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. Roh said he had asked Japan to move forward on these issues and expressed satisfaction with the progress made so far. About 20,000 police had been mobilized in Tokyo to provide security for Roh during his three-day state visit against possible threats from extreme leftist or rightist groups. But no incidents were reported. Roh's visit to Tokyo was only the second by a South Korean head of state since the two countries established diplomatic relations in 1965. Roh's predecessor, Chun Doo-hwan, visited Japan in 1984. Japan and Korea have a long history of enmity and sore points still linger from Japan's 1910-45 colonization of the Korean Peninsula. The centerpiece of Roh's visit was the Thursday night state banquet at which Akihito expressed his ``deepest regret'' for the suffering Koreans endured at Japanese hands. Kaifu offered his ``sincere remorse and honest apologies,'' and said good relations between Japan and Korea are a basis for peace in the region. Roh extended the invitation to Akihito and Empress Michiko to visit South Korea during a short meeting with the emperor today at the Akasaka State Guesthouse, said a palace official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``After your coronation I am sure that you will visit many countries, and I hope that you will consider visiting South Korea also,'' the official quoted Roh as saying. Akihito, who assumed the throne after the death of his father, Emperor Hirohito, will not travel abroad until after his official coronation on Nov. 12. The coronation is traditionally delayed by a year of mourning for the deceased emperor. Akihito would be the first emperor to visit South Korea since its creation after Japan's defeat in World War II. Japanese Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe said Kaifu had also accepted an invitation from Roh to visit South Korea at a mutually convenient time.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Close Unlicensed Day Care Center With 54 Children
DOC.TEXT: Authorities in this District of Columbia suburb say they found 54 children, some in infant car seats and some on benches, in the home of a woman running an unlicensed day care center. Thirteen infants were kept in bedrooms on the first floor of the two-story brick house, Prince Georges County authorities said Friday. Nine of those infants were in child car seats, they said. Older children, up to age 10, were sitting on benches in the basement, authorities said. A teen-ager was watching over the children when Prince Georges County Police and employees of the Maryland Department of Human Resources entered the house on Thursday, authorities said. Despite the number of children present, the 12-room house was described as immaculate. Nannie Marie Pressley, 53, was given a letter ordering her to stop caring for the children in her home, said Ardis Welch, a spokeswoman for the Department of Human Resources. No criminal charges were filed, but Welch said the case had been referred to the state's attorney's office. Roberta Ward of the Department of Human Resources said there was no sign of abuse among the children seen Thursday. Pressley acknowledged in an interview with The Washington Post that she had been caring for children without a license, but no more than 20 on most days, including eight or nine infants. ``Yeah, I know it was wrong,'' Pressley said. ``Sometimes people ask you, `Can I bring my baby over?' and you have to say yes.'' Pressley said there were more children than normal in her home Thursday because she was giving a birthday party. She said she left her daughter in charges while she went out to buy supplies for the party. It is a misdemeanor under Maryland law to operate a day care center without a license. A violation is punishable by a fine up to $500.

DOC.BYLINE: Soviet Leader Balks At Troop Pullout if United Germany in NATO
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD comment by Foreign Minister Shevardnadze, insert 2 grafs after 9th pvs, `Soviet negotiators...' Pickup 10th graf pvs, `Gorbachev did...' TRIMS.
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev says he will keep hundreds of thousands of Soviet troops in eastern Germany and review his policies on European arms control and security negotiations if a united Germany joins NATO. The Soviet president's comments Friday came six days before he discusses German unification with President Bush in Washington. It amounted to a new Kremlin bargaining chip, a message that the West would pay a high price for German membership in the Western military alliance. Gorbachev repeated the Soviet preference that Germany belong to both the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. The Bush administration favors only NATO membership for a united Germany. Gorbachev also suggested Friday that a united Germany could follow France's lead and take part only in NATO political activities. He told a news conference that Western leaders seem to assume a unified Germany would join NATO, but he said the German people should be allowed to decide the issue. He said Moscow was wary of that prospect. ``What should we do then about all the negotiating processes, including the European process, the CSCE process, the Vienna disarmament process? Then we must take a fresh look at whether we should pursue the same policy, whether we should base it on the same approaches,'' Gorbachev said. The superpowers are trying to negotiate reductions in their nuclear and conventional forces and hope to reach agreements during the Washington summit. CSCE refers to the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which deals with military security, economic cooperation and human rights. Soviet negotiators and State Department officials are still trying to wrap up major unsettled issues in a new Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, or START. The aim is to expand on a declaration already ready for Bush and Gorbachev to sign during their May 31-June 3 summit. U.S. officials in Washington said Gorbachev made a similar warning to Secretary of State James A. Baker III during their talks last week in Moscow. A West German newspaper today quoted Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze as saying the Soviets cannot approve NATO membership for a united Germany. He told the paper the Soviet position ``is determined by the realities of our foreign policy interests, by our history and by our public opinion.'' ``I believe that the West must understand this, and that in this question we must be aware of our responsibility to our people,'' he told Welt am Sonntag, which released a text of the interview before its publication Sunday. Gorbachev did not threaten to withdraw from the European negotiating processes and did not specify how the Kremlin's positions in those talks might change. But, referring to wartime treaties, Gorbachev indicated the estimated 380,000 Soviet troops in eastern Germany would become squatters if the new country joins NATO. ``On the basis of those international legal acts, the Soviet Union will remain where it is now with its group of troops,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Arafat Calls For Sweeping U.N. Measures And U.S. Pressure On Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with more Arafat comment, meeting ending, U.S. veto threat, Iranian comment. Pickup 10th graf pvs, `Arab delegations...'
DOC.TEXT: Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat today urged the United States to take a tougher line against Israel in efforts to bring about peace in the Middle East. ``We are running out of patience,'' Arafat told a news conference, referring to the casualty toll in the 29-month-old Palestinian uprising in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The comments by the Palestine Liberation Organization chief came as the United Nations Security Council was winding up a two-day session on the escalating confrontation in the occupied territories. Arafat today renewed the call he made Friday to send a U.N. emergency force into the territories to protect the Arab population. No vote was taken on the issue, and the Security Council meeting was to resume in New York on Tuesday. Arafat also called for the deployment of U.N. observers in the area, a ban on Jewish settlements in the occupied territories, and international sanctions against Israel. Israel opposes the deployment of a permanant U.N. force. A U.S. official said the United States would veto any resolution that called for either a permanent force in the occupied territories or sanctions against Israel. ``There are obviously elements of the (Arafat) speech we don't agree with,'' the official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The United States envoy, Thomas Pickering, did not take the floor at the Geneva meeting. Israel's deputy foreign minister, Benyamin Netanyahu, said he met U.S. representatives today and was ``encouraged'' by their assessment of the debate. ``I found the U.S. position understandable and reasonable,'' he told reporters, without elaborating. By far the most violent attack on Israel during today's debate came from Iran, which pledged to support the ``struggle against the Zionist entity so as to dismantle this source of mischief, instability and aggression.'' Deputy Foreign Minister Hossein Sheikholeslam of Iran told reporters that the Jewish state is ``illegal'' and a ``cancerous tumor.'' Arab delegations called the emergency meeting of the 15-nation Security Council to consider ways to quell a surge of Arab-Israeli clashes in the territories and Israel. The violence followed the killing of seven unarmed Arab workers by an Israeli gunman on Sunday. Arafat challenged Israel's claim that Sunday's killings were the act of an isolated madman, saying: ``The primary responsibility falls on the insanity and derangement of the whole system.'' Since the uprising began in December 1987, 710 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians, 43 Israelis slain by Palestinians, and at least 216 other Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs. Arafat said Palestinians had the ``sacred right'' to continue their uprising until Israel ended its 23-year-old occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, home to 1.7 million Palestinians. Arafat today said the United States, which provides about $3 billion in aid to Israel annually, is shielding the Jewish state from international pressure. He also criticized Washington for restricting the immigration of Soviet Jews to the United States. He said this forced the ``transfer'' of Soviet Jews to Israel instead. ``Does the American citizen accept that in 30 months, 256 Palestinian children have died? In relation to the U.S. population this is the equivalent of 140,000 American children,'' he said. Netanyahu told journalists that casualty figures given by Arafat were at least double the real toll. In Washington on Friday, Secretary of State James A. Baker III stated U.S. opposition to stationing a U.N. observer force in the territories but said the ``idea of the secretary-general sending one of his top aides to take a look at the situation and return is something quite different.'' Asked to appraise Arafat's speech, Baker said he had not read it.

DOC.HEAD: Vatican Envoy Announces Christian Accord But Fighting Continues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Vatican ambassador announcing permanant Aoun-Geagea truce, fighting continues. Pickup 3rd graf pvs, `Syrian troops...'
DOC.TEXT: The Vatican ambassador today announced that Christian leader Gen. Michel Aoun and militia chieftain Samir Geagea have agreed to a permanant truce, but their forces continued to fight. Police said Aoun's troops and Geagea's Lebanese Forces militiamen exchanged sniper fire in east Beirut, killing three people and wounding one. The latest fighting raised the casualty toll to 1,035 killed and 2,770 wounded since the power struggle between the rival warlords broke out Jan. 30. There was no immediate comment from Geagea or Aoun on the declaration of the envoy, Pablo Puente. Many previous cease-fires have failed to last. Puente said at a news conference that in addition to making permanant their 9-day-old truce, the two leaders had agreed to halt propaganda campaigns against each other and to release all prisoners. Also today, the Syrian army intervened to end 15 hours of street battles between rival Shiite Moslem militias that killed five people and wounded 42. In another development, Israeli-backed militiamen killed four Arab guerrillas during a clash today in south Lebanon, the Israeli army command and the guerrillas said. The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine said its fighters attacked to avenge the slayings Sunday of seven Palestinian laborers by an Israeli. The slayings near Tel Aviv caused riots in the occupied lands. Syrian troops armed with automatic weapons and rocket-propelled grenade launchers moved into the south Beirut slum quarters of Hajjaj and Haymadi before dawn to stop the fighting there. The capital's Moslem sectors remained tense, with fighters of the fundamentalist pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the mainstream Syrian-backed Amal movement still on a combat footing. The factions have been battling for dominance of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect, for 2{ years. By police count at least 1,049 people have been killed and 3,136 wounded in that intermittent feud. Most of the 16 Westerners missing in Lebanon are believed held in the south Beirut slums close to the fortified Green Line that slices the capital into Christian and Moslem sectors. The hostages include six Americans. Streets were littered with the burned-out, blackened hulks of dozens of cars set ablaze by rocket-propelled grenades in the fighting. Hundreds of Moslem families used the lull to evacuate the shantytown slums and head for the relative safety of villages in predominantly Shiite south Lebanon, where Hezbollah and Amal frequently clash. Syria is the main power broker in Lebanon. It has 40,000 troops in the country, mainly in Moslem areas, under a 1976 Arab League peacekeeping mandate. In the clash in south Lebanon, Lebanese security sources said the guerrillas ambushed a South Lebanon Army convoy near the town of Shebaa in the eastern sector of the Israeli-occupied border zone. Israel established the 6-to-10-mile-deep zone to curb guerrilla raids into northern Galilee when it withdrew the bulk of its army from south Lebanon in mid-1985, three years after it invaded. The Israeli military also reported four guerrillas killed, and said members of the South Lebanon Army, which is trained and supplied by Israel, suffered no casualties. An army spokesman said the attackers were members of George Habash's Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine. The Popular Front, in a series of communiques issued in Beirut, acknowledged four of its fighters had died and said the attack was to avenge the massacre of seven Palestinian workers near Tel Aviv on Sunday. The Front is made up of Palestinian and leftist groups which regularly attack the Israelis and their militia allies in south Lebanon. Lebanese security sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the guerrillas detonated three remote-control bombs on a road as the convoy passed. It was the heaviest guerrilla raid in the heavily guarded buffer zone in several weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Opera Extravaganza At Football Stadium Canceled, Stadium Official Says
DOC.TEXT: A $7 million production of Giuseppe Verdi's opera ``Aida'' at Giants Stadium has been canceled because of problems in setting up the show, a stadium official said this morning. Producers of the show decided to cancel late Friday ``because of their inability to complete some necessary logistical arrangements for the show,'' said John Samerjan, a spokesman for the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority. The authority operates the stadium. The show was scheduled for performances June 1 and 2. Ken Cherry, a supervisor at Ticketmaster in New York City, said ticket sales had been brisk. ``It was selling out,'' he said. ``There were quite a few tickets sold.'' No one answered the telephone this morning at the offices of the Montreal-based producers, International Opera Festival. The opera extravaganza was to feature a cast of more than a thousand and a five-story replica of a sphinx. The show was first performed in Giza, Egypt, in 1987. Since then, the production has been staged around the world and seen by about 850,000 people. Tickets ranged in price from $35 to $300; Cherry said refunds would be available.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Fails to Win Runoff, New Elections to be Held
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Expands 4th pvs, ``Lawmakers said... to UPDATE with session over, to resume on Monday. Pickup 5th, `In Friday's...'
DOC.TEXT: Populist Boris N. Yeltsin today failed to win a runoff election for the presidency of the Soviet Union's largest republic, and the Russian Congress now must take new nominations. Yeltsin is considered one of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's main rivals, and his failure to win the runoff was a major victory for the Soviet leader. Yeltsin won 503 votes, 28 short of the necessary majority of the 1,060-member congress. His rival, Communist Party functionary Ivan Polozkov, received 497 votes. Lawmakers said Yeltsin, 59, may run again, or that a compromise candidate with better chances of winning a majority may be nominated. The legislators will resume their session on Monday. In Friday's first round of voting by the Russian Congress, Yeltsin won 497 votes, short of the 531 he needed for an absolute majority. The candidate backed by Gorbachev, Russian premier Alexander Vlasov, withdrew from the race Friday after it became clear he lacked Yeltsin's popularity. During his campaign, Yeltsin angered Gorbachev with calls for sovereignty for the Russian republic, which includes Moscow, the seat of national leadership. Russia, by far the largest of the nation's 15 republics, contains more than two-thirds of the country's territory and half the Soviet populace. Gorbachev accused Yeltsin of being anti-socialist and said his plans for Russian autonomy would mean ``the breakup of the Soviet Union.'' Yeltsin pledged Friday that if elected he would defend the republic from Kremlin interference, but also said he would be able to work with Gorbachev. Yeltsin told the Russian Congress of his plans to promote Russian sovereignty, establish a market economy, increase housing and fill stores with consumer goods. He blasted the national government program announced Thursday for a transition to a free-market economy. Yeltsin said he backed an alternative program involving sale of government property, full independence for enterprises, more liberal laws on ownership and foreign loans. Yeltsin is already a member of the national Congress of People's Deputies and a member of the Communist Party Central Committee. Yeltsin, once a Gorbachev protege, has made a remarkable political comeback from disgrace two years ago, when he was ousted from his post as Moscow party chief and ostracized by the Kremlin elite, including Gorbachev. Yeltsin has continued to criticize Gorbachev for what he calls ``halfway reforms.'' Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov appealed to consumers Friday to stop their panic buying of food, triggered by his announcement of plans for sharp price increases, and urged lawmakers to quickly approve economic reforms. Opposition deputies in parliament demanded a no-confidence vote aimed at bringing down Ryzhkov's government, but he got one important voice of support for his program: from Gorbachev himself. ``I'm hoping in the end, after all the debates _ and they won't be simple _ we'll agree that we have to move toward a market. I'm sure of this,'' Gorbachev told a news conference. Ryzhkov's plan, broadcast on national television Thursday, proposes tripling the price of bread and other flour-based products on July and increasing the prices of most other consumer goods in January. It envisions a five-year gradual shift to a government-regulated market economy by freeing most prices, raising taxes, selling off state property, and reducing central control of industry. Announcement of the plan triggered immediate rushes to stores for macaroni and bread, Ryzhkov told reporters at the Kremlin. ``Now this wave for bread and bread products has already rolled through half the country, and it's gotten to Moscow,'' he said. ``I am appealing for restraint and calm,'' said Ryzhkov, looking haggard and with his voice ragged from fatigue. At Food Shop Number One on Gorky Street, a shop assistant, who asked not to be identified, said panic-stricken buyers ``are literally clearing full shelves for hoarding.'' Bread is the staple of the Soviet diet, virtually the only product that's always readily available and remains cheap at about 32 cents a loaf.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING TO RESTORE CYCLE DESIGNATOR
Arafat Calls For Sweeping U.N. Measures And U.S. Pressure On Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with more Arafat comment, meeting ending, U.S. veto threat, Iranian comment. Pickup 10th graf pvs, `Arab delegations...'

The comments by the Palestine Liberation Organization chief came as the United Nations Security Council was winding up a two-day session on the escalating confrontation in the occupied territories. Arafat today renewed the call he made Friday to send a U.N. emergency force into the territories to protect the Arab population. No vote was taken on the issue, and the Security Council meeting was to resume in New York on Tuesday. Arafat also called for the deployment of U.N. observers in the area, a ban on Jewish settlements in the occupied territories, and international sanctions against Israel. Israel opposes the deployment of a permanant U.N. force. A U.S. official said the United States would veto any resolution that called for either a permanent force in the occupied territories or sanctions against Israel. ``There are obviously elements of the (Arafat) speech we don't agree with,'' the official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The United States envoy, Thomas Pickering, did not take the floor at the Geneva meeting. Israel's deputy foreign minister, Benyamin Netanyahu, said he met U.S. representatives today and was ``encouraged'' by their assessment of the debate. ``I found the U.S. position understandable and reasonable,'' he told reporters, without elaborating. By far the most violent attack on Israel during today's debate came from Iran, which pledged to support the ``struggle against the Zionist entity so as to dismantle this source of mischief, instability and aggression.'' Deputy Foreign Minister Hossein Sheikholeslam of Iran told reporters that the Jewish state is ``illegal'' and a ``cancerous tumor.'' Arab delegations called the emergency meeting of the 15-nation Security Council to consider ways to quell a surge of Arab-Israeli clashes in the territories and Israel. The violence followed the killing of seven unarmed Arab workers by an Israeli gunman on Sunday. Arafat challenged Israel's claim that Sunday's killings were the act of an isolated madman, saying: ``The primary responsibility falls on the insanity and derangement of the whole system.'' Since the uprising began in December 1987, 710 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians, 43 Israelis slain by Palestinians, and at least 216 other Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs. Arafat said Palestinians had the ``sacred right'' to continue their uprising until Israel ended its 23-year-old occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, home to 1.7 million Palestinians. Arafat today said the United States, which provides about $3 billion in aid to Israel annually, is shielding the Jewish state from international pressure. He also criticized Washington for restricting the immigration of Soviet Jews to the United States. He said this forced the ``transfer'' of Soviet Jews to Israel instead. ``Does the American citizen accept that in 30 months, 256 Palestinian children have died? In relation to the U.S. population this is the equivalent of 140,000 American children,'' he said. Netanyahu told journalists that casualty figures given by Arafat were at least double the real toll. In Washington on Friday, Secretary of State James A. Baker III stated U.S. opposition to stationing a U.N. observer force in the territories but said the ``idea of the secretary-general sending one of his top aides to take a look at the situation and return is something quite different.'' Asked to appraise Arafat's speech, Baker said he had not read it.
