DOC.HEAD: Moderate Earthquake Shakes Capital, No Injuries or Damage
DOC.TEXT: A moderate earthquake shook the Portuguese capital for a few seconds Saturday but caused no damage or injuries, authorities said. The quake, which registered 4.0 on the Richter scale, was centered 90 miles west of Lisbon in the Atlantic Ocean, according to Lisbon's National Institute for Meteorology and Geophysics. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. Thus a reading of 7.5 reflects an earthquake 10 times stronger than one of 6.5. A quake registering 4 can cause moderate damage in a populated area. Much of Lisbon was destroyed by a powerful earthquake and an ensuing tidal wave and fire in 1755. The city center was rebuilt and has since suffered several less serious quakes.

DOC.HEAD: Small Quake Shakes Central West Germany
DOC.TEXT: A small earthquake shook central West Germany on Saturday, sending worried residents rushing into the streets but causing no damage or injuries, authorities said. The temblor, which shook buildings for up to 10 seconds, registered between 3.5 and 3.6 on the Richter scale of ground motion, said Professor Ludwig Ahorner at the Cologne University seismograph station. The epicenter was probably in the Rhein-Main area, near Frankfurt, he said. Officials said police and fire stations were inundated with telephone calls from people who reported dishes rattling and floors shaking. The quake struck at 1:45 p.m., when stores were crowded with shoppers. Some anxious customers rushed out of stores onto the streets, police said. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. Thus a reading of 7.5 reflects an earthquake 10 times stronger than one of 6.5. A quake of 3.5 can cause slight damage in the local area.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Looks for Links Between Bombing and Earlier Sabotage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 9th graf, `Although Sims ...', with 3 grafs to UPDATE with sources telling Oakland Tribune about evidence found in Bari's car. Picks up 10th graf pvs: `Duke Diedrich...'. Earth First! is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Federal agents are investigating possible links between a car-bomb blast that injured two radical environmentalists accused of carrying the explosives and a recent bombing at a lumber mill. Earth First! activists Darryl Cherney and Judi Bari, who have been waging a campaign to slow logging in Northern California's old-growth forests, strongly denied knowing anything about the pipe bomb that injured them Thursday. Some of their supporters accused police of framing the victims, and about 200 environment activists held a vigil at police headquarters Friday night. The two were put under arrest Friday after police questioned Cherney for several hours. Bari, 40, was under police guard at a hospital where she was in stable condition after surgery for a fractured pelvis, officials said. Cherney, 33, was treated for minor injuries and booked into city jail. Oakland Municipal Court Judge Horace Wheatley raised bail to $100,000 each, based on what he called new information from Oakland police. He declined to elaborate. No charges were immediately filed, but police Lt. Mike Sims said at a news conference, ``The evidence is strong they were transporting this device and that's why they were arrested.'' ``We believe it went off accidentally,'' Sims said. ``Based on our determination of the placement of the device in the car, we believe they should have known it was there.'' Sims declined to be specific about what evidence was found. But The Tribune of Oakland quoted unidentified law enforcement sources today as saying that the bomb, which was located behind the driver's seat, was covered by Bari's guitar case. She placed the case there when she got into the vehicle, the sources said, suggesting that she knew the device was in the car. Finishing nails identical to ones used in the bomb were found elsewhere in the car, and similar nails were found during a search of one of the suspect's home, the sources said. Duct tape and wire resembling that used in the bomb was found in Cherney's van and home and also in Bari's house, they said. Duke Diedrich, spokesman for the FBI in San Francisco, said the bureau planned to send remnants of the pipe bomb to its headquarters for analysis and comparison to remains of a pipe bomb that exploded May 10 outside a lumber mill in Cloverdale, about 80 miles north of San Francisco. That blast caused no injuries and only minor damage. The FBI is also investigating possible links between Friday's explosion and sabotage of Pacific Gas & Electric transmission lines in Santa Cruz County last month that left thousands of residents without power throughout the county. ``We will conduct and have been conducting an investigation throughout Northern California to see if any of the incidents are connected in any way,'' Diedrich said. ``This is going to be a long, involved investigation.'' The bomb in Bari's car exploded on an Oakland street as she and Cherney were driving to a rally in Santa Cruz. The blast blew out the windows and the left rear door, bowed the roof upward and blew open other doors. Bari and Cherney insisted they are victims, not criminals. ``We are demanding ... that the Oakland police department and the FBI seek out this assassin and bring whoever it is to justice immediately,'' Cherney said in an interview from his jail cell. Susan Jordan, an attorney for Bari, said her client blamed the explosion on the timber industry. ``We're not involved in any violence,'' Jordan quoted Bari as saying. The pair were described by friends as dedicated pacifists, instrumental in planning non-violent efforts to halt what they believe is excessive logging of ancient redwood trees in Northern California. Though Earth First! has become known for radical tactics, including driving spikes into trees to damage logging equipment, the group recently announced it was ending the practice. Sims said authorities had used three search warrants to find evidence that led to the arrests. Police Thursday night searched Cherney's van and a Berkeley house occupied by several members of another environmentalist group, Seeds of Peace. On Friday the searched Bari's home near Ukiah. Cherney said he agreed to let police search the van because he feared for his life. Daniel Barron, an Earth First! organizer from San Francisco, said about a dozen anti-logging activists have received anonymous death threats. The arrests prompted Earth First! supporters to criticize police for ``blaming the victim.'' They vowed to continue a 24-hour vigil at Oakland police headquarters until the activists are released. ``I know they didn't blow themselves up,'' said Shannon Marr, a friend who was in a car ahead of Bari's vehicle.

DOC.HEAD: Genscher Stresses Transatlantic Partnership to Graduates
DOC.TEXT: West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher today called for a ``new transatlantic partnership,'' bolstered by a treaty, with the United States and Canada to accompany a more unified Europe in 1992. ``The Atlantic must not grow wider as a result of European unification,'' Genscher told graduates of Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service. Genscher received an honorary doctorate from the university. European unity has raised concerns in this country about the ability of U.S. business to compete with a ``Fortress Europe'' whose internal trade barriers are lowered. The 12-nation European Community plans to create a vast common market by the end of 1992. Leaders are also working on a blueprint for political unity. ``The European Community is becoming a pillar in the transatlantic structure as a result of its progress towards European union and of economic monetary and political union,'' Genscher said. ``We must establish a framework for consultation and action for the new transatlantic partnership. ``Other important European institutions, such as the European Parliament and the Council of Europe, should also seek new forms of dialogue and cooperation with our American partners. I call for a solemn joint declaration on this new transatlantic partnership.'' The European Parliament is the representative body for the European Community. The Council of Europe is a separate representative body. ``This declaration must embrace the political, economic, ecological, technological and cultural aspects of relations linking the United States and Canada with the European Community. This must be followed by a European-American treaty aimed at shaping the future. Both of these must also play a part in overcoming the division of Europe. They must contribute to the formation of the one Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals and pave the way for cooperation between North America and the new democracies in Europe.'' The EC comprises the European Economic Community, known as the Common Market, the European Atomic Energy Commission and the European Coal and Steel Community. Its members are Belgium, Britain, Denmark, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Portugal and Spain.

DOC.NOTE: For Release 12:01 a.m. EDT Sunday; Time set by source.
DOC.HEAD: Incumbents Enjoy Overwhelming Edge in PAC Receipts
With AM-PAC Money-Spending, AM-PAC Money-Donations
DOC.TEXT: Political action committees gave $63.5 million to congressional candidates in the first 15 months of the 1990 election cycle, targeting nearly 90 percent of the special-interest money to incumbents. The 4,517 PACs registered with the Federal Election Commission began April with another $131 million on hand for the final six months of the election year, the FEC said in a study released Saturday. The $63.5 million in candidate contributions by PACs from January 1989 through March 1990 represented a 13 percent increase over the comparable period in the 1987-88 election cycle. Most of the increase came in spending on House races and was partly attributable to the 10 special House elections held to fill vacancies over the past year. All told, PACs raised $219 million and spent $173 million in the 15 months covered by the study. Fund raising was up 2 percent over the last cycle, and spending increased 7 percent. Total spending was nearly three times the amount actually donated to congressional candidates. Total spending includes administrative, staff and new fund-raising costs and in some cases transfers from the national PACs to affiliated state PACs for use in state elections. The study's release comes as the Senate considers campaign-finance legislation containing new limits on PAC activity designed to erode some of the fund-raising edge typically enjoyed by incumbents. The FEC data show PACs not only are spending more on congressional races but incumbents are getting even larger shares of the money. In the 15 months studied, incumbents got $56.4 million from PACs, or 89 percent of PAC candidate donations. Challengers received $3.2 million, or just 5 percent. The rest went to candidates in races without incumbents. In the same 15-month period of the 1987-88 cycle, incumbents got 88 percent of PAC donations to candidates and challengers received 6.5 percent. Two years earlier, the edge was 85 percent to 7 percent in favor of incumbents. ``What this shows is that we need public financing of elections,'' said Joan Claybrook, the head of the public-interest lobby Public Citizen. ``PAC contributions from special interests which want legislation enacted should not determine who gets elected to Congress.'' Democrats, largely because of their majorities in both chambers of Congress, received more PAC money. This year's Democratic Senate candidates received $10.3 million from PACs through the end of March, with $9.5 million of that total going to incumbent senators facing re-election. GOP Senate candidates got $9.5 million from PACs over the same period, of which $7 million went to incumbents. In House races, PACs gave $30.1 million to Democratic candidates, $28 million of it to incumbents. Republican candidates received $13.3 million, with all but $240,000 going to incumbents. The PACs also reported contributing $10.3 million to national, state and local political party organizations. Twenty-nine PACs reported raising at least $1 million over the 15 months, and nine of them raised at least $2 million. Twenty-three PACs spent more than $1 million in the study period; three topped $2 million. Topping the fund-raising list was the Teamsters union PAC, which reported raising $6.7 million in the 15-month period. The Teamsters PAC also was first in spending, at $4.6 million, and in the $4.9 million it had on hand as of March 31. Another labor PAC, that of the Letter Carriers union, narrowly eclipsed the Teamsters in donations to candidates, with contributions totaling $884,600 in the study period, $2,000 more than the Teamsters' group. American Telephone & Telegraph's PAC was the leading corporate PAC, with $1.8 million in receipts; disbursements, $1.7 million; and contributions to candidates, $829,000. Leading the trade- and health-organization PACs in fund raising and overall spending was the American Medical Association PAC, which collected $4.1 million in the 15-month period and spent $2.1 million. But in that same category, the Realtors PAC gave the most to candidates, reporting $789,000 in contributions compared with the AMA PAC's $542,037. The Realtors group was second to the AMA in fund raising in this category, collecting $3.2 million in the 15-month period.

DOC.HEAD: Race for Democratic Nomination a Free-for-All
DOC.TEXT: The three-way fight for Iowa's Democratic gubernatorial nomination began as a battle over abortion but has ranged far afield in a free-for-all that has Iowans wondering what comes next. The heat got so intense at one point that state party Chairman John Roehrick told two contenders to ``cool it'' and ``keep their eyes on the prize'' _ two-term Republican Gov. Terry Branstad. With the June 5 primary just around the corner, the Democratic race remains too close to call. The fight is between state House Speaker Don Avenson, state Attorney General Tom Miller and former banker John Chrystal, all hoping to oppose Branstad in November. Some argue the pressure is higher because the state features the first-in-the-nation precinct caucuses. That brings more attention to the state even in non-presidential years, Avenson said. ``The significance of Iowa goes beyond our small population,'' he said. ``We're the first-in-the-nation caucus state, we're the state that many people in this country listen to for direction in terms of Democratic politics.'' Because of that, activists on the abortion issue have gotten involved. Kate Michelman, head of the National Abortion Rights Action League, said the group would target Miller and Branstad, both of whom are pro-life, for defeat. Michelman previewed television ads the group had prepared, and said she planned a $250,000 campaign. That was derailed, however, when only one television station in the state would carry the commercials. NARAL's Iowa affiliate endorsed Avenson, angering Chrystal, who pointed to his 25 years of financial support for Planned Parenthood and abortion rights. But Avenson also snared endorsements from other feminist groups, including the National Organization for Women. The groups believe Avenson has the best chance of beating Miller, and they don't want to split the pro-choice vote. ``Iowa Democrats won't let these would-be kingmakers tell them how to vote,'' snapped Chrystal. ``You have to wonder why Don Avenson would accept support from a group that is narrow, negative and not interested in the future of Iowa,'' Miller echoed. The campaign has featured twists on other issues as well. Avenson is a large man who concedes he's as much as 40 pounds overweight. In 1985 he suffered a heart attack, and he was hospitalized for two days last week for emergency procedures to clear a blocked artery in his heart. Some activists believe voters will be nervous about Avenson's health, but others look for a sympathy vote. Avenson said his quick recovery demonstrates his general good health. ``It makes Miller and Chrystal understand they're dealing with steel wrap and rawhide here, not just a normal person,'' said Avenson, who took time out to admonish reporters on their smoking habits and weight. For his part, Miller has sought to deflect attention from abortion by stressing tough anti-crime stands. Television ads brag he's ``convicted 135 murderers'' and underscore his proposal to halve the blood-alcohol level needed for a drunken driving conviction. Avenson charges that would make criminals out of people who drink two cans of beer and says it's ``insane.'' Miller accused Avenson of being ``on the side of the drunk driver.'' That's when Roehrick told the candidates to keep their eyes on Branstad. Many label Chrystal a dark horse, but he's well connected and has raised far more money than the other Democrats. He has reported raising $524,000 to Miller's $339,000 and Avenson's $294,000. Branstad dwarfs them all with $2.4 million. Chrystal also will get attention in the closing days of the campaign courtesy of the summit between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. Chrystal, an acquaintance of Gorbachev, has been invited to Washington during the May 31-June 3 summit and will lead a delegation of farm experts to Minneapolis to meet with Soviet officials when Gorbachev stops there. That comes just before the June 5 primary. Complicating the issue is a big block of undecided voters, ranging as high as 40 percent in some surveys. Avenson said that's because Iowa voters are sophisticated after having been exposed to presidential contenders for 20 years. ``Iowans make their decisions very, very late,'' said Avenson.

DOC.HEAD: National Gallery Opens Show of Edvard Munch's Troubling Prints
DOC.TEXT: The tormented inner life of Norwegian artist Edvard Munch, who once said that ``my pictures are my diaries,'' is laid bare in a new exhibition of his prints opening Sunday at the National Gallery of Art. The show's 94 prints were assembled from the holdings of Sarah and Lionel Epstein of Washington, D.C., who plan eventually to give their entire collection of about 200 Munch woodcuts, lithographs and other graphic works to the National Gallery. Gallery officials say the Epsteins, who began collecting his prints in 1961, have the largest and finest collection of Munch's graphic works outside Europe. To mark the show's opening, the Epsteins gave the gallery two of the prints on display. They are ``The Kiss,'' a color woodcut made in 1902, and ``Madonna,'' a color woodcut combined with lithograph made in the same year which presents an ambiguous image of religious or sexual ecstasy. The prints reveal the turbulent feelings of anger, jealousy, loneliness, anxiety, fear and sexual desire that haunted Munch for much of his life. His recurring artistic themes, such as sick children and estranged couples, reflected his own romantic conflicts and the traumatic deaths of his parents and siblings. Senior curator Andrew Robison said Munch, like his contemporary Sigmund Freud, ``portrays the life of his inner self, his emotions and dreams.'' Munch's approach to life through his art and innovative print techniques was highly influential among German expressionists. Gallery director J. Carter Brown called Munch, who died in 1944, ``one of the great talents of modern Western civilization.'' The exhibition, titled ``Edvard Munch: Master Prints from the Epstein Family Collection,'' will appear at the National Gallery through Sept. 3. It will travel to Honolulu, Los Angeles, Miami, Indianapolis, Kansas City, Mo., Atlanta and Memphis, Tenn., through January 1992. The exhibition is underwritten by Statoil, the Norwegian national oil company.

DOC.HEAD: From Ice Cream Parlor To Quilt Shop, Old Cabooses Find New Homes
DOC.TEXT: On a siding near an interstate highway, the old cabooses sit out of service, but they're far from the end of their line. Already, many of these railroad relics have been cleaned, painted and moved across the country to serve as quilt shops, ice cream parlors, storage buildings and motel rooms. ``The railroads don't make them anymore,'' says Don Flynn, a Danville businessman who has just five of his original 26-caboose fleet left at the siding visible from Interstate 74. Flynn, who operates Prairie States Warehouse, has the cabooses lined up outside his business with a telephone number and ``For Sale'' sign displayed for passing motorists. The collection caught the eye of James Friedlander of Freeport, Maine. ``Last year, in the dead of winter, we were driving by Prairie States and saw four or five cabooses parked on the tracks along the interstate,'' Friedlander said. ``They gave us the keys and said to pick the one we wanted.'' Friedlander selected his favorite, paid Flynn $3,500 for it, and shipped it to Freeport for an additional $2,000. A crane lifted the caboose from the track and took it to Friedlander's 15-room bed-and-breakfast home. He and his wife planned to use the caboose for another sleeping room. ``Instead, we use it for an office and for storage,'' said Friedlander. Flynn acquired the 26 cabooses in 1982 after the death of the Danville businessman who owned them. ``We had the tracks out here and so we just brought the cabooses he owned out here and tried to sell them,'' said Flynn. The first 14 went for $2,500 each. The price has risen to $4,500. Each caboose is 40 feet long, 13 feet wide and 16 feet high, and weighs 30 tons. They have toilets and heating stoves that were used by the railroad crewmen who once rode in them. Railroads have been phasing out cabooses, which once were the last cars on freight trains. Flynn said that when the last five cabooses are gone he probably will have no more to sell. ``They're getting harder and harder to come by,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Burma Elections at a Glance
With AM-Burma
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts and figures about Burma's national election, to be held Sunday.

AT STAKE _ The first multiparty elections in Burma since 1960 are for 492 seats in a parliament that will draft a new constitution. Once this is done, the ruling military has promised to step down from power.

VOTING _ There are nearly 21 million eligible voters, including 2.6 million in Rangoon, the capital. All citizens 18 years old and above can vote. A complete election tally will not be available for up to three weeks.

SUPERVISION _ Some groups have charged the election will be rigged; the military maintains it will be fair and free. An election commission says ballots will be counted at each of the 18,190 polling stations with candidates' representatives present. Foreign monitoring will be minimal. Several human rights and legal groups asked to observe the election but have not received visas. Rangoon has allowed more than 60 American, Asian and European journalists into the country, which has been virtually off-limits to the foreign press since mid-1989.

MAIN PARTIES AND CANDIDATES _ Contesting the election are 2,296 candidates from 93 parties along with 87 independents. The National Unity Party, fielding 490 candidates, is widely believed to have military backing. The best organized and financed, it is the least popular: under the name of the Burma Socialist Program Party it led Burma to economic ruin during a quarter-century of one-party rule. The National League for Democracy, fielding 448 candidates, is the strongest of the pro-democracy parties, although its two key leaders _ Aung San Suu Kyi and Tin Oo _ have been barred from participating in the elections. Other parties which stand to make a showing are the League for Democracy and Peace, backed by onetime Prime Minister Nu; the Union Nationals Democracy Party of Aung Gyi; Thu Wai's Democracy Party and the Democratic Front for National Reconstruction headed by onetime leftist leader Chit Maung.

ISSUES _ Pro-democracy parties are hoping to return to a liberal multiparty government, abolished by the military in 1962. The National Unity Party stands for conservatism and the status quo. Parties have been vague on specific political and economic issues. Criticism of the military was forbidden during campaigning and discussion of other topics was restricted as well.

DOC.HEAD: Crew Rescued From Leaking Ship in Indian Ocean
DOC.TEXT: The crew of a Chinese tanker whose hull cracked in a storm gave up a three-day struggle to save the leaking vessel on Saturday and was rescued by another ship in the Indian Ocean. The Australian Federal Sea Safety Center reported all 38 crewmen aboard the Tao Yuan Hai had been transferred to the Japanese gas tanker Kakuko Maru. The Tao Yuan Hai first reported it was in trouble on Wednesday after its hull cracked in rough weather 2,000 miles southwest of Perth. The ship headed north in search of calmer waters but continued taking on water in conditions Australian authorities described as atrocious. The 122,000-ton ship was hauling a load of iron ore from Venezuela to Wollongong, 50 miles south of Sydney. A salvage tug, the Smit Rotterdam, was steaming toward the Tao Yuan Hai and was expected to reach the ship on Tuesday, the Sea Safety Center said.

DOC.NOTE: For Release at 6:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.HEAD: Rights Group Says El Salvadoran Rebels Executing Civilians
DOC.TEXT: Leftist rebels in El Salvador have flagrantly violated international law by executing hundreds of civilians over the years without proper judicial procedures, a human rights group said Saturday. Americas Watch, a privately funded group based in New York, said in a report the FMLN rebels should immediately halt trials of suspected war criminals until the insurgents can prove the proceedings comply with international standards. It also called on the insurgents to renounce the use of the death penalty to punish offenses related to the civil war. The report said the rebels are bound by the terms of Geneva Convention rules which provide for the protection of victims of civil conflicts. Specifically, the study accused the insurgents in some instances of carrying out assassination-style executions of government officials, members of civil defense groups and others said to be government informers or collaborators. They cited El Salvador's attorney general, Roberto Garcia Alvarado, as being the victim of an ``extrajudicial slaying'' a year ago. In other instances, the report said the victims were given the death penalty after being subjected to a flawed judicial proceedings in areas controlled by the rebels. The Salvadoran military has been widely accused of promoting or engaging in extrajudicial slayings over the years, and Americas Watch has highlighted these abuses in previous reports. But the report released Saturday, titled ``Violations of Fair Trial Guarantees by the FMLN's Ad Hoc Courts,'' focuses on rebel excesses. In response, FMLN spokesmen said death sentences for enemy collaborators normally are preceded by an investigation whose results are judged by an impartial civilian tribunal. The rebel spokesmen cited by Americas Watch acknowledged that conditions for a fair trial are not always ideal in rebel-controlled territory. In some zones, the spokesmen have noted, there is not a single person who qualifies as a defense attorney. But Americas Watch rejected the FMLN arguments, asserting that the rebels have given the authority to impose the death penalty to persons with no legal training. It called this practice ``appallingly indecent.'' The report also denounced as a ``serious flaw'' the FMLN decision to withhold the identities of the members of its courts. The insurgents have said confidentiality is necessary to protect these persons from reprisals. As for the rebel practice of selecting the counsel for the accused, the report said, ``This makes a farce of any defense the rebels assert is provided to the accused.'' The FMLN has in public statements said it is attempting to ensure compliance with the Geneva Convention in its judicial proceedings. Rebel spokesmen also have acknowledged that the FMLN is ``normally severe'' with those who are discovered to be engaging in spy activities for the government. ``It finds itself forced to be so because the government forces, with the support of American advisors, have increased their efforts to create intelligence networks which ... are aimed at discovering where the strategic command posts of the FMLN are in order to annihilate them,'' the FMLN has said. The conflict between the rebels and the U.S.-backed Salvadoran government is believed to have claimed more than 70,000 lives since it began more than 10 years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Dutch Police Battle Squatters, Arrest Seven
DOC.TEXT: Squatters protesting a court order evicting them from an office building hurled bricks at police, set fire to a bar and a lawyer's office, and lit bonfires in the streets on Saturday. Police fired tear gas to disperse the crowd and arrested seven squatters, but the rest withdrew into their heavily barricaded building in the northern city. Police surrounded the building, television said. No injuries were reported in the early morning clash, and it was not immediately clear how many police and squatters were involved. The squatters, who have been ordered to leave the Wolters-Noordhof office complex by Monday, tossed the furniture of the bar and lawyer's office into the street before setting them ablaze, the television report said.

DOC.HEAD: Military Team Investigates Air Force Jet Crash That Killed Two
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 7th graf, `Air Force ...', to UPDATE with pilot's ID.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX32 of May 25
DOC.TEXT: Investigators picked up the pieces of an Air Force jet and tried to determine why the plane crashed, plowing a fiery path through a residential neighborhood. The pilot and a woman on the ground were killed. The F16-A, on an approved training route, had just flown low over a public school with more than 1,000 students when it went down Friday morning in rural south Georgia, witnesses said. It was the second time since November that a military jet crashed in Georgia and killed civilians on the ground. ``My first thought was, `They're bombing us,''' said Vance Taft, whose farm abuts the crash site two miles north of Pearson. Taft and his wife, Lucy, watched in horror as the plane destroyed two houses and continued across a highway, shearing a pine tree in half, turning sideways and shattering to pieces. Killed in the crash were the pilot and a woman identified by the Atkinson County Sheriff's Department as Marian Lanier, in her mid-50s, who worked each Friday as a housekeeper in one of the leveled homes. Air Force officials today identified the pilot as Maj. Archie E. Stuart, 39, of New Castle, Pa. An 18-year Air Force veteran, Stuart was chief of operations plans for the 347th Tactical Fighter Wing. He was assigned to Moody in October 1988. The F-16A ``Fighting Falcon'' was on a training flight from Moody Air Force Base, about 40 miles away near Valdosta, to Lake George Weapons Range in Florida when it crashed, Moody officials said. The pilot was the only person on board, they said. A 50-member team from Moody searched the woods near the damaged houses, putting remains of the plane into black plastic bags. An Air Force board was formed to investigate the crash. The board's interim president, Col. Stu Mosbey, estimated it would take 30 days to determine the cause of the crash. The plane, which General Dynamics Corp. said cost about $9 million, was carrying 20mm practice bullets _ including some that apparently caught fire after the crash _ six practice bombs and a practice unarmed Sidewinder missile, Mosbey said. He said all the items were recovered within the crash area. The jet was in a ``two-ship formation'' with another F-16A when it went down, said Air Force Master Sgt. Pat Miller. Mosbey said jets from the base routinely make low-level training flights at altitudes of no more than 500 feet. The training route used by the two pilots Friday is approved by the Federal Aviation Administration, a Moody spokesman said. The jets had just passed over a public school when the one went down. ``We see the planes flying low over the school all of the time, but these two were flying lower than usual,'' said Michele McKinnon, a teacher at the county's elementary and high school complex, where more than 1,000 students were startled by the explosion. ``We ran around to the front of the school and we could see the smoke coming from where the plane crashed,'' she said. The plane itself did not burn, but flames from a fuel tank that tore away from the jet and exploded quickly engulfed the single-story house where Mrs. Lanier was working, City Fire Chief Henry Vickers said. The house and a mobile home behind it were destroyed, and at least seven other homes were damaged by debris, authorities said. In November, a Navy jet crashed into an apartment complex north of Atlanta and burst into flames, killing two residents of the complex and seriously wounding the pilot. The fighter was trying to land at Dobbins Air Force Base when it crashed in suburban Smyrna.

DOC.HEAD: Man Convicted of Abusing, Then Killing 12 Children
DOC.TEXT: A man who admitted molesting and killing 12 children over a four-year period and hiding some of the bodies in abandoned wells has been convicted of murder and sentenced to hang. The man's arrest in December and his conviction Thursday ended a traumatic time for the nation, where the string of child killings was unprecedented. The victims, nine boys and three girls, were between 9 and 13 years old. Many of the victims' parents demanded a public hanging. The killer, 45-year-old Naceur Ben Allala Damergi, admitted the crimes and showed investigators where the victims' bodies were hidden, mostly in pastures and unused wells. No death sentence has been carried out in Tunisia for two years.

DOC.HEAD: Libyan Leader Pays Surprise Visit to Damascus
DOC.TEXT: Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi flew to the Syrian capital Damascus on an unannounced visit Saturday, the Kuwait News Agency reported. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, said Gadhafi immediately went into a meeting with Syrian President Hafez Assad. Quoting unnamed sources, it reported that Gadhafi was trying to persuade Assad to attend the Arab summit scheduled to start Monday in Baghdad, Iraq. Assad, a bitter foe of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, has refused to attend the summit called to deal with the influx of Soviet Jews into Israel and occupied Arab territories. The summit also was to address an alleged Western media and diplomatic campaign against Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Candid Camera: Police Use Videos to Snare Drunken Drivers
LaserPhoto HF3
DOC.TEXT: Michael Creamer could produce a show called ``America's Most Inebriated Videos,'' but the veteran policeman is just glad to show the videotapes in court to convict drunken drivers. During nearly three decades as an officer, Creamer has arrested scores of drivers who couldn't walk a straight line or recite the alphabet, only to see them acquitted once they got to court looking sober and respectable. But thanks to one of the nation's insurance giants, he and other law enforcement agents across the nation have been turning on video cameras to capture on tape the evidence of drunken driving: swerving cars, slurred speech, wobbly steps. ``With the video cameras, you have a pretty clear case,'' said Creamer, chief deputy in the Franklin County Sheriff's Department in Columbus, Ohio. ``The tape says it all.'' Hartford-based Aetna Life & Casualty has donated more than 300 video cameras to 19 police departments in 10 states under a program it began last year with Mothers Against Drunk Driving. So far, results have been impressive. Creamer's department has a perfect conviction rate: All 27 drivers whose videotaped arrests have made it to court have pleaded guilty. In Tampa, Fla., where police have used cameras for almost a year, 36 out of 37 cases that went to court have resulted in a conviction _ most through guilty pleas entered after defendants and defense attorneys watched the tapes. ``It's just indisputable evidence,'' said Jimmy Stallings, a deputy chief in the Tampa Police Department. ``Once the defense attorney sees what their client looks like at that particular point in time ... it's very obvious, it's not even close. ``Many times, you've got a person who says they had two drinks, and they're falling down drunk'' on the videotape. Aetna concedes that its move is just good business as well as being philanthropic. The company estimates it paid $250 million in claims from drunken driving accidents last year. The $300,000 worth of video equipment is a small price to pay to combat what has become a national epidemic, Aetna says. ``The drunken driving problem is a major business problem, in addition to taking a terrible human toll,'' said Aetna spokesman Robert Caruthers. ``That's where these cameras fit in. We believe it has a very strong deterrent effect.'' The Houston Police Department got the first camera in July 1989. Since then, Aetna has donated cameras to police departments in Phoenix; Pittsburgh; Richmond, Va.; Indianapolis; Montgomery, Ala.; Orlando and Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; and Kansas City, Mo. The Colorado Highway Patrol has also received cameras. Hoping to capitalize on the publicity from anti-drunken driving campaigns timed for the Memorial Day holiday, Aetna this month donated another batch of cameras to seven more departments: Austin, El Paso and Dallas-Fort Worth, Texas; Buffalo and Rochester, N.Y.; Cleveland; and Cincinnati. Aetna plans to donate cameras to departments in Connecticut this summer. Officers turn on the dashboard-mounted cameras as soon as they spot somebody they suspect is driving drunk. The videotapes typically show a car weaving across the road, a driver stumbling through his alphabet or wobbling as he tries to walk a straight line, and an officer telling the suspect he is under arrest for drunken driving. Most police departments say they tell drivers they are being videotaped just before the arrest, but officials also acknowledge that have not made it mandatory for officers to warn suspects about the cameras. Videotaping suspects before they are read their rights and without a lawyer present has raised some questions about legality and constitutionality. Loren Siegel, an attorney for the American Civil Liberties Union, said the ACLU is monitoring the program, but has not decided whether to challenge it. ``Although actual testimony isn't being given, videotaping without the presence of an attorney raises the self-incrimination question, and that's a basic part of due process of the law,'' Siegel said. ``One should not be forced to give testimony _ verbal or otherwise _ against oneself.'' Drunken driving arrests in the United States reached an all-time high in 1983 at about 1.92 million, then dropped to about 1.8 million a year since then, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

DOC.HEAD: Santa Barbara Copes With Worst Water Shortage in Statewide Drought
LaserPhoto LA2
With AM-Floods-Future Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Folks in this parched seaside resort, perhaps the driest town in California this summer, cope with drought in their own ways. Some blame the government. Some seek charity. And some pour money on their problems. ``At this point, people are really in a frenzy, and there's a lot of noise about what we should be doing,'' said Tom Rogers, chairman of the Santa Barbara County Board of Supervisors. The water shortage has ``occupied all the politics in the (area) for the past three or four months.'' Unlike the rest of southern California, which brings in outside water in canals and aqueducts, the county and scenic city 100 miles northwest of Los Angeles rely entirely on groundwater and local rainfall. That has to serve the county's 300,000 residents plus 5 million tourists a year. Years of below-normal precipitation have exhausted one reservoir and nearly drained another. The region now faces a 45 percent supply shortfall, forcing the City Council to declare a ``drought emergency'' in February. The council has imposed some drastic measures to foster conservation. Water rates were hiked drastically. Outdoor sprinklers and hosing were banned. Other rationing measures were ordered and three ``drought cops'' were hired to enforce the rules. One customer with a leaky toilet recently complained he was charged $2,725, city officials said. Gardening businesses have dried up. Farmworkers also have lost work, said Josie Mendoza, a case worker at Catholic Charities. Families are unable to pay their water bills and evictions have increased, along with requests for assistance and shelter. But the drought has created opportunities for some entrepreneurs. Steve Bates, 24, delivers water in a 4,000-gallon tanker truck to spray homeowners' trees, yards and shrubs _ for $80 a load and $55 an hour. ``The best way to describe that truck these days is it's like an ice-cream truck,'' said Bates, who gets his water from a private well. ``People are always stopping me while I'm driving down the street.'' Landscaper Walter Barrows offers to make a dying lawn look lush _ by painting it green. A modest front yard costs just $45, he says. Spray-painted turf doesn't look bad from a distance, but underfoot it feels like Iowa corn stalks following harvest. In nearby affluent enclaves, drilling rig operators are busy with orders from residents willing to pay upwards of $20,000 for private wells. County environmental health officials say at least 81 well permits have been issued this year in affluent Montecito, compared with 12 for the same period last year. Since 1975, 3,295 private wells have been drilled throughout the county, according to health officials who monitor well water quality. The drilling has prompted worries that an every-man-for-himself attitude could deplete groundwater. ``Those people who have money can do any dang thing they want,'' said E.R. Masonheimer, 76, a retired construction worker who recalled that just 10,000 people lived in the area when he arrived in 1917. Residents are still buzzing about Harold Simmons, the Dallas-based corporate raider who paid the nearby Montecito Water District $25,504 in surcharges for almost 10 million gallons of water last year at his 23-acre vacation home. Simmons apparently was willing to pay any price, said Henry Muller, a Montecito director. After weeks of wrangling last fall, Simmons drilled his own well for $18,000. For almost 20 years, Santa Barbara city and county officials have used water as a means of controlling growth. If you want to build a house today, you usually have to drill a well, because the towns of Santa Barbara, Montecito and Goleta refuse to issue permits for new water hookups, Muller said. The city of Santa Barbara has clamped down on new construction altogether because of the drought. Local water agencies cannot regulate drilling outside the city because water is a property right under California law. City officials have been considering a number of long-range solutions to modestly supplement existing water supplies. On Tuesday, the City Council is expected to approve initial development of a multimillion-dollar seawater desalinization plant. Other options include shipping water by tanker from the Northwest, arranging water transfers from the state, and drilling more wells. In the meantime, people like 82-year-old Herman Fisher will continue to use rags to wipe dirt off cars returned to Fiesta Car Rental. ``They don't have enough water for all the people,'' he said. ``Of course, you can't blame people for moving here. It's the nicest place in the world.''

DOC.HEAD: Flood Victims Watch Water Recede, but Effects to Continue in 1991
LaserPhoto DN2
DOC.TEXT: The $3 million Highport Marina on Lake Texoma has a restaurant and even an outdoor dance floor, but these days it's more of a scuba divers' haven. Nearly a month after severe flooding began, the marina and other lakeshore properties are still under as much as 10 to 12 feet of water. Record rain in the first days of May, following the wettest spring since 1922, made the man-made lake on the Red River rise to 28 feet above normal, flooding hundreds of properties. Water flowed over the dam's spillway for only the second time since it was built in 1944. Residents of Lake Texoma's 1,200 miles of shoreline in Texas and Oklahoma are among thousands whose lives will be disrupted for months by flooding. On Memorial Day, boaters approaching the sprawling Highport Marina can refuel at a floating gas station and buy food under a tent pitched on a hill overlooking the submerged Pompanos and Puffers restaurants. ``Many months from now, the lake businesses and residents, along with more than 8 million visitors who come to Texoma every year, will still be feeling the flooding's impact,'' said Highport owner C.D. Loe Jr. ``The whole area will have an economic problem through next year, including decreased sales tax revenue.'' Only the rooftops of Loe's two restaurants and a bar can be seen at the lake about six miles north of Pottsboro. Texoma is slowly receding, but at 6 inches a day it will take two months just for water to drain from his development. Flooding on the Red and other rivers also prompted disaster declarations for more than one-third of Arkansas' 75 counties and caused millions of dollars damage to farmland and homes. Farther downstream on the Red, more than 100,000 acres have been flooded in Louisiana. More than 1,000 Oklahomans were affected by flooding and tornadoes, said the Red Cross. Not far south of Lake Texoma, the same storms made the Trinity River flood in the Dallas area. Downstream in southeastern Texas, that river will continue to flood low-lying subdivisions until fall as runoff is slowly released from swollen reservoirs, said David Haun of the Texas Division of Emergency Management in Austin. The upper Trinity River has a normal flow of 7,000 cubic feet per second, said Trinity River Authority spokesman John Jadrosich in Arlington. But for the next few weeks, it will course at nearly three times that rate _ 20,000 cfs. ``That's the point at which the river begins to leave its banks and cause low-level flooding, so that will continue through the end of the summer,'' he said. Texas croplands, many acres of which remain underwater, suffered hundreds of millions of dollars in damage, said Heather Ball, a Texas Department of Agriculture economist in Austin. Downstream at the Trinity River's Lake Livingston Dam, the release of water through the spillway has exceeded 100,000 cfs, five times normal. Below Lake Livingston, several hundred homes were flooded and Jim Mitchum, Liberty County Emergency Management coordinator, said the high water could affect as many as 7,000 residents. Of 24 U.S. Army Corps of Engineers reservoirs on the Red, Trinity and five other river basins, 20 are still storing excess water, said corps spokesman Ron Ruffennach. It will take more than two months to drain the excess from some of them, he said. Although the corps says the system of dams and levees built since the 1940s spared Texas from suffering more than the $500 million worth of losses already estimated, critics said more and better flood control is needed. In Arkansas, Gov. Bill Clinton appointed a task force to examine the corps' release of water from reservoirs along the Red and Arkansas rivers. And the Lake Texoma Association is urging the government to build more dams upstream on the Red and Washita rivers. ``It is obvious that Lake Texoma cannot hold all the water that the watershed can supply,'' said Loe. ``Where are the politicals and why are they not doing something about the problem? If Texoma can't hold the water, why don't we have another lake?''

DOC.HEAD: Communist Official Says Moscow to Review Foreign Military Aid
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union soon will undertake a ``radical review'' of its foreign military assistance programs, a Soviet Communist Party official said Saturday. Andrei S. Grachev, deputy of the international department of the Communist Party Central Committee, told reporters that Moscow is putting less emphasis on its relations with the Third World in light of political changes in Eastern Europe and at home. He indicated that foreign military assistance programs could be readjusted as a result. ``These will be subject to a very radical review in the near future,'' he said. Grachev acted as moderator at the first in a series of meetings between U.S. journalists and Soviet political figures, scholars, writers and others who are in Washington in connection with the U.S.-Soviet summit meeting that begins Thursday. His comments about foreign military assistance were in response to a question about whether Moscow intended to reduce its aid to Cuba and other Third World countries in light of its own domestic economic and political problems. Grachev did not specifically mention Cuba, but his response seemed to indicate that a review of foreign military assistance would include all countries currently receiving such aid. A U.S. Defense Intelligence Agency official told Congress last month that the Soviets already have been cutting back their military aid programs. The value of Soviet military assistance to Third World countries dropped to $17 billion in 1989, about $2 billion below the previous year's figure. Lower shipments to Iraq and other Middle East states accounted for the drop, the DIA official said. Grachev also said that while some parts of the Soviet Union are suffering acute food shortages, Moscow is not looking for emergency assistance from the United States. He said the main thing the United States can do for the Soviet economy is help end the arms race, thereby reducing the burden of Soviet military investment. In describing the context of the coming summit meeting between Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Bush, Grachev said the key factor was that this would be the first superpower summit since the demise of the Cold War. The two men last met in December 1989, a month after the fall of the Berlin Wall. Grachev said the tenor of the emerging new world order ``will depend on the results of the meetings here'' which are expected to focus on arms control, economic relations and the future political and military structure of Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Magellan Goes Through Dress Rehearsal For Venus Maneuvers
With AM-Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: The Magellan spacecraft completed a four-day run-through of the tasks it will perform when it enters Venus' orbit to map that planet later this year, scientists said. The spacecraft, 104 million miles from Earth and 12 million miles from Venus, completed 100 hours of maneuvers, data gathering and communication with ground stations on Earth on Friday afternoon, said Magellan project manager Anthony J. Spear. The spacecraft performed flawlessly, Spear said. Magellan is scheduled to go into orbit around Venus on Aug. 10 to begin a 243-day mission mapping about 90 percent of Earth's sister planet. The spacecraft will look for ancient stream channels, shorelines and other evidence the planet once had oceans. Scientists believe an unchecked greenhouse effect _ in which the carbon dioxide atmosphere trapped solar heat _ raised the planet's temperature until water disappeared. Gravity forces on Venus will be studied by plotting the path of Magellan as it swoops to within 155 miles of the planet's surface, then sweeps out to a high orbit point of 4,977 miles. Magellan was launched from the space shuttle Atlantis on May 4, 1989.

DOC.HEAD: As S&L Losses Mount, Legislators Focus on Justice Department Role
DOC.TEXT: The nation's bill for cleaning up the savings and loan crisis is rising _ along with the temperatures of legislators who accuse the Justice Department of dragging its feet on prosecuting S&L fraud. As the rhetoric heats up, some department officials are hinting that major indictments could come down soon. ``We do have some excellent investigations that we hope will be very productive in the very near future,'' Marvin Collins, the U.S. attorney in Fort Worth, Texas, said last Thursday. Collins declined to elaborate, since the Justice Department's policy is not to discuss pending cases. But there is speculation that indictments could be announced in the coming weeks against S&L high-fliers in Texas, a hotbed of thrift fraud and failure. The Bush administration, meanwhile, has sharply boosted its estimates of how much the government will have to borrow to clean up the savings and loan mess. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady told Congress this past week the borrowing need is between $90 billion and $130 billion. The new assessment came after the administration insisted for more than a year that most of the problem could be resolved with the $50 billion in borrowing authority included in the S&L bailout bill. U.S. taxpayers will have to shell out an astounding $325 billion or so to cover losses to depositors of the federally insured thrifts. Some Democratic legislators, perhaps sensing a potential campaign issue, are becoming more muscular in their approach to the S&L debacle. And some government agencies, such as the Office of Thrift Supervision, seem to be taking a higher profile as well. Timothy Ryan, who became the OTS director in early April, held his first news conference last Wednesday. He outlined a ``broad game plan of enforcement'' under which the OTS and other federal agencies plan to coordinate efforts with the Justice Department to bring perpetrators of S&L fraud to justice. At the White House, President Bush said the worsening thrift crisis ``causes me great concern'' and the first priority of government policy makers is to protect the depositors. The House Banking Committee held a hearing Tuesday and Wednesday on the $1 billion collapse of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, a Denver thrift that counted Bush's son, Neil, among its directors. Committee Chairman Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, said he will ask Attorney General Dick Thornburgh to testify before the panel as it broadens its S&L investigation. Another Democrat on the committee, Rep. Frank Annunzio of Illinois, was more strident. ``We must find out why the Justice Department is so reluctant to investigate savings and loan cases,'' Annunzio told the hearing Wednesday. ``The taxpayers have a half-trillion reasons to want an answer to the question: When are the savings and loan crooks going to jail?'' In fact, some of them already have been put behind bars since Congress passed the S&L bailout bill nine months ago. Twenty-three former thrift officers and roughly the same number of real estate developers, brokers and accountants are serving terms ranging from six months to 30 years for bank fraud, conspiracy and related charges, according to the Justice Department. But Justice still has a backlog of thousands of potential criminal cases under investigation, ranging from simple teller thefts to serious abuses that dragged down thrifts. ``The cases themselves are very difficult to make,'' Justice Department spokesman Doug Tillett said Thursday. ``It's very difficult to prove criminal intent.'' Nearly all of the convictions so far have been in southwest Texas. The department has set up S&L fraud task forces in 27 cities across the country. Tillett said government investigators have to trace ``very complex, usually bogus'' financial transactions, with the result that it takes three to four years on average to build a fraud case. Tillett declined to comment on whether the department planned to announce big indictments soon. He did promise, however, that ``you're going to see prosecutions.'' Concern about the pace of investigations and prosecutions isn't limited to the Democrats on the banking committee. ``It's not a partisan thing at all,'' said a committee staffer on the Republican side, who asked not to be identified by name. ``We're more than prepared to help to get the attorney general up here.'' He was more inclined than the Democrats, however, to give the Justice Department the benefit of the doubt on the foot-dragging issue. ``I would assume that they're doing the best they can,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Roh Urges Koreans to Look to Future, Not Past
LaserPhoto TOK4
DOC.TEXT: President Roh Tae-woo said Saturday that Japan's apologies for its brutal colonial rule might not satisfy all South Koreans, but he urged them to look to the future, not the past. Roh returned from an emotional three-day visit to Japan aimed at beginning a new partnership between the Asian neighbors. At its conclusion, he invited Emperor Akihito to make the first Japanese imperial visit to South Korea. During Roh's visit, Akihito expressed ``deepest regret for the sufferings and pain'' Japan inflicted on Korea during its colonial rule from 1910 to 1945. Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu extended his ``sincere remorse and honest apologies.'' Kaifu's apology was Japan's clearest statement of regret ever over its military past. But Roh acknowledged many South Koreans would be dissatisfied with it. ``I well understand what feelings my fellow countrymen have about what went on between our country and Japan in the past. No amount of apology can be fully satisfactory,'' Roh said at a news conference at Seoul's airport. During much of the colonial period, Koreans were forced to speak Japanese, use Japanese names and worship the late Japanese Emperor Hirohito, Akihito's father. Many Koreans died after being conscripted into Japan's army or in dangerous jobs as laborers in Japan. Before leaving Tokyo on Saturday, Roh said Akihito's words of regret ``were very significant,'' and said the emperor and Kaifu had ``expressed a common awareness about this unfortunate period between our two countries.'' ``With this, I feel that myself and the people of my country feel we can put the unfortunate period of our history behind us,'' Roh said. In Tokyo, about 20,000 police had been mobilized to guard against threats to Roh from both rightist and leftist groups, but no incidents were reported. During a brief visit to Osaka in western Japan on his way home, about 30 leftists demonstrated peacefully against Roh's visit, police said. Roh's visit had sparked far bigger protests in South Korea. Before he left for Japan, radicals and human rights groups demonstrated almost daily, demanding that he cancel his visit. One man slashed his belly with a knife in front of the Japanese Embassy in Seoul in protest. Roh said after his return that he believed Kaifu's and Akihito's statements of regret were sufficient and urged that they be accepted. ``Even if we may feel that the Japanese apologies do not fully live up to our expectations, we should accept them with magnanimity and generosity now that Japan has forthrightly admitted its mistakes, reflected on them and apologized,'' he said. ``With that, I believe we must now forge a new era of neighborliness and friendship,'' he added. Some sore points remain unresolved, including discrimination against Korean residents in Japan and health care for Korean survivors of the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. Roh made clear that he had asked Japan to move forward on those issues, but he said he was satisfied with the progress so far. ``If we are to promote the peace and prosperity of northeast Asia and also usher in an Asian-Pacific age by the 21st century, we should advance friendly cooperation with Japan, our next-door neighbor,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: West German Calls for New U.S.-European Economic Alliance
DOC.TEXT: West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher called Saturday for a new, treaty-based economic partnership between the United States and Europe to ensure that the reduction in political and military tensions is not replaced by wars of trade and technology. ``The Atlantic must not grow wider as a result of European unification,'' Genscher declared. In a commencement address at the Georgetown University School of Foreign Service, Genscher also called for the Soviet Union to become a full partner, through the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, in developing ``a stable European confederation from the Atlantic to the Urals.'' Genscher made no mention of Soviet President Michael S. Gorbachev's warning on Friday that the Soviet Union would keep its troops in eastern Germany and would review its participation in the CSCE process if a reunited Germany is a military _ rather than just political _ member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. But Genscher, who met with his Soviet counterpart, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, in Geneva on Thursday, did affirm his government's determination that ``a united Germany will remain a decisive advocate of the close bonds between Europe and America, and will remain a member of NATO.'' Genscher's commencement address duplicated, in large measure, a speech he made to the American Society of Newspaper Editors in Washington several weeks earlier, when he called upon the United States and Canada to join members of the European Community ``in a joint declaration heralding a new Atlantic partnership, a declaration encompassing all the political, economic, technological and cultural aspects of our relationship.'' On Saturday, he said such a declaration ``must be followed by a European-American treaty aimed at shaping the future.'' He did not elaborate as to what that might specifically entail, but said ``the right decision to reduce political and military tension must not be replaced by a wrong decision to engage in wars of trade and technology.'' ``National thinking is no longer in line with the new challenges confronting the whole of mankind,'' Genscher said. ``The future belongs to a worldwide domestic policy which must involve a new culture entailing the coexistence of the nations.'' By 1992, trade among the 12 member nations of the EC will be simplified by the lifting of hundreds of tariffs and other trade restrictions. Many American business and political leaders fear this single-market system will unfairly restrict U.S. and non-European trade. Genscher said he was confident that the summit between Presidents Bush and Gorbachev in the week ahead ``will lead to a new, broad-based breakthrough'' on nuclear arms control and than an agreement on conventional troop cuts will be reached by the end of the year. The conventional pact, he said, ``will pave the way for further far-reaching reductions in troops and for the reorganization of all troops in Europe.'' The global challenge now, said Genscher, ``is to ensure the survival of mankind. The vicious circle of poverty, overpopulation and the destruction of the environment has reached new proportions. Life on our planet is being threatened. Now that Europe is achieving peace, now that East and West are bringing their senseless waste of resources on the arms race to an end, mankind's war with nature must also end.''

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Meets With Lab Directors on Short-Range Missile Safety
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney met Saturday with the directors of three national weapons laboratories but made no decision on their request to ground a short-range nuclear missile carried by Air Force planes. The meeting focused on the Short Range Attack Missile-A, or SRAM-A, which are carried aboard B-52, B-1 and FB-111 bombers that are on alert. The laboratory directors fear that a plane will crash or catch on fire by accident and that the flames will spread to the missiles, destroying protective walls and dispersing radioactive material into open air. The directors believe the missiles should be taken out of the air and stored. ``They had a very good discussion. Cheney was briefed first hand by the lab directors, but they reached no decision,'' said Tom Olson, a spokesman for the Energy Department. Defense Department spokeswoman Jan Bodanyi said most of what was discussed at the session was classified. Also at the meeting were Energy Secretary James Watkins and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. The three directors were Albert Narath, president of Sandia National Laboratories in Albuquerque, N.M.; John Nuckolls, director of the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California; and Sigfried Heckler, director of the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico. Their safety concerns about the SRAM-As emerged Wednesday at a hearing held by the Senate Armed Services subcommittee on strategic forces. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., who has an Air Force Base with combat-ready B-52s in his district, telephoned Cheney following the testimony to urge a meeting with the directors. The three laboratories design and test nuclear weapons, but they are manufactured elsewhere. How many of the missiles are currently being flown aboard ``alert'' strategic bombers has not been disclosed.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Says He'll Keep Fighting to Become Russian President ^LaserPhotos MOSB1,2,4
DOC.TEXT: Radical reformer Boris N. Yeltsin failed Saturday to win a majority in balloting for president of Russia, the largest Soviet republic, but said he'll start a new campaign Monday for another election. The Congress of the Russian Federation will take new nominations then, and Yeltsin said he will stick to his platform of transferring economic and political decision-making power from central authorities to the republic _ despite opposition from Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``I am not going to change on matters of principle,'' he said as he strode through the Kremlin grounds after Saturday's runoff election in the parliament. Gorbachev, who holds the posts of Soviet president and general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, accused Yeltsin on Wednesday of being anti-socialist and said his demands for Russian sovereignty would mean ``the breakup of the Soviet Union.'' If Yeltsin ultimately wins Russia's presidential election, the post would give him and his supporters a prominent platform from which to continue their campaign to accelerate Gorbachev's political and economic reforms. Yeltsin pledged Friday to defend the republic from Kremlin interference but also said he could bury personal differences and work with Gorbachev. In Friday's first round of balloting he won 497 votes, forcing a runoff on Saturday. But Yeltsin received 503 votes in the second round, still short of the 531 needed to win. His opponent, Krasnodar Communist Party chief Ivan Polozkov, won 473 votes in the first round and 458 in the second. The Russian Congress is electing the first president of the republic. By far the largest of the Soviet Union's 15 republics, Russia comprises more than two-thirds of the country's territory and is home to half the Soviet populace. Yeltsin told reporters he thought he could swing blocks of votes by agreeing to include various legislators in the government, but he offered no specifics. Noting his gains in the second round, he jokingly told reporters and supporters outside the Great Kremlin Palace that ``I need 531. That means we should go for five rounds, and every round we will add six votes.'' He said he expected Polozkov to withdraw in favor of another Gorbachev supporter, Yuri A. Manayenkov, first secretary of the Communist Party organization in the Lipetsk region, in southern Russia. The first candidate backed by Gorbachev, Russian premier Alexander Vlasov, withdrew from the race Friday after it became clear he lacked Yeltsin's popularity. The race for the Russian presidency marks the latest stage in a remarkable political comeback for Yeltsin, 59, who was ousted as Moscow party chief in 1987 after urging Gorbachev to speed up the reforms. As Yeltsin left the red walls of the ancient Kremlin, he avoided a crowd of several hundred supporters waiting in Red Square. Two women handed him bouquets of flowers. One woman fell to her knees in front of him, but he raised her to her feet and said: ``Please, don't,'' then stepped into a waiting car. The car drove past the adjacent Rossiya Hotel where about 300 more Yeltsin backers chanted his name and the word ``referendum,'' demanding a direct presidential vote. ``This election has been undemocratic,'' said legislator Viktor Aksyuchits, addressing the crowd through a bullhorn. ``We demand that the voice of Russian citizens be heard.'' Olga Yulitova, a doctor, said: ``the people want Yeltsin. But our opinions don't matter. The (Communist Party) apparatus is against him.'' Police looked on but did not interfere with the demonstration. Yeltsin told reporters he believed ``a direct vote for president of Russia ... would be the most objective'' means of settling the race. ``Nominations will take place again on Monday. I think that I will be nominated, and instead of Polozkov, Manayenkov will be nominated,'' Yeltsin said. He urged Gorbachev ``to take a step forward, and come halfway. I am ready to meet him halfway.'' Asked what step he wanted Gorbachev to take, Yeltsin said he should withdraw his criticism. ``At least he should not say the words he said in the hall,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gun Battle Leaves at Least 18 Dead, 200 Wounded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE death toll to 18, sted 12, ambulances begin picking up bodies; Picks up 3rd graf, `The battle ...'
DOC.TEXT: Security forces waged a gun battle Saturday with residents of the city's poorest neighborhood, leaving at least 18 people dead and more than 200 wounded, police and witnesses said. Police and doctors at a local hospital said they expected the death toll to rise as ambulances picked up bodies that lined the narrow streets of the old walled city, a winding congested maze of mud brick houses and shanties. The battle, which lasted for more than two hours, forced authorities to cancel a two-hour curfew break, they said. As security troops cordoned off the area and prepared to conduct house-to-house searches, the fighting spread to other parts of Hyderabad, the second-largest city in southern Sindh Province. According to official count, at least 75 people have been killed and hundreds more wounded since May 15 in ethnic-related violence and indiscriminate shootings in this city of 3 million people. No one has claimed responsibility for the bloodshed. Police blame a militant faction of the Mohajir Qami Movement, a small political party representing descendants of Moslem Indians who immigrated to Pakistan during the 1947 partition of the subcontinent. The movement is demanding recognition as Pakistan's fifth nationality, along with the Punjabis, Pathans, Sindhis and Baluch. Witnesses said Saturday's gun battle erupted as security forces moved into the old city, home to about 100,000 people, searching for weapons. The residents, most of them Mohajirs, apparently thought rival Sindhi nationalists planned to attack and opened fire with automatic weapons, killing two officers and wounding seven others before security forces returned fire, witnesses said. About 2,000 combat-ready paramilitary units, riot police and rangers have patrolled the city to try to contain the violence. Army-supervised curfews have become a way of life. Thousands of security force members swept through Hyderabad and across Sindh on Thursday and Friday and arrested more than 800 suspects. Police said they included members of the Mohajir Qami Movement and Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party. In recent years the province has been the site of constant kidnappings and assassinations. More than 2,000 people have been killed. The worst carnage occurred on Sept. 30 in Hyderabad, when at least 300 people were killed in a massacre that lasted only 23 minutes. Those suspected of organizing the killings have not been arrested, fueling fears that the problem is beyond the government's control. In Karachi, the provincial capital, ethnic strife and political rivalries have turned Pakistan's largest city into a battleground. The main combatants are Ms. Bhutto's supporters and members of the Mohajir Qami Movement. Opposition politicians have accused Ms. Bhutto's 17-month-old government of failing to curb the violence in her home province. She has said the provincial government has not done enough to curb the escalating violence and lawlessness. But she accused neighboring India of stirring up trouble in Sindh and in the eastern province of Punjab. New Delhi blames Pakistan for violent separatist movements in Indian Punjab and Jammu-Kashmir, India's only state that has a Moslem majority.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Says North Koreans Have Identified Remains of GIs
DOC.TEXT: The Defense Department said Saturday the remains of two Korean War soldiers being returned on Monday have been identified by North Korean officials as being from Utah and Pennsylvania. Pentagon spokeswoman Jan Bodanyi noted, however, that the United States would not be certain of the identities of the remains at least until it receives the report of forensics specialists at a Honolulu military laboratory. The North Koreans said May 14 that they would turn over the remains of five Americans who lost their lives in the Korean War, which began in 1950 and finally ended in a truce in 1953. The North Koreans plan to return the remains Monday through a congressional delegation at the village of Panmunjom where truce negotiations were held during the Korean War. The Pentagon said the Koreans identified the remains as those of: _Army 1st Lt. Jack J. Saunders, 27, of Ogden, Utah, who was listed as missing in action on Feb. 13, 1951. The Army believes he died as a prisoner of war the following month. _Army Cpl. Arthur Leo Seaton, 20, listed as missing Feb. 12, 1951. He disappeared near the village of Hoengson, as did Saunders. Bodanyi said the Army has not been able to reach the relatives of Seaton, who lived in Chester, Pa. The Washington Post in Saturday editions quoted Saunders' widow, LaRelle Basoco of San Bernardino, Calif., as saying that ``after 40 years it's a relief.'' ``It seems like it has been up in the air all these years because we've had no body,'' she said. She said she remarried and moved to California about six years after Saunders was listed as missing. ``I used to worry about it a lot after I remarried _ that he would come back and what would I do,'' she said. ``But it's a relief.'' The newspaper quoted her as saying that Saunders ``thought it was dirty over there and he didn't like it.'' ``He was anxious to get back,'' she said. ``He didn't like it. He didn't write too much about what the war was like because he didn't want to worry me.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Actor Don Johnson says he's satisfied after an arbitrator ruled that parts of his house were poorly built and the contractor was ordered to pay damages. ``The people who did the actual work will finally be paid,'' Johnson said after the hearing. The contractor, Duddy-Viele Construction Inc. of Vail, sued Johnson in November after he refused to make a final payment of $95,813 on the $604,085 job. But the settlement requires Duddy-Viele to pay Johnson and subcontractors nearly $112,000, said Johnson's publicist, Elliot Mintz. Johnson earlier had said he was withholding payment because floors and beams in the Woody Creek home were cracked and sagging, plumbing leaked and backed up, and doors and windows were not airtight. A panel of three arbitrators visited the home, and took testimony from Johnson and other witnesses, Mintz said. Johnson's attorney, Robert Shoecraft, said that much of the money Duddy-Viele claimed Johnson owed it was actually money Duddy-Viele owed subcontractors. Duddy-Viele must pay more than $64,000 to subcontractors, and $47,900 to Johnson to compensate him for ``the costs to remedy the defective workmanship,'' said Mintz. Mike Ellis of Duddy-Viele said Friday that no company officials would be available to comment on the settlement until after Memorial Day.

One month after his 84th birthday, Supreme Court Justice William Brennan Jr. says he has no plans to slow down. ``Retirement for me is no consideration,'' the 33-year veteran of the nation's highest court says in the June issue of Irish America Magazine. ``I would not know what to do with myself that would give me what I get and the satisfaction I get here staying on the court.'' Acknowledging he doesn't have ``many more years left,'' Brennan said he's trying to let the American people know exactly how the Supreme Court works. One way of accomplishing that would be televising court sessions, he said. ``I would love it. I'm the only one presently of the nine who would allow television broadcasts of our actual proceedings,'' said Brennan. Nonetheless, he thinks the day is inevitable that Supreme Court sessions will be televised.

A union group has sent a letter to Polish Solidarity leader Lech Walesa, informing him that the award he received last month from Bellarmine College comes from a school that uses non-union labor. ``We view the Bellarmine Award as rank hypocrisy,'' said Jerry Hammond, secretary-treasurer of the Kentucky State Building and Construction Trades Council. Bellarmine recognized the rights of Polish workers, Hammond said, but at home college officials haven't ``practiced what they pretend to preach.'' The letter congratulated Walesa on receiving the award, which is given to those who ``exemplify charity, justice and temperateness in dealing with controversy.'' But it also said the college has awarded multimillion-dollar construction contracts to companies that ``exploit their workers'' by paying wages below union scale and refusing to provide health insurance. College spokesmen said Friday that the school does not discriminate between union and non-union contractors. Bids for construction are awarded based on the ``lowest and best bidder,'' said Bill Lynch, a retired consulting engineer who serves on the college's construction committee.

An American producer and a Soviet director are teaming up in hopes of making international films. Robert Kaplan of Los Angeles is working with Soviet director Vladimir Alenikov, whose film ``The Drayman and the King'' had its first U.S. commercial showing at the Soviet Film Festival, which is running here through Sunday. Kaplan, who helped produce ``A Clockwork Orange'' and ``Papillon'' among other films, wants to produce two movies with Alenikov. ``Our ultimate goal is to get Vladimir into a position of being a true international director,'' he said in a telephone interview from Los Angeles. To that end, the pair is doing pre-production work on a horror film and a love story, both in the United States and the Soviet Union.

Actor Marlon Brando hired a former chief pathologist for New York City to perform an independent autopsy on the man Brando's son is accused of killing, a county coroner official said. Michael Baden, former chief medical examiner of New York, performed the autopsy on Dag Drollet, 26, of Tahiti, coroner's supervisor David Campbell said Friday. The autopsy's results were not released. Baden also reviewed coroner's documents filed in connection with a first-degree murder charge against Christian Brando, 32. Drollet was found shot to death at Marlon Brando's exclusive estate on May 16. ``We wanted someone with impeccable credentials to review the way the coroner's autopsy was conducted,'' said Daniel Stormer, a lawyer for Brando. Baden served as a pathologist for congressional committees investigating the assassinations of President John F. Kennedy and civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. Stormer said Drollet's family had granted permission to perform the second autopsy.
