The defense maintains the shooting was an accident that occurred during an argument over Drollet's treatment of Cheyenne Brando, sister of Christian Brando and daughter of the Oscar-winning actor.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: It will be a busy Sunday in holiday traffic for the Brabham bothers. David Brabahm qualified for Sunday's Monaco Grand Prix. About 6,000 miles away, his older brother Geoff starts in the Indianapolis 500. Their father, Sir Jack Brabham of Australia, won at Monaco in 1959 en route to the first of three Formula One world championships. With David, 27, making the field at Monaco, it will be the first time a son of a world champion starts in a Formula One race. He just barely made the 26-car field, qualifying for the next-to-last spot. He averaged 87.15 mph on the twisting street course, a far cry from 38-year-old brother Geoff's Indy qualifying mark of 216.58 mph in winning a seventh-row position in Indianapolis. Still, David is happy to be racing on Sunday. ``I am absolutely delighted to have made it,'' David said.

DOC.HEAD: Violent Protests Spread in Gabon, Prompting Government Warning
DOC.TEXT: French troops guarded key installations in this oil city Saturday, enforcing a calm after two days of riots and hostage-taking. The capital of Libreville also appeared calm. The riots were triggered by the unexplained death of an opposition leader in a Libreville hotel Wednesday. Opposition supporters burned shops and government buildings in Libreville and Port Gentil. The French consulate in Port Gentil was burned and the consul held hostage for several hours Wednesday. On Thursday, 10 oil company executives were held for most of the day. The hostages were released after French troops arrived, but oil production remained shut down. French authorities insisted Saturday that their goal was to protect French and other expatriate workers, and they would not intervene to protect President Omar Bongo. By Saturday evening, more than 1,300 evacuees _ French, Belgian, Dutch and English _ had been flown to Paris. Meanwhile, results of the autopsy conducted on Joseph Rendambe, secretary-general of the Gabon Progess Party, were still not known. Official sources said Rendjambe might have died as the result of an injection of a liquid whose composition was undetectable. Earlier the government said traces of needle marks had been found on the stomach of Rendjambe, a diabetic. Bongo's government has said it had nothing to do with the death of the opposition leader, whom it described as a patriot. Rendjambe was viewed as a moderate in Gabon political circles, and his party also was held to be among the most moderate of opposition groups. Violence spread to Lambarene, 140 miles southeast of Libreville, on Friday. Protesters attacked a prison, freeing many inmates. Shops and government buildings and vehicles were burned, witnesses said. Violence also was reported in Mouila, 200 miles south of Libreville, according to the witnesses, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Bongo, after visiting several areas badly hit by the rioting, said that if the demonstrations continued he ``would pull out all the stops'' to restore order, news reports said. He did not elaborate. Information Minister Jean-Remy Pendy-Bouyiki appealed on national television for an end to the violence to faciliate the country's move from a one-party state to a democracy. The oil-rich country had suffered a wave of riots in January as opposition groups pressed Bongo to accept opposition parties. The president ultimately agreed to hold a national conference on the issue, and he accepted their recommendation to install a multiparty democracy. The tension eased after the conference, and on Monday the constitution was amended to permit the opposition to contest elections in September.

DOC.HEAD: Quarter Million Dollars Stolen From Teller Machines
DOC.TEXT: Bandits swiped more than $250,000 after breaking into a pair of automatic teller machines at a bank's branch office, police said Saturday. The money was taken from a Chemical Bank branch in Manhattan sometime between closing Friday and Saturday morning, when bank security personnel discovered the break-in, said Chemical spokesman Charles Salmans. ``We're still trying to determine the exact amount that was taken,'' said Salmans. Police Sgt. Ed Burns said more than $250,000 was reported missing. There was no evidence of forced entry at the bank, said Burns. ``The machines are open and the money is gone,'' he said. Chemical Bank has 120 cash machines in the city, and Salmans _ while not providing any figures _ said thefts from the machines are rare.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Won't Tell Family Whereabouts Of Man Missing for 12 Years
DOC.TEXT: Federal officials know the whereabouts of a former police chief who disappeared 12 years ago but, at his instruction, they can't tell his wife and two children. The Social Security Administration informed the family of John Hoyt Kelley on Friday that Kelley is alive but does not want his whereabouts revealed. Despite the distress it causes his family, federal privacy laws require the agency to respect his wishes. ``How do we know he's still alive? They just told us they know,'' said a sobbing Linda Kelley Bardin, Kelley's former wife. ``We don't have any proof he's alive. I can't believe he wouldn't want to let his kids know where he is or even to talk to them.'' Kelley was declared legally dead in 1987 to allow his children to draw $17,363 from three life insurance policies. Ms. Bardin said she received a letter Thursday instructing her to call a Social Security representative in El Dorado. She said she talked to Betty Harper there Friday morning. ``She said `I have some good news,''' Ms. Bardin said. ``I said `He's alive' and she said yes, but he had signed papers saying that he did not want his kids or me to know his whereabouts.'' ``I'm not convinced. They tell me they did it, but I'm not convinced the man they've found is him,'' she said. Ms. Harper, reached by telephone Friday, confirmed that Kelley's former wife had been notified that her ex-husband was alive, but said further details could not be released. Kelley joined the Crossett Police Department in 1964. He divorced his first wife 10 years later and was police chief by the time he met Linda in 1975. He was 34, she was 27. Ms. Bardin recalled that the family was happy, even though Kelley kept secrets about where he went and how he spent his money. She said she has learned he received $17,000 from the sale of his father's estate through 1976 and 1977, but said she had no idea at the time that he received so much money. Then threatening telephone calls began from people insisting Kelley owed them money, Ms. Bardin said. Kelley began disappearing for days at a time. He resigned as police chief in January 1977 and moved the family to Little Rock, where he worked as a salesman. One day in 1978, he got up, helped his children get ready for school, kissed his wife and told her he loved her, dropped the children off at a bus stop and drove away. He never returned.

DOC.HEAD: Neighbor Says Woman Caring for 54 Kids Was Helping Struggling Families
DOC.TEXT: A modern-day Mother Hubbard who allegedly had 54 children in her suburban Maryland home when authorities raided it last week was described Saturday by a neighbor as ``a lot of help to people who couldn't afford'' licensed care. ``She was real particular about the children,'' said Albert H. Abney, 44, who lives two houses down from Nannie Marie Pressley in the Washington suburb of Oxon Hill, Md. Authorities who searched Mrs. Pressley's home on Thursday said a lone teen-ager was keeping watch over the children, ranging from infants to 10-year-olds. Authorities said 13 infants were in bedrooms on the first floor of the two-story house, and nine of those infants were in infant car seats. Authorities said the older children sat on benches in the basement. Mrs. Pressley, 53, was served with a letter telling her to stop caring for children in her home, said Ardis Welch, a spokeswoman for the Maryland Department of Human Resources. The case has been referred to prosecutors, authorities said. But Prince George's County Police Lt. Mark A. Wright said Saturday he had not been asked to help serve any criminal warrants. Ms. Welch said it's a misdemeanor punishable with up to a $500 fine to operate day care from a home without a license. The state limit on home care is six children, she added. Felony charges can be brought if there is evidence of abuse or unsafe conditions, she said. Mrs. Pressley did not immediately return a telephone call seeking comment Saturday. Ms. Welch said the raid was the result of a complaint, since state authorities lack the resources to search for unlicensed home providers. ``The need is too great and the practice is too pervasive,'' she said. Abney said Mrs. Pressley fulfilled such a need. ``She was a lot of help to a lot of people who couldn't afford to pay $50 to $75 a week for day care,'' Abney said. ``Mrs. Pressley would charge people $15 to $20 and maybe a little more.'' Mrs. Pressley often let women get by without paying accumulated bills as high as $400, he said. ``I used to tell her she was crazy for doing that.'' He said a lot of the clients were young, single mothers. ``She couldn't say no to that mother.'' ``I'm not sure I'd know the woman if I'd see her,'' said another neighbor from across the busy, four-lane street. But the neighbor, who asked to remain anonymous, said she was aware that day care was being offered. She said the exterior of the house was maintained ``very nicely.'' Another neighbor who asked that his name not be used, said he noticed more and more ``younger girls'' bringing their children by for help. The neighbor, who has lived near Mrs. Pressley for about eight years and said she has been caring for children that long, added: ``I think people did depend on her. ... If she wasn't that good, she wouldn't be in business that long.'' He said the neighborhood of modestly priced homes was occupied by working people and a large number of retirees. In an interview published in Saturday editions of The Washington Post, Mrs. Pressley acknowledged that she cared for children without a license but usually cared for no more than 20. She said there were so many children because she had been giving a birthday party. She had left the children temporarily with her teen-age daughter when she went to the store for supplies, Mrs. Pressley said. ``Yeah, I know it was wrong,'' Mrs. Pressley said about keeping kids without a license. ``Sometimes people ask you, `Can I bring my baby over?' and you have to say yes.'' Mrs. Pressley told the newspaper the children were in the basement because they had been watching a videotape. The Post described the interior of the house as immaculate and well furnished. Labor Department figures say 57 percent of all women with children under 6 work outside the home, compared with 12 percent in 1950. The Children's Defense Fund, a Washington-based advocacy group, predicts that by 1995 two-thirds of all pre-school children will have working mothers. Ms. Welch said she was unaware of any other instance of finding so many children being cared for in one home.

DOC.HEAD: Full Text of Kidnappers' Statement
With AM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of the statement released Saturday by the Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, as translated from Arabic into English by The Associated Press: As a result of the latest crime committed by Zionism, the foster daughter of America, international changes have emerged in the reactions, which required the organization of Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine to take time in declaring its position until all reactions had been scrutinized. A big storm has been unleashed. Hardly anyone has been left without condemning and declaring profound dismay. A unique global outrage was triggered off, but it was clear that it was only an artificial patronage of our people's security against the executioners and their masters. The bloodletting continued. It was a hollow storm of empty words representing a new method to diffuse the anger of the honest freedom-loving strugglers and manifesting the orchestrated conspiratorial role of the international community against our sacred cause. The Organization of Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine declares that the effective deterrent is force. America is directly responsible for shedding the blood of our people and our cause. America seeks at all costs to retain its base, Israel, in the east and will not permit even verbal resolutions of an adverse nature against Israel. We warn America and Israel that future developments will not be in the interests of either of them. They will realize that the blood will not be wasted. They will pay the price. Lastly, we address warm tribute to our struggling people in Palestine and call for redoubled action and uprising. Have patience for dawn will be coming. Peace upon those who serve justice for the sake of justice. The Organization of Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Nuclear Activists Plot Strategies For Halting Testing
With AM-Soviet-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Grass-roots activists from around the world came together Saturday with songs, shouts and sad stories of radiation damage in Soviet Kazakhstan, and they discussed ways to halt all nuclear testing. ``We're poisoning our air, we're poisoning our soil, we're poisoning our water,'' former bomb-maker Ted Taylor told participants in the four-day conference. The U.S. nuclear physicist said Americans and Soviets are more likely to be killed by the pollution from their own nuclear testing than by an enemy bomb. Although superpower tensions are easing, the activists decided they have virtually no hope of persuading U.S., British and French leaders to stop testing nuclear bombs anytime soon. The United States detonated an underground bomb on Friday. The activists are concentrating instead on Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, said Dr. Bernard Lown, an organizer of the conference and president of International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War. The conference was highlighted by Saturday's festive, multinational rally and a political victory for the hosts, a Kazakh nuclear group called Nevada-Semipalatinsk, named after the U.S. and Soviet test sites. On Wednesday, Kazakhstan's legislature voted unanimously to ask the Soviet government to halt all nuclear explosions at Semipalatinsk, located in the northern steppes of the Central Asian republic. The American delegation to the conference, in contrast, was outraged to learn their government had set off another underground nuclear explosion in Nevada. ``I feel ashamed and angered,'' Lown said. ``This makes no sense. Why are we conducting nuclear tests just a few days before the summit?'' Gorbachev is to meet President Bush in Washington this week, and the superpowers hope to complete an agreement to reduce long-range nuclear weapons by 30 percent to 50 percent. The activists sent a telegram urging the leaders to halt nuclear testing. But no serious discussion of the issue is expected at the summit, Lown said, quoting Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. Conference leaders met with Shevardnadze on Tuesday in Moscow, where he restated the Soviet willingness to stop nuclear testing if the United States does. Bush and Gorbachev are expected to sign protocols on verifying compliance to a 150-kiloton ceiling for nuclear tests. Although a pair of treaties setting the ceiling were signed in the early 1970's, they have never been ratified by the U.S. Senate, and previous American administrations expressed doubt about Soviet compliance. U.S. policy, outlined by an American diplomat in Moscow, is that exploding nuclear bombs under the Nevada desert is necessary for testing safety and new weapons. But the Kazakhs of Central Asia have used Gorbachev's policies of glasnost and democratization to temporarily halt the blasts and pollution they blame for health problems. Semipalatinsk has been silent since October. At the conference, participants saw a graphic documentary film called ``Testing Ground,'' which mixed scenes of deformed local children with film clips of mushroom clouds blasting sheep off the Soviet prairies. Still births have tripled near the test site since 1970, said Dr. Samaim Balmkhanoe, assistant director of the local radiation research institute. Nevada-Semipalatinsk, led by a Kazakh poet named Olzhas Suleimenoz, had won a Soviet government promise to end testing at Semipalatinsk by 1993, but plans to move testing to Novaya Zemlya in the Artic could be delayed. The rally on Saturday appeared to have official support: Giant bilingual banners in English, Russian and Kazakh called for peace and truckloads of pastries were sold from state-run kiosks. But local journalists said their coverage of the conference was being restricted by the state-run media, Suleimenoz said. The government ordered the demonstration moved from a downtown square to a remote stadium where passers-by would not be likely to join in. Turnout was less than 15,000 instead of the expected 50,000. The authorities ``are afraid of public action,'' Suleimenoz said in an interview at Saturday's rally, which ended with the crowd carrying him out of the stadium on their shoulders, chanting his name. ``If they don't show us support, they will lose authority,'' Suleimanoz said. ``Communists, and non-communists alike are united here.''

DOC.HEAD: Panic Buying Prompts Restrictions by Moscow Mayor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `He said ...' to note that restrictions to begin Monday.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Gavriil Popov said Saturday he would temporarily allow only Muscovites to shop in the capital's stores for fear that continued mass panic buying would play into the hands of ``conservative forces.'' The consumer fever began Thursday after Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov announced an economic reform plan that would triple bread prices July 1 and raise prices on most other goods in January. ``As a direct result of the speech, there has been a gigantic explosion of demand for anything that can be bought,'' Popov told a news conference at the Moscow City Council. If Muscovites enraged by empty stores riot, ``that would only profit the conservative forces who are dreaming of provoking mass clashes that could serve as a pretext to bring on measures against perestroika,'' he said. In the past two days, people have bought seven times as much flour and vegetable oil as usual and doubled their purchases of salt, said Yuri Luzhkov, head of the City Council's executive committee. He said a two-week period during which would-be purchasers must show identification with their Moscow addresses would allow time to calm the panic and let city officials work out other measures to cope with heightened demand. The two-week period is to begin Monday. Many other regions of the country began similar residents-only rules months ago, and some have long been on a straight ration system requiring coupons for such basics as meat, cheese and butter. Sugar is rationed throughout the Soviet Union. But Moscow, long the country's showcase, remained relatively rich in goods and even had enough to supply an estimated 1 million out-of-town visitors a day. The sudden rush on the stores ``is a reason for frustration _ we were like the last bastion of a non-administrative economy,'' said Sergei Stankevich, Moscow's deputy mayor. Stankevich and Popov, both members of the opposition group in the Soviet Congress and thus more radical in their thinking than President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, said the Ryzhkov plan and its consequences showed it was time for the government to step down. ``Our government can't think ahead of events,'' Stankevich said. ``This is a real weakness and it's unimaginable that we still have this kind of government.'' Popov said people lacked confidence in the national Supreme Soviet, which has the power to vote down the economic plan but has rarely defied the government. City officials said they expected the residents-only buying plan to provoke conflicts with the regions that surround Moscow _ Vladimir, Yaroslavl and Tula _ whose inhabitants are used to buying many of their supplies in the capital. But they said they would try to work out deals with regional leaders over the next two weeks. Residents of the greater Moscow region will still be able to buy in the city's stores, as will veterans and invalids from elsewhere, Popov said. Moscow's stores have been packed since Thursday with what Stankevich called ``enormous lines of angry people.'' They were trying to buy macaroni, cereals and salt, all usually among the few readily available food products in the shortage-plagued Soviet Union. Lines at some food stores Saturday evening were not longer than usual, and shoppers interviewed at random said they were not buying up extra goods _ although they clearly were dissatisfied with the selection of what food was available. Popov said Moscow had received offers from Lithuania, Estonia and the Crimea to supply it with food, but did not specify whether it would circumvent the Kremlin's ministries and strike deals on its own. Ryzhkov's economic plan proposes a five-year transition to what it calls a market economy still partially regulated by the government. It has drawn criticism from all sides. Lawmakers are angry over its price increases and the expected unemployment it will bring, while Western experts say it doesn't do enough to liquidate central control and introduce a real market. The Supreme Soviet legislature is to continue discussing the plan early next week, and a vote is not expected before Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Feinstein Leads in Race for Democratic Gubernatorial Nomination in Calif.
DOC.TEXT: Former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein leads state Attorney General John Van de Kamp for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination but Republican U.S. Sen. Pete Wilson would beat both, a poll found. A Los Angeles Times survey, published Saturday, showed that 38 percent of registered voters favored Feinstein while 27 percent wanted Van de Kamp. Thirty-five percent of respondents were still undecided on a Democratic nominee in the June 5 primary. The Times polled 1,730 registered voters by telephone between May 17 and May 23. The sample included 854 self-described registered Democrats, 621 people who said they were registered Republicans, 218 independents and 37 members of other parties. Neither top Democrat has picked up significant support since late February, according to the poll. Feinstein jumped ahead of Van de Kamp that month with a television commercial that featured her announcing the assassination of San Francisco Mayor George Moscone. The number of undecided voters also has not changed since February. Of those polled, 42 percent said they would vote for Wilson, compared with 36 percent who said they preferred Feinstein. Another 21 percent were undecided and 1 percent would vote for someone else. In a Van de Kamp-Wilson matchup, 44 percent said they would vote for Wilson and 36 percent for Van de Kamp. Twenty percent were undecided. Feinstein supporters said her ``single most important quality'' is the belief that she ``can get things done,'' the poll said. Van de Kamp's chief attraction for his supporters was his experience, according to the survey. The Times said the poll's margin of error for all registered voters was 3 percent. For Democrats and Republicans only, the margin of error was 5 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Vows Effort to Sell Gorbachev on NATO Role for Germany
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADs with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Bush comments on Germany and summit; picks up 2nd graf pvs, bgng: Bush, who
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Saturday he will try to convince Mikhail Gorbachev there is no threat to the Soviet Union from a united Germany in NATO. However, Bush acknowledged it will be difficult to sell that idea. ``I think it's going to take a while before we have agreement on how a post-German unification Europe looks,'' Bush said. ``My job is to convince him that there is no threat to the Soviet Union from a united Germany in NATO and, I'm absolutely convinced there is no threat to him and I think it's stabilizing,'' Bush said. The president spoke briefly with reporters as he began a round of golf at a local country club. Bush is relaxing here for four days before meeting with the Soviet president in Washington. Gorbachev said Friday that if Germany is allowed to join NATO, the Kremlin will refuse to pull out its troops and might retreat in all negotiations to end the East-West confrontation in Europe. But Bush, asserting that a united Germany should be in NATO, said, ``I think really I can make the case that it is in their interest.'' He acknowledged, however, ``They have a different position than we do right now.'' Bush, who arrived Friday at his oceanside estate, received a morning briefing from Robert Gates, his deputy national security adviser, on developments throughout the world but then moved on quickly to recreation. The weather was perfect for a holiday weekend, with sunny skies and warm temperatures. After a morning tennis game, Bush piloted his boat, Fidelity, into the Atlantic Ocean. Swinging by the shore, he waved to tourists. A group of children, camping on a beach, yelled in unison, ``Hello, Mr. Bush.'' Spending the weekend with Bush and his wife, Barbara, at his Walker's Point compound were Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner and his wife, Honey; Houston friends Charles and Sally Neblett; and Daphney Murray, director of the Institute of Museum Services of Washington. Also staying with the Bushes are their son, Marvin, and his wife, Margaret, and their two children; and their daughter, Dorothy LeBlond, and her two children. As Bush relaxed, his senior advisers were getting ready to set the stage for the summit by appearing Sunday on television talk shows. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and national security adviser Brent Scowcroft were scheduled to appear on network TV programs. Bush was interviewed in Washington on Thursday by a Soviet television journalist for broadcast on Sunday. Gorbachev will return to Washington on Wednesday evening after an overnight stop in Ottawa for talks with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. Bush and Gorbachev will begin their meetings Thursday at the White House. After two days of talks in Washington, the two leaders will go to Camp David on Saturday for more discussions. Their meeting will conclude on Sunday with a morning news conference back at the White House.

DOC.HEAD: Cashier's Lament at Moscow Grocery: `They Are Sweeping Up Everything'
With AM-Soviet-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Cashier Sofia Martikina waved her arms toward the dozens of people jamming a nearby counter to buy sausage and lard. ``It's just outrageous!'' she said. ``They are sweeping up everything. There is no salt or macaroni left.'' At a bakery down the street, Nargiza Nargieva clutched a loaf of brown bread as she spoke of the impending government plan to triple the prices of bakery goods on July 1 and the crush of shoppers back home in Tbilisi, the capital of Soviet Georgia. ``It's been that way for about a week,'' she said of the run on the stores in the Caucasus republic. ``In Georgia, we are very much afraid of bread price increases. ... There is nothing left, neither bread nor cheese.'' Mrs. Nargieva, who on Saturday bought a dress imported from Hungary before heading back to Tbilisi on Monday, seemed genuinely surprised at new, temporary restrictions that would prevent out-of-towners from buying goods in Moscow stores. ``We just can't believe that anything like that _ selling things on passports _ can happen in the Soviet Union,'' she said. ``I can't believe that. It's very bad.'' In reality, some other regions in the country adopted residents-only rules months ago. Moscow's planned restrictions are being put into effect to curb panic-buying that city officials say has been occurring in the capital since an economic reform plan was announced Thursday. Another woman in the bakery who refused to give her name was pleased with the rule in which residents of Moscow would have to show their ``propiska'' _ a stamp in their internal passports _ to shop at the city's stores. ``I'm a Muscovite and I think it's good,'' she said. ``There will be fewer crowds in the shops and we will be able to buy anything without a fuss.'' But Mrs. Martikina, the cashier, wasn't so sure. ``I don't know how I will feel when a woman with a young child comes up to me to buy milk and I have to refuse on the grounds she has no propiska,'' Mrs. Martikina said. ``Does the fact that she's not a Muscovite mean that she has to starve, she and her child? It's just awful.'' Shoppers interviewed at random on a drizzly Saturday evening said they had not done any hoarding of goods themselves and had not seen their neighbors buying extra. Alexandra Sergeyeva, standing in a slow-moving line along with more than 60 other people to buy about 2 pounds of the grayish, wrinkled sausages on sale, said she has not been stocking up on food. ``I don't have any place to store it,'' she said, adding that if she did have extra shelf space, she would be buying more goods. ``Well, anyway, I don't have that much money, but I could afford another kilo,'' she said. The store was limiting shoppers to two kilograms, almost 4{ pounds. ``Yes, I heard that prices will go up,'' Mrs. Sergeyeva said. ``You know, I don't think the country's economy is going to be saved. For ordinary people it's going to be worse. It's not that they will suffer that much, but they will be much poorer.'' Further up the line, Svetlana Kireichnenkova, who has a husband and two children, said the planned price increases are ``going to adversely affect my family.'' Mrs. Kireichnenkova described herself as an out-of-towner and had heard about the new rules for Moscow shoppers, but did not want to speculate about her future. ``I don't really feel up to making forecasts,'' she said. ``We shall live and see.''

DOC.HEAD: TV Station Admits Videotaping Illegal Pit-Bull Fight
DOC.TEXT: Executives at a Denver television station have defended their staff's videotaping of an illegal pit bull fight as ``legitimate news-gathering activities.'' Roger Ogden, general manager of KCNC-TV, on Friday said station employees attended such a fight in September, but they didn't realize at the time that it was illegal. He also said the tape used in reporter Wendy Bergen's four-part series on illegal pit bull fights came from a confidential source. ``We have been told, and we believe, that this video was not the same fight attended by KCNC employees in September,'' the station said in a statement. The station and police agencies began an investigation this month after allegations were made by anonymous sources that KCNC staged a fight between two dogs for Bergen's series. The sources also told competing news organizations the station paid for the fight. KCNC-TV denied the allegations, and Ogden ordered a comprehensive investigation. Police said the fight featured in Bergen's report, which aired April 30 through May 2, occurred on a grassy area near the South Platte River in Sheridan, a Denver suburb. Staging a dogfight or even attending one is a felony in Colorado, punishable by up to four years in prison and $1,000 fine. Police investigations into the incident were completed this week. District attorneys in Arapahoe and Jefferson counties, where the fights reportedly occurred, are looking into who might have been involved. No charges have been filed against station employees or dog owners. KCNC-TV News Director Marv Rockford said no disciplinary action has been taken against any KCNC employee. In a statement released Friday, KCNC defended its actions. ``We believe the subject of pit bulls and pit bull fighting in Colorado was and is a legitimate topic of public concern and interest and is an appropriate journalistic subject,'' the unsigned statement said. ``Last September, in the course of investigating the pit bull issue, KCNC employees attended and videotaped a pit bull fight that took place in Arapahoe County. Attendance and coverage of the fight was in the normal course of the station's activity in gathering the news and preparing the report. The station later learned of the existence of a criminal statute relating to dogfighting. ``We then contacted and met with Robert Gallagher, the district attorney for Arapahoe County, and members of his staff, to discuss whether journalists attending and videotaping a pit bull fight for the purpose of obtaining and reporting the news might be committing a criminal act. ``While they indicated that it was their view that the statute might apply even in that situation, KCNC did not and does not agree with any interpretation of the statute that would make criminal such legitimate news-gathering activities.'' When the Arapahoe County district attorney's office learned of KCNC's statement, it announced that a special prosecutor would be appointed to review the case. But because of the holiday weekend, it will be at least Tuesday before the court appoints a special prosecutor.

DOC.HEAD: Arafat Asks U.S. to Pressure Israel to Move Ahead on Middle East Peace
DOC.TEXT: Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat, apparently sensing a cooling of relations between Washington and Jerusalem, pleaded with the U.S. government Saturday to help along Middle East peace by pressuring Israel. A U.N. Security Council emergency session on the latest violence between Irsaelis and Arabs in the Israeli-occupied lands adjourned and was to resume Tuesday in New York. An Arab diplomat said a council decision could be ``one week, two weeks'' off. Arafat asked the 15-nation council during the two-day session for sweeping U.N. moves to protect Arabs in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. At a news conference Saturday, Arafat criticized the United States for shielding Israel from international pressure and for vetoing critical Security Council resolutions. ``In view of Israeli dependence on U.S. aid, we are expecting the U.S. administration and people to play a more effective role in bringing about peace,'' the Palestine Liberation Organization chief said through an interpreter. Arab League Ambassador Clovis Maksoud said the United States had tried to launch the idea in Geneva of sending an international fact-finding mission to the occupied territories, but backtracked Saturday under Israeli pressure. ``The U.S. had been informally suggesting such a development and in our view flip-flopped on its position,'' Maksoud told reporters. ``It means Israel still has a stranglehold on the decision-making process.'' The U.S. State Department earlier said it was prepared to discuss having the Security Council send a temporary fact-finding mission to the occupied lands. That put Washington publicly at odds with Israel, which said it would bar any observer team. U.S. Ambassador Thomas Pickering suggested a likely move would be dispatching a personal representative of U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to look into the situation in the territories. This has been done before. ``The direction in which we're looking is something that might come from the secretary-general in that regard,'' Pickering said after the meeting. Secretary of State James A. Baker III raised the possibility Friday when he said Washington would not oppose such a mission. Pickering did not speak in the council meeting. Arafat, in an unprecedented speech to the council Friday, appealed for a U.N. emergency force to protect the 1.7 million Arabs in the occupied lands, and he urged sanctions against Israel. A U.S. official made plain Saturday that Washington would veto any council resolution containing those points. ``There are obviously elements of the speech we don't agree with,'' the official said on condition of anonymity. A U.N. emergency team would include representatives of several countries rather than personal representatives of Perez de Cuellar and would presumably mount a wider probe than a special envoy. The Security Council convened at Arab behest after an Israeli gunman killed seven Arab workers on May 20, touching off a surge of violence in the occupied territories that left at least 15 dead. Israeli officials say the man was deranged. Palestinians have been waging an uprising, or intefadeh, for nearly 30 months aimed at ending Israel's 23-year-old occupation of the lands. Since the uprising began in December 1987, 720 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians. An additional 216 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel. Forty-three Israelis have died. The Security Council session was held in Geneva rather than New York City to avoid a showdown over Arafat's visa. The United States has refused him entry in the past.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Warns Travelers on Philippines
DOC.TEXT: The State Department on Saturday warned that Americans traveling in the Philippines face an increased risk of terrorism as the two countries prepare for a new set of negotiations on U.S. military bases in the island nation. ``During this period, Communist elements in the Philippines are likely to expand their current terrorism campaign beyond U.S. officials and active duty U.S. servicemen to include retired personnel and the places they frequent,'' the department said in a statement. American and Philippine negotiators are preparing to resume talks on whether to renew a lease on Clark Air Base, Subic Bay naval base and four smaller installations. The leases expire in September 1991. Opposition to the bases is growing because many Filipinos view them as an infringement on national sovereignty. The State Department said that ``most of the major tourist destinations and most urban areas generally have not experienced the type of civil disorder'' noted in its advisory. But it added: ``Because of criminal activities, travelers should exercise caution at night in the downtown entertainment districts of major cities and should avoid travel to remote mountainous areas.''

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Want Stuart's Attorney to Break Attorney-Client Privilege
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING a0598 to restore overline.
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors want the lawyer of Charles Stuart, who apparently committed suicide after his wife's mysterious shooting death, to break attorney-client privilege, two newspapers reported Saturday. Suffolk County prosecutors are seeking to force lawyer John T. Dawley to tell a grand jury what he knows of the events surrounding the October shooting that left Carol Stuart and her prematurely born son dead. Stuart, who also was shot, originally blamed the attack on a black robber, and summoned police help with a dramatic call from his car telephone. The request to order Dawley to testify came in a closed hearing last month. Appeals Court Judge Edith Fine on Friday ordered the court to release a condensed transcript of the hearing following an appeal by the Boston Herald. Superior Court Judge James Donohue has asked the state's appellate court to rule on the prosecutors' request, the Herald and The Boston Globe reported Saturday. At the closed hearing, Assistant District Attorney Thomas Mundy argued that shortly before Stuart apparently jumped to his death off a bridge five months ago, he told Dawley of his plot to kill his wife. Mundy said Stuart's brother, Matthew, was a potential target of the grand jury's investigation, and indicated that Dawley's testimony could shed light on Matthew Stuart's possible role in the killings. ``The inferences point that he may well have told Dawley exactly what occurred, and that information may be very important to the grand jury's determination as to what inference they wish to draw from Matthew Stuart's purported statements to several witnesses in determining what charges to bring,'' Mundy said in his argument before Donohue. Matthew Stuart told police he thought he was involved in an insurance scam when he drove to the city's Mission Hill section to meet his brother shortly after the shooting. Matthew Stuart allegedly disposed of the gun police believe was used in the shooting, as well as other items he said he believed would later be reported stolen. He also said he did not recognize Mrs. Stuart in his brother's car, but mistook her body for a duffle bag or laundry bag. Mundy said he believed ``the interest of the grand jury in resolving this very serious crime, I would submit in the interest of justice, overrides the privilege'' protecting client-lawyer communications. Nancy Gertner, a lawyer for Matthew Stuart, argued at the hearing that no Massachusetts case law gives precedent for overriding the attorney-client privilege in the interest of justice. ``And in addition, the kind of evidence, even if Mr. Dawley were permitted to testify, would not be admissible in a proceeding likely to come out of this,'' Gertner said.

DOC.HEAD: Rival Christian Forces Agree to Truce in Lebanon, Vatrican Says
DOC.TEXT: A Vatican envoy said Saturday that rival Christian leaders agreed to end their 4-month-old war that has left more than 1,000 people dead, but new sniping reportedly claimed three lives. In south Lebanon, Palestinian guerrillas ambushed a convoy of Israeli-backed militiamen, inflicting an undisclosed number of casualties and losing four of their men, Lebanese security sources reported. An Israeli spokesman said no militiamen were killed. In Lebanon's other factional power struggle, Syrian troops intervened early Saturday to halt 15 hours of street battles in west and south Beirut between rival Shiite Moslem factions. That fighting reportedly left five people dead and 42 wounded. Vatican ambassador Pablo Puente told a news conference that Christian Gen. Michel Aoun and fellow Christian Samir Geagea, a militia chieftain, had agreed that a 9-day-old cease-fire ``will become a permanent truce.'' Puente said the rival leaders made the pledges separately to him and also vowed to release all prisoners. Neither leader provided immediate confirmation. They have been fighting for control of Lebanon's Christian enclave, which comprises east Beirut and nearby coastal communities. Despite Puente's announcement, police said Aoun's troops and Geagea's Lebanese Forces militiamen exchanged intermittent sniper fire in east Beirut, killing three people and wounding one. The latest casualties raised the toll to 1,035 killed and 2,770 wounded since the power struggle broke out Jan. 30. Independent observers doubt the power struggle will end until Aoun and Geagea work out a political settlement and somehow overcome their deep-seated hatred of each other. Aoun controls 19,000 troops. Geagea's militia includes 6,000 core fighters who are backed by about 30,000 reservists. Before agreeing to the cease-fire May 17, the two forces had fought each other to a standstill. Geagea has accused Aoun of trying to destroy his militia. The general charges Geagea with ``plotting against the Christians' interest'' by trying to enforce a peace accord brokered by Arab nations to end Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war between Christians and Moslems. The accord, endorsed by Lebanon's parliament in Saudi Arabia in October, gives Moslems equal power with the traditionally dominant Christians. Aoun rejects that accord, complaining it does not guarantee the withdrawal of 40,000 Syrian troops from Lebanon. They have been deployed since 1976 under an Arab League peacekeeping mandate, and they now control most of Lebanon's territory. In the south Lebanon fighting, the Marxist Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine said in a series of statements from Beirut that its fighters carried out Saturday's attack to avenge the massacre of seven Palestinian workers by an Israeli gunman near Tel Aviv on May 20. Lebanese security sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said a guerrilla force detonated three remote-control bombs on a road inside Israel's self-designated security zone north of the border with the Jewish state as the mostly Christian South Lebanon Army convoy passed. The SLA works in concert with Israeli forces. But an Israeli Army spokesman in Tel Aviv said there were no SLA casualties but reported that the militiamen killed four guerrillas. He made no mention of bombs. The Israeli version indicated that an SLA patrol intercepted an infiltration attempt, not that the militiamen were ambushed. However, a Lebanese source said the SLA convoy of two armored personnel carriers and two jeeps was hit near Shebaa in the eastern sector of the Israeli zone. In the Moslem power struggle, police said the situation remained ``very tense'' after Syrian troops moved in to stop the Beirut fighting. Authorities said the mainstream Syrian-backed Amal movement and the fundamentalist pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, were keeping their fighters on alert. Amal and Hezbollah have been battling sporadically for 2{ years for control of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect. At least 1,049 people have been killed and 3,136 wounded during that time.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Leader Looks to Narrow Differences With Bush Over Germany
DOC.NOTE: For Release at 8 p.m. EDT - time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev says the question of whether a unified Germany should belong to NATO is certain to produce a major disagreement in his coming summit with President Bush, but ``I do expect the differences to be narrowed,'' Time magazine reports. ``I hope the character of the relationship I've developed with the president will permit us to move forward rather than backward in our discussions,'' Gorbachev said in an interview with the magazine Tuesday at his office in Moscow. The transcript of the session appears in the June 4 edition of the magazine. On Friday, Gorbachev told a press conference that the Soviet Union will keep hundreds of thousands of troops in eastern Germany and will review its approach to European arms-control talks if a united Germany joins NATO. The U.S. and West German governments have insisted that membership in the alliance is imperative. President Bush, meanwhile, told reporters Saturday he will try to convince Gorbachev the Soviet Union would not be threatened by a united Germany in NATO. ``I think it's going to take a while before we have agreement on how a post-German unification Europe looks,'' Bush said. ``My job is to convince him that there is no threat to the Soviet Union from a united Germany in NATO and, I'm absolutely convinced there is no threat to him and I think it's stabilizing.'' In the session with Time, Gorbachev said that ``Politically, we are already entering a new phase that should be characterized by the establishment of permanent security structures, instead of NATO and the Warsaw Treaty Organization. ``I envision Europe as a union of states with common institutions to assure military and environmental security, along with cooperation in science and culture,'' the Soviet president said. ``Each state would retain its local and national character and have the right to protect is special interests without prejudice to others. ``You ask how my approach differs from that of President Bush. Indeed, there are some differences. According to the American scenario, as far as I can tell, NATO _ and that means a NATO strengthened by the inclusion of a unified Germany _ should be the foreman and guarantor in the building of a new European order,'' Gorbachev said. ``I can understand that Americans and many Europeans have their own perception of this organization,'' he went on. ``They give it credit for keeping peace throughout the cold war. On that basis, we are being told the role of NATO, in the new phase as well, will be entirely positive, and will even serve the interests of the Soviet Union. But that's just not serious. For our people, too, NATO is associated with the cold war _ but as an organization designed from the start to be hostile to the Soviet Union, as a force that whipped up the arms race and the danger of war. ``Regardless of what is being said about NATO now, for us it is a symbol of the past, a dangerous and confrontational past. And we will never agree to assign it the leading role in building a new Europe. I want us to be understood correctly on this.'' Gorbachev, at another point, was asked whether he expected the issue to lead to a ``major disagreement'' at the summit his coming week. ``I wouldn't say I expect a major disagreement _ I'll state for a fact that there will be one,'' he replied. ``But I do expect the differences to be narrowed as a result of my discussions with President Bush.'' On other topics, Gorbachev: _Conceded his domestic economic reforms are likely to trigger serious inflation and unemployment as the nation moves toward a market economy. ``You have to bear in mind that we have quite a few factories ... that are simply inefficient,'' he said. ``They're going to have to reorient their production. People will have to be retrained. Many will have to find new occupations. _Said ``it would be an environmental catastrophe'' if other nations, including his own, tried to achieve the standard of living enjoyed by Americans. ``America already consumes a disproportionate percentage of the world's energy resources,'' he said. ``That's why I stress the conflict between consumer society and nature.'' _Defended his tough stance against the independence moves of the Baltic states, saying ``as president, I took an oath of office to uphold the constitution ... We are looking for a way to restore constitutional order and authority, and to do so by political means. Let me just stop there, particularly because recently we've seen some new and encouraging signs.'' _Said a return to the cold war is ``hardly possible now'' because ``We have learned too much about each other to be able to revert to old preconceptions and ideological cliches.''

DOC.HEAD: Sudan Quake Kills 31
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout with 31 people killed; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Thirty-one people were killed and hundreds of thousands left homeless by last weekend's earthquake and strong aftershocks in southern Sudan, government and rebel officials said Saturday. Thirty people were killed at Kuon-Wei near the city of Bor, 669 miles south of Khartoum, said the Sudan Relief and Rehabilitation Association in Nairobi, Kenya. The association is the relief arm of the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army. It said the May 20 quake sent homes tumbling into the River Nile. A spokesman for the rebel relief group, James Nduku, said another person was killed and two buildings collapsed in the village of Lafan near Torit, 790 miles south of Khartoum. Because of the remoteness of the area, reports about the effects of the earthquake have trickled in slowly. The quake measured 7.4 on the Richter scale, capable of causing widespread damage in a populated area. But much of southern Sudan's population has been displaced by famine and the country's 7-year-old civil war. Brig. Dominique Kasiano, a member of Sudan's ruling junta and political supervisor of the southern Equatoria region, said every government building and many homes were destroyed in Terakeka, a Nile River garrison town 55 miles north of southern Sudan's main city, Juba. He appealed for international help for quake victims. The government said about 300,000 people were left homeless. Officials of Western relief agencies and the rebel relief group said they had no knowledge of the situation in Terakeka, but questioned government figures on the number of people left homeless. In Cairo, the head of Egypt's monitoring service said the unit's seismographs have recorded almost continuous aftershocks since Thursday, when a strong aftershock struck. Monitoring stations measured it at 7.1 on the Richter scale. A number of houses and buildings have been reported damaged in Juba, 750 miles south of Khartoum, whose population has been swelled by refugees. No injuries have been reported in Juba, however. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. Thus a reading of 7.1 reflects an earthquake 10 times stronger than one of 6.1.

DOC.HEAD: Yugoslav Communist Party Renounces Monopoly on Power
DOC.TEXT: Yugoslavia's Communist Party on Saturday called for nationwide multiparty elections and formally renounced its monopoly on political power at a national congress. But the congress was boycotted by Communist Party members from three of Yugoslavia's six constituent republics, and analysts said it is doubtful the latest moves by the party will help restore its sagging national power. In a rare commentary, the leading Macedonian daily Nova Makedonija said Saturday's session represents ``the definite end'' of the Communist party of Yugoslavia since only three of the six republics took part in the session. Delegates from Slovenia, Croatia, and Macedonia refused to join in the resumption of the 14th Communist Party congress that broke up in disarray at its last meeting in January. Communists suffered resounding defeats in recent local multiparty elections in Slovenia and Croatia, the first free elections in Yugoslavia in 50 years. Delegates from the three republics that boycotted the meeting claimed the resumed congress was organized by hard-liners intent on maintaining their leading role at a time when parts of the country are already moving toward democracy. The January congress was suspended when Slovenia's delegates left the hall after losing a vote on reforms to hard-liners. Participating in Saturday's gathering were Communists from Serbia, the largest republic, Montenegro and Bosnia-Hercegovina. Delegates at the three-hour session adopted a statement waiving the party's leading role in society and called for free national elections. ``The most important thing is that the party be radically reformed ... into a modern political party,'' said Communist Party acting president Miomir Grbovic in his opening speech. Yugoslavia's Communist Party continues to rule at the federal level, but its power has been crippled since center-right parties won elections in Slovenia and Croatia. Multiparty elections are also planned in Bosnia-Hercegovina and Macedonia. Many political analysts doubt the Communist party can restore the authority it has lost after over a decade of ethnic and political squabbles and economic mismanagement. Saturday's session decided that a ``Congress of Democratic Renewal'' will be held on September 29 and the Communist Party will take part in future free elections at the federal level. The adopted document said the ``radically renewed party'' will try to unite all leftist political groups within Yugoslavia. ``The party still enjoys the support of the working class and will continue to rely on it in the future,'' Grbovic said. But he admitted the party's reputation ``has drastically declined throughout Yugoslavia.'' Nijaz Durakovic, head of the party in Bosnia-Hercegovina, told the gathering the Communists ``must show the right-wing parties that we are able to unite and function successfully in a multiparty environment.'' Serbian Communists are still firmly entrenched in their republic. Serbia is the only one of Yugoslavia's six states that has failed to schedule multiparty elections.

DOC.HEAD: Costumed Money-Giver Delights Dayton
DOC.TEXT: A ``bear'' with a chauffeur has been giving away money in downtown Dayton, but authorities don't have any idea as to the benevolent bruin's identity. ``A white, 1955 T-Bird pulls on Main Street in front of Courthouse Square, a guy in the bear suit gets out and he goes around handing out $1 bills,'' mounted police officer Rick Shiverdecker said Friday. ``He's been doing it most of the week.'' Shiverdecker said the bear has a driver who tools the Thunderbird once around the block while the currency is being distributed. ``Then the bear gets back in the car and they drive off,'' he said. Shiverdecker has been unable to determine who the philanthropists are.

DOC.HEAD: Three Iowa Counties Made Eligible For Federal Assistance
DOC.TEXT: President Bush issued a disaster declaration Saturday for three counties in Iowa, clearing the way for federal funds to be used in cleaning up after storms and flooding that began May 19. The counties are Crawford, Plymouth and Woodbury. The White House said more counties could be added after further damage assessments. The order authorizes temporary housing and federal grants and low-interest loans for businesses and individuals. The announcement was made here, where Bush is spending four days at his oceanside home.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Family Walks Parade Route; Rain Keeps Crowd Thin
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle, a self-described ``racing buff,'' hoofed the soggy three miles of the Indianapolis 500 Festival parade with his wife and three children Saturday. Quayle, wife Marilyn and children Tucker, Benjamin and Corinne were whisked into a building to wait out a 30-minute downpour before the festivities began. But the weather at least stayed dry during the 2{-hour parade. ``I can't believe he's walking,'' said Janie Charles, who waited to ride an old-fashioned bicycle in the parade as Quayle bodyguards tucked umbrellas into an escort car. Quayle, the first sitting vice president to serve as parade grand marshal, said the role was unquestionably in character for him. ``I've been to the race close to 20 times, that's about half the years of my life,'' the 43-year-old vice president said. The Quayles were joined by several celebrities and the race's 33 drivers, who rode in open convertibles over the sopping wet black-and-white checked carpet near the reviewing stand. Bands from as far away as South Dakota and Texas marched and played, while gigantic balloons of Raggedy Ann and Popeye floated high above the soggy crowd. Gov. Evan Bayh and Indianapolis Mayor William H. Hudnut also took part in the parade, as did Showtime comedian Jeff Altman and actor Norman Fell. Quayle, a former senator from Indiana, said getting to the race this year would be a lot more convenient than when he lived in his hometown of Huntington or was in law school in Indianapolis. ``We're going to fly over traffic this year,'' he said. ``But there was something that was fun _ to get ... to the track by some sort of back road,'' he added. ``We'd usually get about a half a mile from the race track. It was a little bit of a challenge to do that hauling the picnic basket.'' Quayle attended last year's race as a spectator. Organizers of Saturday's nationally televised parade said the rain kept attendance down to less than 100,000. ``We usually don't get to see any of the parade,'' said Tim O'Connor, a hot dog vendor and seven-year parade regular who's usually too busy selling. ``We'd usually be out of pop by now, but we can't give it away,'' he said. As of late Saturday afternoon, the forecast for Sunday's race included clouds _ and a 30 percent chance of rain. The start was set for noon EDT.

DOC.HEAD: A Summit of Lowered Expectations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 17th graf, ``Bush will xx to CORRECT Shevardnadze to Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: George Bush's second get-together with Mikhail S. Gorbachev shapes up as a summit of lowered expectations. There will be no treaty signed to limit long-range nuclear missiles, no announcement of a dramatic increase in trade between the United States and the Soviet Union. Other differences also will be felt: Moscow's resistance to German unity, its pressure on rebellious Lithuania to rejoin the Soviet fold, and the slow pace of talks to call home hundreds of thousands of troops and tanks from Europe. An agreement will be signed to destroy chemical weapons and a statement will be issued announcing limits on cruise missiles, an important step toward a broader treaty cutting the deadliest weapons in the superpowers' arsenals. But much of the three days of talks will be given over to discussing issues on which the superpowers are at loggerheads. ``We've got a lot of things to discuss that might not result in a signed agreement,'' Bush said last week, adding, ``There's enormous problems that just need to be talked about.'' Yet, he told reporters, ``I don't want to have two ships pass in the night, the United States and the Soviet Union.'' Recognizing the two leaders' fondness for springing surprises, many experts believe that something unexpected will emerge from the summit _ but probably nothing earthshaking. ``They are almost compelled to pull one or two rabbits out of the hat but they're going to be fairly small rabbits,'' predicted Robert W. Tucker, a Soviet specialist at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies. ``The administration always `low balls' summits,'' said Robert Hunter, a Soviet expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. ``It's the New Hampshire primary syndrome.'' Possible steps toward progress include further compromises for a pact covering long-range nuclear missiles, where differences already have been narrowed significantly, or pledges to revive slowly moving negotiations on a treaty to slash the superpowers' European armies and stores of conventional arms. Tucker said the real importance of the summit is that it continues the string of superpower meetings. ``It's part of the long and complicated and arduous process of winding down the Cold War and the differences that remain between us,'' Tucker said. Aside from striving for progress in arms talks, Bush will press Gorbachev to allow a united Germany to be a part of the U.S.-led NATO alliance. ``At stake,'' said Secretary of State James A. Baker III, ``is the reconciliation of a people and of a continent too long divided and the future of a legitimate and stable European order.'' Yet, Moscow has refused _ at least publicly _ to budge from its opposition to a united Germany in NATO, fearing a shift in the balance of power in Europe. Bush will press Gorbachev on the pace of negotiations in Vienna aimed at reducing the U.S. and Soviet forces and conventional arms in Europe. As the president said Thursday, ``The talks haven't gone as far or as fast as I would like to see. ... Maybe we can find some way at the summit ... to move CFE (the talks) forward.'' The Bush administration feels Moscow has slowed the pace of the discussions on a Conventional Forces in Europe treaty, in part, because it wants the large West German army scaled back. On this issue, there may be signs of movement. Last week, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said Moscow ``advocates an acceleration in the Vienna negotiations.'' He rejected the notion that Moscow's concerns over the West German army have made his government hesitant to sign a CFE agreement. Moreover, West German officials who met with Shevardnadze say they think the U.S. assessment of Soviet concerns may be a misunderstanding. Lithuania also promises, in Bush's words, to put ``some tension on the summit.'' Baker said recently that ``a good bit'' of the president's time will be spent discussing the moves by Baltic states to become independent of the Soviet Union and Gorbachev's pressure to keep them in the fold. Gorbachev, facing tests of his power at an important Communist Party Congress in July, likely will be unwilling to give up too much to Bush, experts say. ``Gorbachev's playing a very weak hand but he's playing it so well he's made himself look like an equal,'' said Hunter. ``His objective is not to humiliate the president but to be seen as a member of `The Club.' It's Bush's interest to be as forthcoming with Gorbachev as he can, while Gorbachev is doing what we want him to do,'' Hunter said. ``They have a mutual interest in success at this summit.'' Gorbachev is interested in any help Bush can offer for the battered Soviet economy. But that help, at least for now, won't include the trade concessions that once had been expected from the Bush administration. The United States will not grant the Soviet Union preferential, most-favored-nation status because the Soviet legislature has not passed legislation guaranteeing the right of emigration. U.S. law prohibits the president from granting such concessions to any nation determined to be denying its citizens the right to leave. On the other hand, Bush recently loosened restrictions on sales to Moscow of high-tech products such as computers and precision milling equipment. The two presidents also will discuss the unfulfilled efforts to sign a treaty limiting strategic arms. While Bush and Gorbachev will declare their intention to reduce the numbers of their long-range nuclear bombers, missiles and submarines by one-third, the formal agreement they once had hoped to sign is not even close to being ready. Gorbachev arrives in Washington Wednesday evening as a leader enjoying widespread popularity on the international stage but strapped by immense problems at home. His economy is wrecked. His nation is torn by nationalist uprisings. His far-flung communist empire virtually is gone. By contrast, Bush remains high in the public opinion polls and deals from a position of strength even though he is wrestling with difficult deficit problems. Yet, Bush does not want to undermine Gorbachev or push him from power because he has been the champion of Soviet reforms and allowed Eastern Europe to break free from Moscow. Despite his problems, Gorbachev appears in control. ``Whether we like what he is doing, whether we are unhappy with what he is doing, the buck in the Soviet government today stops with him,'' said Dimitri K. Simes, a Soviet expert at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. Beginning Thursday, Bush and Gorbachev will hold two days of talks at the White House. On Saturday, they will retreat to the privacy of Camp David for a day of discussions on troublesome political issues. It is at the presidential retreat, Bush said last week, that he expects he and Gorbachev ``can sit and talk'' about relations between the two superpowers. The summit will end Sunday morning, when the two leaders hold a wrap-up news conference in the chandeliered East Room of the White House. The planned showpiece of the summit will be the signing Friday evening of the agreements to destroy chemical weapons and clamp long-sought limits on air- and sea-launched cruise missiles.

DOC.HEAD: Talks Break Off in Polish Transport Strike
DOC.TEXT: Striking railworkers and government representatives broke off talks Saturday after failing to settle a walkout that has crippled transportation nationwide. The strike over a wage dispute has tested the resolve of the government reformers, who have imposed a strict program to shock the economy back to life. The government has flatly rejected pay increases as an inflationary threat to the economic overhaul plan imposed on Jan. 1. ``I am willing to talk with everybody ... about everything except wages,'' said Labor Minister Jacek Kuron of the Solidarity-led government. ``There will be no change of the government's stand.'' Strike committee member Janusz Zaborowski said his negotiating team would return to its headquarters in the northwest city of Slupsk to decide on its next move. ``We came to Warsaw in good faith and our outstretched arm was rejected yet again,'' Zaborowski said. ``The only constructive effect of the talks was that both sides agreed the strikes are over purely economic issues'' and not politics. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki reiterated Friday that despite sympathy for the sufferings of Poles under the economic reforms, he would not give to the strikers' demands. Lech Walesa, leader of the Solidarity trade union, said the workers' grievences were real but said a strike was not the appropriate answer. The strikes began May 20 and quickly spread across northwest Poland. But the protest eased slightly Saturday when strikers at Gdansk harbor and in at least one other area agreed to allow limited passenger service as ``good will gestures.'' The first signs of progress came Friday night when 42 hunger strikers, six of them hospitalized, suspended their fast and three rail stations in north-central Poland were reopened pending the outcome of negotiations. But rail traffic to the Baltic coast remained closed on Saturday and the country's busiest port, Szczecin, was paralyzed. The Transport Ministry said 72 passenger trains had been canceled Saturday morning. Freight traffic to the ports from Poland's industrial south and Hungary and Czechoslovakia were also disrupted. The army was called in to move essential freight, but Transport Minister Adam Wieladek said Saturday the military would not be used to run the railroad. He said there were plans to replace major rail routes with bus and truck transport. Officials say ``thousands'' of the nation's 400,000 railroad workers were striking but gave no specific figures. The government's economic reforms cut off huge government subsidies that allowed state-run industries, including the railroad, to charge unrealistically low rates. The government has demanding that pay increases come from funds within the enterprise and have refused to make any exceptions. Strict wage controls coupled with a raise in prices to market levels has reduced real income by an estimated 40 percent. Strikers are demanding a raise in rail workers' pay to 110 percent of the average national wage of $79 as month and have asked for the dismissal of railroad directors installed under the former Communist regime.

DOC.HEAD: Nationwide Tour Of Opera Extravaganza Canceled
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. tour of Verdi's opera ``Aida'' that would have included a five-story Sphinx and about 1,200 performers was canceled because producers felt they'd lose too much money, an official said Saturday. ``The bottom line was red ink. The costs were getting too high and the producers felt income would not cover expenses,'' said Tony Attanasio, marketing director for the International Opera Festival. The show was scheduled to begin with performances June 1 and 2 at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, across the Hudson River from New York City, and 30,000 tickets had been sold, Attanasio said. It had been scheduled to move to Los Angeles and San Francisco. The Montreal-based festival usually produces its own shows but had contracted with Concert Production International to run the show, Attanasio said in a telephone interview from New York. He said the company had a proven record of success with rock tours by the Rolling Stones and David Bowie. ``They were trying to put on a good show,'' Attanasio said. ``Most of the trucks with the props had arrived in New York from Toronto and work on building the stage and set was supposed to start Monday ... they were just overwhelmed by the size of this production.'' The production was to include a stage the length of a football field, the five-story replica of the Sphinx _ the Egyptian statue of a lion with the head of a man _ and about 1,200 performers, Attanasio said. The show was first performed in Giza, Egypt, in 1987. Since then, the production has been staged around the world and seen by about 850,000 people. Concert Production International decided to cancel Friday in a decision that surprised festival officials, he said. A man answering the phone Saturday at Concert Production International headquarters in Toronto referred all questions to marketing director Joe Owens, but said Owens would not be reachable until Monday. The cancellation cost the production companies a combined $2.5 million, Attanasio said. He said the festival was planning to resume the show in Europe next summer. ``We have to go back to our old way of doing production _ produce it ourselves and do it one show at a time,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodian Warring Factions Agree to Truce, but Fighting May Continue
DOC.TEXT: Cambodia's four warring factions signed a truce and agreed to form a body to enforce it, but one rebel leader said Saturday that the accord would accomplish little. If successful, the truce would end the 11-year-old civil war between the Vietnam-backed government in Phnom Penh and a three-party guerrilla coalition. However, guerrilla and diplomatic sources say they expect renewed fighting prior to peace talks in Tokyo as the guerrillas try to gain new ground and strengthen their bargaining positions. The truce will go into effect when it is announced officially at the Cambodian peace talks scheduled in Tokyo June 4-5, said senior guerrilla sources who spoke on condition of anonymity Saturday. The parties also will announce that peace talks will be resumed in Paris in July, they said. The guerrilla sources said the parties also agreed to the formation of a Supreme National Council that would include representatives from each faction and oversee the truce. The rebels include the Communist Khmer Rouge, the non-Communist Khmer People's National Liberation Front, and a faction loyal to coalition leader Prince Norodom Sihanouk. One guerrilla spokesman, Ok Serei Sopheak of the National Liberation Front, said Saturday a truce would not end the fighting. ``It is only a document,'' he said. ``It is a play on words. There will be no cease-fire on the ground.'' Another National Liberation Front, Ieng Moly, described the reported agreement as only ``a voluntary self-restraint on the use of force. There is no control, no supervision.'' The National Liberation Front launched major attacks Friday against the government-held town of Svay Chek in northwestern Cambodia. Guerrillas said that 4,000 fighters were involved in the push. ``We believe that an effective cease-fire must be controlled by the United Nations,'' Ok Serei Sopheak said. ``Otherwise the fighting will continue. We see a cease-fire as an element of a larger solution. We won't get anything at all through a cease-fire alone.'' Thai Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan, a key mediator in the conflict, had said last week that the pact would be signed. The guerrilla sources said the agreement had been initialed by Thai Defense Minister Gen. Chaovalit Yongchaiyudh. The Khmer Rouge is accused of killing a million Cambodians when it ruled Cambodia for 3{ years during the 1970s. Vietnam invaded, drove the Khmer from power and installed another government. The current government objects to any participation in a future government by the Khmer Rouge, but China _ which supplies the guerrilla faction _ says it must be a part of any peace settlement.

DOC.HEAD: KAL 747's Engine Catches Fire on Takeoff
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with safe landing, details of passenger total and witness reports. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A Korean Air Boeing 747 shut down one of its four engines when flames shot out on takeoff Saturday, and the jet returned to Los Angeles International Airport after dumping fuel, officials said. Flight 17 to Seoul, South Korea, returned safely with its 384 passengers, said S.K. Park, the airline's local passenger services manager. He knew only that the engine was not working, but had no details. The flames were observed by people on the ground as the jet took off about 12:50 p.m., said Art Morrison, a Federal Aviation Administration duty officer. The No. 1 engine, the outside engine on the left wing, was shut down and the plane circled over the ocean to dump fuel. It landed about 2:10 p.m. About 20 people in seaside El Segundo, just south of one end of the airport's runways, saw flames and smoke coming from the 747, said police Lt. David Cummings. ``People saw flames as the plane flew over the ocean and then the flames stopped,'' Cummings said. ``They commented that it was flying slow and lower than normal.''

DOC.HEAD: Memorial Built at Union Camp Site Where Black Troops Trained, POWs Held
DOC.TEXT: A memorial was dedicated Saturday at the former site of Camp Douglas, once a training camp for Union soldiers _ many of them blacks _ and later a prison where thousands of Confederate soldiers died. More than a century later, just six miles from the glitzy boutiques and department stores along Chicago's Magnificent Mile, no trace remains of the camp. The Heritage Memorial Wall honors the 6,000 Confederates who died in the prison camp of malnutrition, disease and exposure, and the thousands of Union soldiers who enlisted at the training camp, said Ernest A. Griffin, who financed the $20,000 monument. Many soldiers from Camp Douglas are buried in mass graves at Oak Woods Cemetery five miles away. Griffin said Camp Douglas was the Union's main training site for black soldiers, almost 200,000 of whom served in the Union army in a separate federal branch designated as the U.S. Colored Troops. For Griffin, the 6-by-6-foot concrete memorial mostly represents his ``admiration for a grandfather who participated in a historic event.'' The grandfather was Pvt. Charles H. Griffin, a Civil War veteran who served in the 29th Regiment's Company B of the U.S. Colored Infantry. Ernest Griffin was born on what was once the camp site in 1912 and now is director of Grifin Funeral Home Ltd., which occupies part of the tract. ``My grandfather enlisted for his Civil War service at this precise spot where I have my funeral establishment,'' Griffin said in a telephone interview Friday. About 300 people, including Mayor Richard M. Daley, joined a motorcade and parade Saturday from Oak Woods Cemetery to the memorial, which features a fountain, Confederate and Union flags, other war memorabilia and the flags of each state that fought in the Civil War. Daley presented Charles Griffin's great-great-great granddaughter, 14-year-old Suzanne Griffin, with a Civil War flag. ``After 125 years, all wounds between the North and the South should have been healed,'' said Ted Saunders, chairman of the Veterans Task Force Inc. in Illinois, organizers of the dedication ceremony. ``Over the years we have become one nation and one group of people.'' Saunders said he hopes the wall's dedication can help bring blacks and whites closer together. ``Every Memorial Day, I think all of our soldiers, black and white, realize how close we are to each other,'' Saunders said. Race is meaningless when soldiers are hiding in a fox hole, said Saunders, a Vietnam War veteran. ``The man who was sitting next to me _ I didn't care whether he was black or white. I wanted to be sure he'd cover my back, and I'd cover his. You don't have division in that type of situation.''

DOC.HEAD: Tradition Vs. Progress As Girls Clubs Change Name
DOC.TEXT: The members are often young girls who still play with dolls and know their dreams will come true. But the adults that run the Girls Clubs of America see the harsher realities the girls face. They see a tight economy, expensive housing, cheap drugs and other tough tests ahead for their 250,000 young participants, more than half of whom are members of minorities and come from poor, single-parent urban homes. In the face of those challenges, the Girls Clubs has changed its name to Girls Inc., and adopted a new slogan, ``Growing up is serious business.'' These days, the 45-year-old, 120-affiliate national network balances lessons in baking pies with lessons in selling them. ``The theme ... is to turn these girls into autonomous, independent adults so they don't get stuck in some awful cycle without any hope,'' said Keven Bellows, who works for the New York-based national organization and directed the search for a new name. She said the new name underscores the group's mission by ``moving away from the word `club,' which suggests exclusivity and recreation.''
