It also should clarify the distinction between the organization and the increasingly coed Boys Clubs and Girls Inc., Bellows said. However, several of the oldest Girls Clubs, like the one founded here 28 years before the national organization was chartered in 1945, object to what they say is leaving a tradition behind. ``This club played a very important role in the whole integration of women into society,'' said Nancy Achin Sullivan, executive director of the Girls Club of Lowell, about 20 miles north of Boston. ``We are very committed to its history.'' Through the decades, professional staff members here have helped thousands of girls, from Yankees looking for a diversion during World War I to the Hispanic and Cambodian immigrant girls who dropped in last week. Its 600 members, ranging in age from 6 to 14, visit the white clapboard club daily to learn about computers, banking, science, cooking and other practical skills. They also learn how to avoid unwanted pregnancy, drug addiction and welfare. ``We've built a lot of equity in our name here,'' said Sullivan. She and other officials worry the club's historic stature will be compromised and reliable donors, who account for at least half the Lowell club's annual $250,000 budget, will be put off by the name change. ``People will begin wondering what else has changed,'' Sullivan said. Other clubs, like the nation's oldest in Stamford, Conn., have lodged similar objections. But Bellows said the change was practical and inevitable. ``Nostalgia had to go by the wayside here in favor of survival,'' she said in a telephone interview. ``Keeping the traditional name was a kind of frivolous luxury we didn't have.'' The issue arose two years ago during a Girls Clubs' lawsuit against the Boys Clubs of America Inc., which had decided to change its name to Boys and Girls Clubs of America Inc. to reflect its growing coed membership. The case was eventually settled out of court when the Girls Clubs agreed to accept $760,000 and withdraw its objections. But Girls Clubs' officials still worried the public would assume the two organizations had merged. The name change was approved by the national body at its annual meeting and made official in May. The old motto _ ``It doesn't matter where a girl comes from as long as she knows where she is going'' _ also was changed to the more sobering ``Growing up is serious business.'' Girls Inc. has hired a public relations firm and plans a national TV, print and radio campaign this summer trumpeting its educational programs. But in Lowell, Sullivan said the club's reputation needs no enhancement. ``We are steeped in tradition and don't need a new identity,'' said Sullivan. ``I have a problem with the assumption that a national group ... knows what's best for this community.'' Clubs have until 1992 to decide whether to go along with the new name, slogan and image. Any that decides not to could become a non-voting affiliate of the national organization. ``Either way, the kids don't really care,'' said Mary Kajanka, president of the Lowell club's board of trustees. ``All they care about is having some place to go and someone to care for them.''

DOC.HEAD: More Than 150 McDonnell Douglas Workers Fired for Misuse of Company Funds
DOC.TEXT: McDonnell Douglas Corp. fired more than 150 employees who allegedly used interest-free company loans intended for personal computers to buy stereos or big-screen televisions or simply for extra cash. The workers received loans of up to $4,000 each under the company's loan program but never bought computers, company spokesman Don Hanson said Friday. A data processing employee reportedly processed the loans by printing phony invoices for computer sales, then took a $1,000 kickback. Loan applicants would then pay back the loan in interest-free paycheck deductions. Some workers at the Long Beach plant used the money to buy big-screen televisions and stereo systems, the Long Beach Press-Telegram reported. In another scheme, employees would buy a $4,000 computer, submit the invoice for a loan, then sell the computer back to the retailer. ``The reason for the program is to help our people acquire equipment that would improve or assure their computer literacy and to assure what they got at home would be compatible with what they were working on at the plant,'' Hanson said. The program began in 1984 to allow people to shop for the best computer bargain and get the loan for the amount of the sale, Hanson said. Some 5,000 employees have taken advantage of the program. Hanson said the fraud was discovered in April when an unusually large number of applications were received for the maximum amount. No charges were filed in the case.

DOC.HEAD: Ceausescu's Son Denies Ordering Troops to Fire on Demonstrators
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with two grafs to ADD Nicu's age; pickup graf 3 ```I kept...'
DOC.TEXT: The youngest son of executed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu insisted Saturday he never ordered the army and police to shoot at demonstrators during the bloody revolution that toppled his father. Nicu Ceausescu, 39, appearing frail and tense, was flanked by two helmeted policemen as he testified on the first day of his nationally televised trial. ``I kept asking the security forces not to shoot at demonstrators,'' he said. He told the five-judge military court that the evidence did not support the chief charge against him, complicity in genocide. Key prosecution witnesses were to be called Monday when the trial resumes. Nicu Ceausescu was the regional Communist Party secretary in Sibiu, 155 miles northwest of Bucharest in southern Transylvania. The city was the scene of fierce fighting during December's revolution. While he steadfastly denied ordering troops to fire on demonstrators, Ceausescu admitted to a lesser charge, illegal possession of firearms and ammunition. He also admitted he ordered the destruction of the Interior Ministry archive in Sibiu to prevent people from finding a list of informers for the Securitate, the hated secret police. The trial, held in Sibiu's cultural center, was expected to last several days. The building was ringed by half a dozen armored personnel carriers and about 40 soldiers in full combat gear. During the 6{-hour court session, attended by about 200 spectators, Ceausescu testified that he had disagreed with his parents for at least two decades on economic and political issues. Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu's other two children _ Valentin, 43, a nuclear physicist, and Zoia Elena, 37, a mathematician _ have also been in custody awaiting trial, but no date has been announced. The trial provided glimpses of the lifestyle of the younger Ceausescu, who had a reputation as a playboy with a penchant for violence. Although he lived in luxury by Romanian standards _ he had a mansion with a garden and swimming pool _ he apparently feared for his life. He told the court that all his meals were brought by plane from Bucharest and that he never tasted ``any food from local sources.'' Press reports after the revolution described the younger Ceausescu as a hated figure who had committed rapes and had killed at least one person while speeding recklessly in his car. He was also reported to have lost at least $1 million gambling. For his court appearance Saturday, Nicu wore a salt-and-pepper blazer and an open-necked shirt, as well as sunglasses. His attorney asked if Ceausescu could sit during the reading of the indictment because he was still recovering from a stab wound suffered after his arrest Dec. 22 near Bucharest, where he was a passenger in a car driven by his cabaret-singer mistress. Nicu needed surgery and six days of hospitalization after the attack by an unidentified assailant, the court was told. According to the indictment, the younger Ceausescu's order to fire on demonstrators was made in a telephone conference call with local party leaders. ``From now on we are in a state of war, not ... a state of emergency,'' the prosecutor quoted him as saying in the Dec. 17 telephone call. He said Nicu ordered troops to battle stations and said: ``You will shoot without warning.'' Eighty-nine people were killed in fighting between the revolutionary forces and Ceausescu's security troops in Sibiu, the indictment said. More than 20 former police officers and local officials in Sibiu have been tried and sentenced for genocide and other serious crimes in recent months. Ceausescu denied issuing shoot-to-kill orders even at the height of the revolution on Dec. 22, just hours before his parents fled Bucharest when the army decided to back the revolution. Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu were arrested, convicted of genocide at a summary military trial and executed on Dec. 25. Nicu Ceausescu testified that on the morning of Dec. 22, police and leaders of the local Securitate told him they were being shot at by demonstrators and asked him what to do. He said he told them to take their secret files, but ``don't shoot at anybody.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet-U.S. Negotiators Reschedule Talks For Sunday
DOC.TEXT: Scheduled arms negotiations between U.S. and Soviet officials were postponed Saturday because the Soviet delegation did not arrive in Washington until later than expected, a State Department spokeswoman said. Anita Stockman said the first round of talks would be Sunday. The Soviet delegation is headed by Viktor P. Karpov and is to meet with a U.S. group led by Under Secretary Reginald Bartholomew. The weekend negotiations involve a half-dozen unsettled issues, including ways to guard against cheating and whether to ban missiles with multiple nuclear warheads. The goal is to expand an agreement reached last week in Moscow by Secretary of State James A. Baker III and to produce a declaration for announcement by President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at their summit next week.

DOC.HEAD: Sabotage and Vandalism Are Trademarks of Militant Environmental Group
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 25th graf, `Earth First! claimed ...,' to CLARIFY that anonymous caller claiming to be from group claimed responsibility for attacks, sted group.
DOC.TEXT: The loose-knit band of radical environmentalists known as Earth First! has gained notoriety for such tactics as toppling power lines and billboards and driving spikes into trees to destroy logging equipment. Such tactics are the only way to prevent irreversible destruction of the environment, including the harvesting of old-growth forests, supporters say. But the radical actions, dubbed ``monkeywrenching'' for the tactics described in the 1975 novel by Edward Abbey, ``The Monkey Wrench Gang,'' have made enemies of loggers, utility companies, ranchers and other targets. ``They are a violent, terrorist group,'' said John Ross, executive vice president of the California Cattlemen's Association. Two key Earth First! organizers were arrested Friday for investigation of transportation and possession of explosives after a pipe bomb exploded in their car, injuring both. Bail was set for each at $100,000. Darryl Cherney, 33, suffered a facial cut. In addition to the possession charge, he was booked for possession of a destructive device in a public place and for possession of a booby trap. Judi Bari, 40, remained in stable condition at Highland Hospital with a fractured pelvis and internal injuries. She was booked on all but the booby trap charge. ``We suspect they intended to use the device in some way, shape or form,'' said Oakland Police Lt. Mike Sims. FBI investigators are looking for a link between the car blast and a May 10 pipe bomb that partially exploded in a Louisiana-Pacific Lumber Co. mill in Cloverdale about 80 miles north of San Francisco, causing minimal damage. But Earth First! supporters suspect that Bari and Cherney were themselves the targets of a terrorist act, accusing both law enforcement officials and logging interests of responsibility. ``This smacks of FBI tactics that were used against political activists, like the Black Panther Party and the anti-apartheid movement, in the '60s and '70s,'' said Earth First! activist Karen Pickett. Bari's lawyer, Susan Jordan, called the arrests ``absolutely insane.'' ``All their past, their present, has been devoted to non-violence,'' she said. In a jail interview with The Tribune of Oakland, Cherney said that by arresting him, ``the police and the district attorney are hiding the fact that they are incapable of going after the would-be assassin.'' ``This whole thing reeks of an FBI operation,'' he said. Cherney said both he and Bari have received numerous death threats in recent months as they worked to drum up support for ``Redwood Summer,'' a three-month series of non-violent protests planned for this summer. Modeling their plans after the ``Mississippi Summer'' civil rights protests of 1964, supporters hope hundreds of protesters will flock to northern California forests to participate in blockades and sit-ins against logging. ``We fully expected this oppression to come down if we were effective,'' Cherney said. Friends describe Bari and Cherney as committed to non-violence, and folksinger Utah Phillips credits Bari with helping unite loggers and environmentalists on economic reasons to oppose clear-cutting of old-growth forests. Bari also led a recently successful drive to renounce tree-spiking in northern California. A labor organizer, Bari saw the controversial practice as an attack on the working class, Phillips said. The campaign came after a mill worker was seriously injured three years ago while cutting a spiked tree. Earth First! was founded in 1979 with the slogan ``No compromise in defense of Mother Earth.'' The group is loosely organized, with no officers, board of directors or formal members. Supporters refer instead to the ``movement.'' The decentralized structure makes it impossible to estimate membership, but more than 10,000 people subscribe to the Earth First! Journal, which is published eight times a year. Earth First! co-founder David Foreman, 43, says the group is dedicated to defending the Earth at all costs. In 1985, he wrote ``Ecodefense: A Field Guide to Monkeywrench,'' which includes instructions on how to down power lines and spike trees. Foreman and three others were arrested in May 1989 and later indicted on charges of conspiring to sabotage nuclear power and arms plants in Arizona, California and Colorado. Their trial, originally scheduled for April, has been postponed until September. An anonymous telephone caller who said he represented Earth First! claimed responsibility for attacks on the California Cattlemen's Association headquarters in Sacramento and a livestock auction warehouse in Dixon in the same January day in 1989, said Ross. In April, thousands of people in the Santa Cruz area were without electricity for hours after two utility towers were the targets of sabotage believed to be the work of a splinter group of Earth First! called Earth Night Action Group, according to police. Earth First! supporters planned to maintain a 24-hour vigil at Oakland Police headquarters until Cherney and Bari are released. ``This only deepens our commitment to non-violence, and I hope it does the same for everybody,'' Cherney said.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Gubernatorial Nominees Make First Joint Appearance
DOC.TEXT: In a gubernatorial race that has been notably lacking in substantive discussion of the issues, Democratic candidate Ann Richards drew criticism Saturday for doing just that. In their first joint public appearance, Richards shared the stage with Republican nominee Clayton Williams at a centennial celebration for Floyd County. Williams, speaking to about 800 people in this Panhandel county seat, told a story about buffalo herding more than a century ago in West Texas and described what a lousy football player he was in high school in Fort Stockton. Ms. Richards, the state treasurer, took the stage next, and spoke about a series of salient issues including education, rural health and prison overcrowding. ``I worked hard on this speech,'' she said. ``I didn't come here just to tell you all a bunch of stories.'' But county Chamber of Commerce President Kyle Smith said Ms. Richards reneged on an agreement to avoid making public political statements during the Old Settlers Day celebration. ``Ann Richards kind of broke the rules on us,'' he said. ``Her campaign had made it clear to us her speech wasn't going to be political. Her camp wanted to make sure Clayton understood that so they would have the same type of speech.'' Many in the audience, however, said they had come to hear the candidates discuss the issues. Ms. Richards was en route to another appointment late Saturday afternoon and could not be reached for comment on whether she had broken the rules. Both candidates held news conferences after the ceremony. At his, Williams said he had abided by the organizers' request. ``I came here with the understanding that we were to talk about pioneers today,'' he said. ``A press conference is the proper time to ask questions above the roar of the crowd.'' Williams then reiterated that, if elected, he would push for a law requiring parental consent for abortions for minors. The oilman-rancher said he supports abortion only in cases of rape, incest or danger to the mother's life. Williams declined to answer questions about other issues, saying he would do so next week. At her news conference, Ms. Richards reiterated that, if elected, she would push for construction of more prisons. She also slammed outgoing Republican Gov. Bill Clements for vetoing a $555 million school-finance reform package, but declined to say how she would have acted. The Richards campaign has accused Williams of avoiding open debate. Before Saturday's ceremony, Williams approached Ms. Richards to shake hands and she said, ``I'm so glad to see you. You don't have to be afraid of me.'' Williams had no reply when Ms. Richards added, ``Tell your consultants to lay back and relax and let you be Claytie.'' Her comment was evocative of Williams' statement earlier this year comparing bad weather to rape. He said then, ``If it's inevitable, just relax and enjoy it.'' Williams later apologized for the remark.

DOC.HEAD: Police in Cameroon Fire on Demonstration, Killing Two
DOC.TEXT: Police on Saturday opened fire on demonstrators demanding an end to one-party rule. Two people were killed and nine wounded, hospitals reported. The violence occurred when members of the opposition Democratic Social Front held an illegal rally in the northern city of Bamenda, almost 200 miles north of Yaounde, the capital of this west African nation. Demonstrators set up barricades at the rally, and police opened fire to disperse the group. President Paul Biya has refused to permit parties other than his Cameroon People's Democratic Movement.

DOC.HEAD: Birch Society Condemns Summit
With AM-Summit '90-Expectations, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The archconservative John Birch Society on Saturday denounced the upcoming summit meeting between Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Bush. ``President Bush should not be welcoming Mikhail Gorbachev to America, should not be helping him out of his severe economic difficulties, and should not be sweeping 70 years of Soviet barbarism under a White House rug,'' Birch spokesman John F. McManus told a news conference. McManus said Gorbahev's glasnost and perestroika initiatives were a disguise for continuing the tyranny of earlier Soviet governments. He urged Bush, who begins his meetings with Gorbachev on Thursday at the White House, not to sign any new treaties with the Soviets. ``Why should we sign agreements with people when we know they're going to break it?'' McManus said. McManus also read from a Birch Society advertisement appearing in Saturday's editions of the Chicago Sun-Times that calls Gorbachev an ``archcriminal desperately seeking Western aid to stay in power.'' He said the ad will appear in newspapers in the Minneapolis area when Gorbachev and his wife Raisa visit there June 3 and in the San Francisco area the next day. McManus, whose group is based in Appleton, Wis., criticized Bush for not being more forceful in demanding independence for the Soviet Union's Baltic republics. McManus charged that U.S. presidents have aided the spread of communism by negotiating with Soviet leaders over the years. If Bush wants change in the Soviet Union, he should simply let communisim fall under its own weight, McManus said. McManus refused to talk about whether summits have led the world closer to peace or help create a climate in which the Berlin Wall has been dismantled. ``I want to answer about the contract of the last 50 years that helped build the Berlin Wall,'' he said. McManus criticized Bush and Congress for approving economic aid for Eastern Europe, contending that Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia are still being run by Communist bureaucrats. ``We should not be helping these people,'' he said. ``When they say democracy, they have literally changed nothing.''

DOC.HEAD: 18 Radical Koreans Try To March On U.S. Embassy
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested 18 radical students who tried to march on the U.S. Embassy on Saturday, accusing Washington of condoning a bloody crackdown on a 1980 uprising. The students were overpowered by riot police a few minutes after they rushed out of an underground walkway 30 yards from the embassy compound in Seoul. The students scattered leaflets charging the United States condoned the military crackdown on the anti-government uprising in the southern city of Kwangju that left about 200 people dead. The protesters demanded an apology. It was the second time this week that radical students tried to march to the U.S. Embassy. On Tuesday, eight students were arrested when they tried to deliver a protest letter to the U.S. Embassy concerning the Kwangju revolt. Radical students are in the midst of a period of anti-government, anti-U.S. protests to mark the 10th anniversary of the revolt on May 18, 1980. It was the bloodiest in modern Korean history. Korean radicals argue that the United States took a bystander's role during the 10-day revolt, thus condoning the crushing of the revolt by South Korean paratroopers. The United States has denied the allegations. In Kwangju, 156 miles south of Seoul, tens of thousands of people mounted street protests to mark the anniversary last week. One rally attracted about 100,000 people.

DOC.HEAD: Spurned Lover Sentenced to Seven Consecutive Life Terms in Arson Murders
DOC.TEXT: A woman who set fire to the home of the lover who spurned her, killing his mother, wife and 2-year-old daughter, was sentenced to seven consecutive life terms plus 15 years in prison. Vicky Chao, 46, remained subdued during sentencing Friday by Superior Court Judge Richard S. Gebelein, and shook her head when asked if she wished to make a statement. ``You were found guilty of the murders of three people, one of which was a child,'' the judge told Chao before pronouncing sentence. ``There is no crime on Earth, I guess, which is as serious as that. The law does provide for a very serious penalty, and the court is going to impose it.'' Chao was convicted in August of six counts of first-degree murder (one of intentional murder and one of felony murder for each victim), one count of attempted first-degree murder, two counts of first-degree conspiracy, and single counts of first-degree arson, first-degree burglary and second-degree conspiracy. The jury could not reach a unanimous decision on the death penalty, automatically mandating life imprisonment without probation or parole for the murder convictions. Gebelein imposed a seventh life sentence for the attempted murder count and 15 years for the other counts. Chao was arrested in March 1988, less than 24 hours after setting fire to the suburban home of William Chen, 36. The fire killed Chen's mother, Lyen Yu Chen, 56; his wife, Guo Jing Hong, 31, and their daughter, Anna Chen, 2. Chen, sole survivor of the pre-dawn blaze, admitted during the trial that he and Chao had a long affair, which he had broken off shortly before the fire. He testified that he barely escaped the blaze. He collapsed in the courtroom when the verdict against Chao was announced, but was not present for her sentencing. His brother, Edward, was there and said, ``Life sentence, right? But her family can see her, right? But our family, can't see anymore.'' William Chen is expected to testify against Chao's co-defendant, Tze Poong Liu, in the fall. Prosecutors allege that Liu, a New York City cab driver, drove Chao, who worked in a New York hotel, to Delaware and helped set the fire. He is free on unsecured bail.

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Depression Dissolves Into Rainstorm
DOC.TEXT: A tropical depression spawning rains that could help ease south Florida's drought dissolved Saturday as it passed over the Florida Straits. The system still threatened to dump heavy rains over south Florida, but the center dissolved Saturday morning. Water officials feared the rain may not travel as far north as Lake Okeechobee, the backup water supply for most southern Florida cities. The system kicked up high seas and made weekend boating hazardous. The depression's center moved through the Florida Keys in a slow, erratic path to the northeast as it dissolved into a rainstorm, forecasters said. A depression is officially classified as a tropical storm and is given a name if its top sustained surface winds reach 39 mph; those that reach 74 mph are classified as hurricanes. The Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 to Nov. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Kill 380 Rebel Troops, Afghan Government Says
DOC.TEXT: Afghan soldiers repelled an attack on an eastern garrison town Saturday, killing 380 Moslem guerrillas, state-run Kabul radio reported. Seven soldiers and four civilians were also killed and 15 civilians wounded in the attack on Khost, a besieged town 15 miles from the Pakistan border, said Kabul radio, monitored in Islamabad. The radio also said ``extremists'' fired 22 U.S.-made rockets into residental areas of the capital of Kabul, killing six people and wounding 12. The term ``extremists'' refers to the Pakistan-based guerrillas who have been trying for 12 years to overthrow the Soviet-backed government in Afghanistan. The reports could not be independently verified. The guerrillas insist they target only military installations but admit they sometimes misfire and hit residential areas. More than 100 rockets hit the capital in the past week, killing at least 12 people. Western diplomats in Pakistan said the guerrillas apparently stepped up their attacks on Kabul to coincide with preparations for a government assembly that is expected to approve major changes in the constitution. The session is also expected to loosen the grip of the leftist People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan that seized power in a 1978 coup. In Khost, the radio said, thousands of guerrillas launched a major attack on the town but were repelled by troops loyal to Afghan President Najibullah. ``The attack was foiled by prompt counter-operations by the military forces, and 380 extremists were wiped from the front line and large amounts of arms and ammunition were seized,'' it said. Khost, located on a high plateau and ringed by mountains, has little strategic significance but is of symbolic value. Najibullah and other senior members of his government are from the area. The rebels, who are financed by the United States, Saudi Arabia, and other sympathetic Arab states, have moved within two miles of the town and frequently fire heavy artillery and rockets into the town. The guerrilla outposts are routinely bombed by government warplanes. The city's airport has been closed for months and supplies to the estimated 5,000 government troops are dropped by air.

DOC.HEAD: Mexico To Seek Extradition Of U.S. Agent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to ADD confirmation of attorney general's office. Pickup pvs 14 `On April...'
DOC.TEXT: Mexico will seek the arrest and extradition of a U.S. narcotics official for his alleged role in abducting a Mexican doctor charged in the death of an American drug agent, the Mexican attorney general's office said. The office said it is asking for the extradition of Hector Berrellez, a superviser in the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration and allegedly the mastermind of the kidnapping of the doctor. ``Based on public recognition and testimony in a trial in Los Angeles that the DEA paid $20,000 `for services' to kidnap Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain from Mexican territory,'' the Attorney General's office will ask for the extradition of Berrellez, it said in a news release Friday. DEA spokesman Cornelius Dougherty in Washington declined to comment on the request for extradition. The Mexican doctor faces trial for alleged participation in the 1985 slaying of DEA agent Enrique Camarena. Berrellez testified Friday at a federal hearing in Los Angeles that a payment of up to $50,000 was authorized for the capture of the doctor. He said DEA Deputy Director Pete Gruden knew of the plan. The abduction of the doctor from his office has caused tension between the U.S. and Mexican governments. Mexico has demanded his return, saying the incident was a violation of Mexican sovereignty. The doctor, a Guadalajara gynecologist, was arrested April 3 after being taken to El Paso, Texas, to face charges he administered drugs to Camarena during the kidnapping, torture and murder of the drug agent and his pilot. In Washington, DEA spokesman Frank Shults denied that the government offered a reward or bounty for the people who captured the doctor, saying a $20,000 payment was provided for ``services.'' He said it could have covered such expenses as rental of the plane that flew the prisoner to El Paso. Former Mexican police officer Antonio Garate Bustamante, who is wanted by the Mexican government, testified he paid $20,000 in DEA money to the people who captured the doctor and was continuing to pay their expenses. Garate said he arranged for the doctor to be brought across the border with the approval of DEA officials. He said he found friends who would do the job without advance payment. ``I told them that no money would be provided up front, and they would have no assistance from the DEA,'' he said. ``Whatever they were doing, they were doing on their own.'' The attorney general's office said Friday that it would present formal accusations against Berrellez and Garate in a Mexico City district court. After obtaining warrants, it will present the accusations to the Foreign Ministry to seek the official's extradition. On April 28, the attorney general's office announced the arrest of six Mexicans for alleged involvement in the doctor's capture. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, commenting on the case, said Friday that the abduction ``does not help in the fight against drug smuggling.'' Speaking in the northern state of Chihuahua, Salinas said that the U.S. and Mexican governments should behave with mutual respect. Salinas and other Mexican officials have threatened to redefine the rules under which Mexico cooperates with the United States in drug enforcement. However, officials at the attorney general's office have said cooperation continues without any changes. Testimony at the trial of three other men in 1988 showed that Camarena was interrogated and tortured by drug traffickers. Prosecutors maintain that the abducted doctor gave Camarena drugs to revive him for additional torture before he was killed. The drug barons reportedly were angered because Camarena's undercover work had led U.S. and Mexican authorities to a desert marijuana plantation, where they seized huge quantities of the drug worth billions of dollars.

DOC.HEAD: Visiting Soviets Get Earful On Cuba, But Say No Aid Cutoff Planned
With AM-Summit '90-Expectations, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Cuban exiles challenged visiting Soviet officials Saturday to withdraw economic aid that helps keep Fidel Castro afloat, but the Soviets rejected the suggestion and reaffirmed support for Cuba's communist government. ``We are giving aid not to the Cuban government, but to the Cuban people,'' Latin American specialist Yuri Pavlov of the Soviet foreign ministry said during the rare meeting at a University of Miami conference. The statement drew groans from many in the crowd of about 300 attending the ``Moscow-Miami'' conference at the Grand Bay Hotel in Coconut Grove. The conference was highlighted by a discussion of U.S.-Soviet relations by a panel that included Georgy Arbatov, a close adviser to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and five other Soviets; U.S. Sen. Wyche Fowler, D-Ga.; and U.S. Reps. Dante Fascell and Larry Smith, both D-Fla. The discussion covered a broad range of topics, including economic cooperation, arms reduction and emigration by Soviet Jews. But there was one dominant issue for members of Miami's Cuban exile community who attended to plead their case against Castro. ``No nation is in a better position to influence the Cuban government,'' said Jorge Mas Canosa, an adamant foe of Castro's regime and chairman of the conservative Cuban American National Foundation. ``If the (Soviets) withdraw their subsidy, the Cuban problem would be solved in 48 hours.'' But several of the Soviet visitors disagreed with Mas. Several countered that U.S. trade with Cuba would reduce the need for Soviet economic aid and might lead to reforms. ``We have full respect for the views of the Cuban communists,'' said Pavlov. ``We are against an economic blockade of any one country.'' When the groans and cries of ``Lithuania!'' rang out from the back of the room, Jiri Valenta, director of the university's Institute for Soviet and East European Studies, quickly moved to the microphone. ``We will conduct this conference in a civilized manner,'' he said, quieting the audience. Much of the conference was quite civilized, with only a small group of protesters across the street from the luxury hotel to criticize the Soviet alliance with Castro. Before the recent dramatic changes in East-West relations, the appearance of Soviet officials in Miami would have provoked far more anger in the exile community. In the recent past, pro-communist entertainers have been banned from performing and paintings by pro-communist artists have been censored. In 1984, a city councilman even tried to prevent a visit by Miss Yugoslavia. But as Cuban broadcaster Tomas Regalado said in an earlier interview about the Soviet visit, ``This is something that Fidel will not like. The bottom line is if Fidel doesn't like it, we like it.'' The Soviet delegation included reform-minded members of the Supreme Soviet, Latin American specialists, and journalists. After the two-day conference ends Sunday, most of the Soviets plan to fly to Washington for the Bush-Gorbachev summit meeting.

DOC.HEAD: Park Ranger Killed, Escapees Caught
DOC.TEXT: Two Florida prison escapees shot and killed a National Park ranger, but minutes later were wounded and captured by police, authorities said. A woman called police around 9 a.m. and said she had escaped from two men who abducted her and brought her to a motel in this Gulf Coast city, said Police Chief Carolyn Frayser. The escapees kidnapped Marie Long Burnette, 55, early Friday from an Alabama motel where she worked as a night clerk, police said. Dempsey Alexander Bruner, 29, and John Fred Woolard, 27, had escaped Thursday morning from Holmes Correctional Instititution near Bonifay, Fla., while out on a doctor's visit, Florida authorities said. Bruner was serving a 20-year sentence for crimes including sexual battery, kidnapping and robbery. Woolard was serving 15 years for crimes including burglary, cocaine possession, battery on a law enforcement officer and a previous escape. Both were hospitalized in stable condition Saturday with gunshot wounds to the legs, hospital spokesmen said. Authorities said the details remained unclear of the events that led to the death of Robert L. McGhee Jr., 50, a ranger who was armed and on duty in the Gulf Islands National Seashore Park. An off-duty ranger who lives nearby heard a shot and found McGhee on the side of the road. McGhee, who was shot several times in the chest and head, was pronounced dead at the park at 9:13 a.m., said Jackson County Coroner James Miller. The escapees, with Burnette, had checked into the Ocean Springs motel at 4 p.m. Friday, Frayser said. She said officers responding to Burnette's call found the escapees minutes later near the park. In an ensuing car chase, the suspects tried to ram a police car, causing one officer minor contusions. A shootout followed, and the escapees were captured in woods next to the park, Frayser said. Unknown to police, the escapees had encountered McGhee about a mile away, she said. McGhee was married and had two children.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Premier Vows to Remain Defiant
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's premier Saturday said her republic will stand by its declaration of independence despite pressures from the Kremlin, and she said it could attain sovereignty within six months. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has said Lithuania could become independent in two or three years if the republic backs down from its March 11 declaration and follows Soviet procedures for secession. Officials in Lithuania said hot water supplies throughout the Baltic republic were shut off because regional distribution stations ran out of oil as a result of Soviet economic sanctions. Lithuanian Premier Kazimiera Prunskiene, in a speech to a congress of German Catholics, said: ``No one can demand from us a withdrawal of the declaration of independence.'' She added the Lithuanian government had receiveda popular mandate to ``secede from the empire'' and appealed to the world's estimated 950 million Roman Catholics for support. Lithuania is predominantly Roman Catholic. The Lithuanian premier also blasted Gorbachev during the address, saying he had not decided between ``democracy and being reactionary.'' Mrs. Prunskiene accused him of unfairly calling the Lithuanian movement a threat to his plans to revamp Soviet society. The West Berlin audience of 4,000 people applauded her for several minutes after the address, which she delivered in German. In talks with reporters, Ms. Prunskiene said she was ``hopeful'' that a solution could be found to end the stalemate. In an interview with West Germany's Saarland State Radio, Ms. Prunskiene said the Baltic republic could achieve sovereignty in six months. She said Lithuania's future was closely linked to the pro-democracy situation in all of Eastern Europe. ``When all of Eastern Europe is developing in this direction, then we'll also achieve independence in Lithuania more quickly,'' she told the radio station. On Friday, Gorbachev called Lithuanian leaders ``adventurists.'' ``We have great reserves of will power, but we are looking for ways'' to end the impasse, Gorbachev said. In an interview with Time magazine, Gorbachev said: ``We are looking for a way to restore constitutional order and authority, and to do so by political means.'' He refused to comment further but added that ``recently we've seen some new and encouraging signs.'' The transcript of the session appears in the June 4 edition of the magazine. Also on Saturday, thousands of Georgians held rallies in the southern Soviet republic's capital of Tbilisi to mark the 72nd anniversary of their brief independence from the Soviet Union, witnesses said. About 5,000 people attended two pro-independence rallies sponsored by the National Forum, a union of about 40 political groups, and Round Table, comprised of four other political organizations. Georgia declared independence on May 26, 1918, and remained independent until Feb. 25, 1921, when it was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Long Line for Final Day of Mapplethorpe Show
DOC.TEXT: The Robert Mapplethorpe photo exhibit ended Saturday the way it began _ with a long line waiting to see the pictures that prompted an obscenity indictment. Nearly 4,000 people lined up Saturday at the Contemporary Arts Center to see the 175 photos, including seven mentioned in the indictment, before the show closed. The line stretched onto the street in front of the arcade that houses the art gallery. The 3,902 patrons brought the show's final total to 79,893, easily a record for the arts center, a spokesman said. The exhibit goes next to the Boston Institute of Contemporary Art, where it is to open Aug. 1. Boston Institute Director David Ross said he expects a quieter reaction than in Cincinnati. ``The Perfect Moment,'' a display of the late Mapplethorpe's photographs, includes seven that a Hamilton County grand jury found objectionable. The arts center and its director, Dennis Barrie, are under indictment on misdemeanor charges of obscenity and displaying children in nudity-oriented matter. Five of the photos show homoerotic acts; two show naked or partly naked children. The exhibit had a preview showing April 6 for arts center members. When it opened to the public the next day, the grand jury was among the spectators. The case remains unresolved. Another court appearance is scheduled next week. The controversy only fueled public interest in the exhibit, and the local dispute became a national cause. ``Cincinnati has become a microcosm of what is happening all over America,'' Barrie said. ``In one way, it's very positive for Cincinnati. I like being able to help shape the future direction of national concerns.'' Mapplethorpe's name was first heard outside the art world last June when Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., showed copies of his controversial photographs to members of Congress. The Corcoran Gallery in Washington canceled its showing of ``The Perfect Moment.'' But the exhibit had been shown in six cities without incident before it reached Cincinnati. In February, a local group called Citizens for Community Values began a mail campaign calling for ``action to prevent this pornographic art from being shown in our city.'' The arts center, its board members and board members' employers received hundreds of protest letters and calls. The center voluntarily withdrew from the city's Fine Arts Fund on March 25, fearing its inclusion might damage the 1990 fund drive. The exhibit's opening drew further attention when police temporarily closed it to videotape the photographs. The arts community feared the exhibit would be closed to the public. But U.S. District Judge Carl Rubin issued a temporary restraining order April 8 barring law enforcement officials from closing the exhibit until the obscenity question was resolved in court.

DOC.HEAD: Swedish Refugees Centers on Alert After Attacks; 11 Injured
DOC.NOTE: Eds: NOTE language in 5th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Eleven people were injured Saturday by a smoke grenade thrown into refugee housing, and arsonists burned down 15 barracks elsewhere in the latest of a spate of attacks on the public centers. Immigration authorities put all the government-funded refugee centers on alert, an immigration official said. Police officers were starting around-the-clock guard at some places, the television reported. The 11 refugees were slightly injured in an attack early Saturday when a smoke grenade was thrown into a building housing refugees outside Motala, 160 miles south of Stockholm. Hours later, arsonists burned down 15 barracks to be used by refugees in a community further south outside Laholm, police said. Swastikas and hate slogans, such as ``no niggers,'' were painted on walls. ``We have called up centers in all regions and told them to be on the lookout,'' Lena Hall-Eriksson, the national immigration official, told a reporter on Swedish national television. Hall-Eriksson said the attacks ``may be organized, or maybe one incident is inspiring the other.'' Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson denounced the attacks as ``criminal acts.'' This country of 8.4 million inhabitants has long had liberal immigration policies. Nearly 20,000 refugees have moved to Sweden every year, many from Iran, Ethiopia and other Third World countries. Until recently, there had been few reports of violent opposition to the influx. The recent wave of attacks flared up about a week ago when windows were shattered at the center outside Motala. On Thursday, two barracks that were being prepared for refugees in Kimstad, 90 miles south of Stockholm, were burned to the ground.

DOC.HEAD: Campers Rescued From High Water
With AM-Floods-Future, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 90 campers, some in trees, were rescued Saturday after heavy rains caused a creek of the Mineral Fork River to rise and flood several campgrounds, authorities said. ``You could see them hanging in the tops of the trees, waving flashlights and screaming for help,'' said Dennis Spradling, a firefighter for the Potosi Fire Protection District. Dozens of people, including Washington County sheriff's deputies, firefighters from about 15 area departments and volunteers, used boats to help rescue campers near this eastern Missouri town, Spradling said. The water was over Highway 21, hampering rescuers' efforts, he said. The river already had been high, following persistent rains through most of May. The call for help came in about 12:30 a.m., Spradling said. People were rescued from four campgrounds just south of Washington State Park, about 13 miles north of Potosi. They were taken to a nearby school. There were no major injuries, Spradling said. Three boats sank in the rain and fast-moving water. By mid-afternoon Saturday, the high water was receding and authorities were checking campers, other vehicles and camping equipment. There were no reports of missing people, Spradling said. The area got about 2.5 inches of rain in the 24 hours ending at John Feldt of the National Weather Service said the area got about 2.5 inches of rain in the 24 hours ending at 7 a.m. Saturday. He said the heaviest rain was in central Missouri, with Iberia getting about 6 inches in that period.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Rules Bio Can Be Published
DOC.TEXT: An upcoming critical biography of L. Ron Hubbard, author and founder of the Church of Scientology, may be published in its original form, a federal appeals court ruled. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals reversed a lower court's ruling in February for New Era Publications International, exclusive licensee of Hubbard's works, which had filed a copyright infringement lawsuit. Hubbard died in 1986. The appeals court held Thursday that the book's quotations from Hubbard's published works, which amount to about 3 percent of the total biography, constituted fair use. Michael Lee Hertzberg, an attorney for New Era Publications, said his client had not decided whether to appeal. The book is ``A Piece of Blue Sky: Scientology, Dianetics and L. Ron Hubbard Exposed,'' by Jon Atack, a former Scientology member who turned against the church, claiming it is a dangerous cult. The book is scheduled to be shipped to stores in June, said Steven Schragis, president of Carol Publishing Group.

DOC.HEAD: Haitian President Visits Burned Boy
DOC.TEXT: Haiti's president stopped at a hospital Saturday to visit a 12-year-old boy who was set on fire more than two months ago by a neighborhood bully. President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot brought flowers, a birthday card and a present to David Opont, who has been in the burn unit of New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan since the March 7 attack. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, speaking through an interpreter, said in Creole that she came to ``try to help his morale.'' She also met with David's parents and his 14-year-old sister. The family is from Haiti. Hospital officials have said David is expected to leave the hospital in the next few days for long-term rehabilitation at another hospital. His birthday was in March, but his condition did not allow for a celebration until Thursday. A 13-year-old boy accused of dragging David into an abandoned basement in Brooklyn, tying him to a pipe and setting him ablaze is being held without bail.

DOC.HEAD: Kidnappers Threaten U.S. And Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 6th `The picture...' to CLARIFY that two pictures are different; pickup graf 7 `On April...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BEI-2
DOC.TEXT: Kidnappers holding two American hostages vowed Saturday to make the United States and Israel ``pay the price'' for the massacre of seven Palestinian workers in Israel last week. However, the statement by the Organization of Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine did not directly threaten to harm the two hostages. In another hostage development Saturday, PLO leader Yasser Arafat reportedly said two Swiss Red Cross workers kidnapped in Lebanon seven months ago are alive, and he offered to help mediate their release. The Arabic-language statement, delivered to a Western news agency in Beirut, came with an instant picture of U.S. hostages Jesse Turner and Alann Steen. They were kidnapped Jan. 24, 1987, from Beirut University College. The picture showed a smiling, bespectacled Turner wearing a bushy black beard and a striped pullover. Steen wore a dark jumpsuit and a beard, and his hair was slightly disheveled. Both looked straight at the camera. The picture resembled a photograph the group released Feb. 23, 1989, showing Turner and Steen along with former American hostage Robert Polhill. However, the two photographs were clearly different, because Turner's hair was much longer in the later one. On April 22, the same group released Polhill, a New Yorker and a lecturer in accounting who was kidnapped with Steen and Turner. Turner, 42, of Boise, Idaho, and Steen, 50, a native of Boston, were professors serving with the U.S.-affiliated college when they were abducted by gunmen posing as Lebanese riot police. Eight days after Polhill was freed, another pro-Iranian group, the Organization of Islamic Dawn, released American hostage Frank Herbert Reed, 57, of Malden, Mass., after 3{ years in captivity. Iranian leaders and their Lebanese allies have since complained the United States has failed to respond with a goodwill gesture of its own. ``America is directly responsible for shedding the blood of our people and their cause,'' the 18-line statement said Saturday, referring to the shooting deaths of seven Arab laborers in a Tel Aviv suburb on May 20. Israeli officials have said the accused gunman, a former soldier, was apparently deranged. The shootings prompted widespread unrest among Arabs in Jordan, Israel and the occupied territories. Arafat also cited the killings when he urged the U.N. Security Council in Geneva on Friday to send an international force to protect Palestinians in the occupied lands. ``We warn America and Israel that future developments will not be in the interest of either of them. They will realize that the blood will not be wasted. They will pay the price,'' the kidnappers' statement said. ``America seeks at all costs to retain its base, Israel, in the East and will not permit even verbal resolutions of an adverse nature against Israel.'' This was seen as a reference to frequent U.S. vetoes of U.N. Security Council resolutions condemning Israeli actions. Asked about the statement, State Department spokeswoman Anita Stockman said: ``I don't really have have anything I can comment on in terms of the report except to say that our general policy is to say that the hostages should be freed immediately and unconditionally.'' The Foreign Ministry spokesman in Israel refused to comment. The Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine took responsibility for the kidnapping of Turner, Steen, Polhill and fellow professor Mitheleshwar Singh, who was released Oct. 3, 1988. The group's statement Saturday condemned the slaying of seven Palestinian workers as a crime. It called the international uproar over the killings ``artificial patronage'' and a ``hollow storm of empty words,'' and said the ``effective deterrent is force.'' Turner and Steen are among 16 Western hostages held in Lebanon, most of them by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem zealots. The captives are six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Italian and an Irishman. After the U.N. Security Council session in Geneva on Friday, Arafat discussed the two Swiss hostages with Pierre-Yves Simonin, a ranking Swiss Foreign Ministry official, a department spokeswoman said Saturday. But the PLO chief did not say where Emanuel Christen and Elio Erriquez of the all-Swiss International Committee of the Red Cross were being held or by whom. The spokeswoman, Andrea Reichlin, also said Arafat offered to mediate between the kidnappers and Swiss authorities if such contacts come about. In a meeting with Cornelio Sommaruga, president of the Geneva-based ICRC, Arafat repeated his assurance that the two hostages are alive, she said. Erriquez and Christen were taken captive Oct. 6 in the southern Lebanese port city of Sidon, where they helped run an artificial limb center for victims of civil war. No one claimed responsibility for the kidnapping. However, the men are believed held by the Fatah-Revolutionary Council, the group headed by terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal, who broke with Arafat years ago. Palestinian sources linked the abduction to a Lebanese Moslem Shiite, Hussein Hariri, jailed for life in Switzerland in February 1989 for hijacking an Air Afrique jetliner two years earlier and killing a French passenger. Of the 16 Western hostages, the longest-held is U.S. journalist Terry Anderson, 42, of Lorain, Ohio, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Expect More Taxes
DOC.TEXT: Most Americans expect President Bush to ask Congress to increase taxes, and less than half say he never meant his campaign pledge of ``no new taxes,'' according to a New York Times-CBS News poll. The most acceptable tax to raise would be the federal excise tax on beer, wine and liquor _ chosen by 80 percent of the 1,140 adults surveyed in the poll published in Sunday editions of the Times. About 78 percent said to raise the tax on income over $200,000. Bush has declined to say whether his staunch campaign opposition to tax increases is still in effect. But nearly 70 percent of those surveyed Tuesday through Thursday expect Bush to seek higher taxes, and 40 percent say he never meant his no-tax pledge. Asked what should be cut from the budget, 83 percent said reduce foreign aid and 64 percent said reduce military spending. Unacceptable areas for cuts included education (named by 86 percent), Social Security increases (82 percent) and the environment (74 percent). Neither party gained a clear advantage in the survey when people were asked which party was more likely to raise taxes. About 38 percent said Republicans were, and 42 percent picked the Democrats. The poll's margin of error was 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Dead in Chemical Plant Explosion in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: An explosion ripped through a downtown chemical plant Saturday, killing at least seven workers and injuring 19, the fire department said. The blast occurred early in the day at Dai-ichi Chemical Industries in northwestern Tokyo, burning down nine factory buildings, said a city fire official. At the time, 51 employees were working in the factory, which manufactures bleaching agents, chlorides and other chemicals. The condition of the remaining 25 was unknown, though most were thought to have escaped, the fire official said. No damage was reported outside the factory, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Chiyo Ito, a 21-year-old waitress at a coffee shop next to the factory, told Kyodo News Service that she saw three factory workers run out of the building with their clothes on fire. Neighbors beat out the flames and splashed water on the victims while they waited for ambulances, Kyodo quoted Ms. Ito as saying. The fire department was investigating the cause of the explosion, the official said. Dai-ichi Chemical Industries was founded in 1953.

DOC.HEAD: National Society of Arts and Letters Announces Winners
DOC.TEXT: A Virginia teen-ager on Saturday was awarded first place in the National Society of Arts and Letters' annual ballet competition. Stephanie Anne Walz, 17, of Dumfries won the $5,000 prize in competition Friday in Pittsburgh. She was chosen from among 28 dancers between the ages of 14 and 19. The second-place winner was Emily Carson Coates, 16, of McMurray, Pa., a suburb of Pittsburgh. She won $4,000. Placing third was Brett Alexis Ishida, 14, of Porterville, Calif., who won $3,000. The National Society of Arts and Letters was founded in 1944 to encourage and assist talented young artists at the beginning of their careers. It presents annual awards in various categories of art, dance, drama, literature and music.

DOC.HEAD: Robert Wagner and Jill St. John Wed in Private Ceremony
LaserPhoto LA6
DOC.TEXT: Actor Robert Wagner and actress Jill St. John were married Saturday in a private ceremony in the garden of Wagner's Pacific Palisades home. Wagner, 60, and Miss St. John, 49, have been together for eight years, said publicist Alan Nierob. Katherine Wagner, 26, served as maid-of-honor. Natasha Gregson, 19, and Courtney Brooke, 16, were bridesmaids. Also attending were Wagner's mother and sister and Miss St. John's mother, Nierob said. Wagner was married twice to the late actress Natalie Wood. On Nov. 29, 1981, Miss Wood accidentally slipped from Wagner's 60-foot yacht Splendour and drowned off Santa Catalina Island, Calif., at age 43. After Miss Wood's death, Wagner gave the yacht to the Sea Scouts, sold their rambling Beverly Hills home and moved to a Sunset Boulevard estate with Natasha, Miss Wood's daughter from her marriage to English producer Richard Gregson; Courtney, born to Miss Wood and Wagner after they married a second time in 1972, and Katherine, Wagner's daughter from his marriage to dancer Marian Marshall. Wagner and Miss Wood's first five-year marriage ended in 1965. Miss St. John, whose films include ``Diamonds are Forever,'' was previously married and divorced three times. Wagner, who has been in numerous films, starred in the TV series ``Hart to Hart'' from 1979-84.

DOC.HEAD: Person Dressed as Clown Shoots Woman In Face
DOC.TEXT: A person wearing a Bozo costume and bearing flowers and balloons shot a woman in the face Saturday when she opened her front door. The suspect _ with a costume that included red hair, an orange nose and white gloves _ sped out of the exclusive Palm Beach County development in a white car without a license plate, police said. The victim, 40-year-old Marlene Warren, was in critical condition on a respirator at Palms West Hospital Saturday night. Investigators said they had some leads, but none solid enough to determine a motive or suspects. They said it appeared that Mrs. Warren was the target. Her son and some friends were home and saw the shooting about 11 a.m. Mrs. Warren opened the door for the clown, investigators said, and took the flowers and balloons without saying anything. ``As soon as she reached out and grabbed it, he pulled out a revolver and shot her once in the face,'' said Sheriff's Detective Sgt. Lou Sessa. Mrs. Warren and her husband Michael own several properties, including duplexes in West Palm Beach and an auto dealership.

DOC.HEAD: Colombia An Armed Camp on Eve of Presidential Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 13 grafs for 3-12 bgng `Some Colombians...' to UPDATE with Barco speech; pickup graf 13 pvs `There are...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BOG2
DOC.TEXT: The bloodiest election campaign in Colombia's 180 years of independence comes to a close with Sunday's presidential voting, but many feared that the terror unleashed by drug traffickers would continue. Officials accused the drug barons of using violence to keep people away from the polls. The army and police mobilized 230,000 troops for election-day duty, and military checkpoints lined major streets and highways. Just hours before the polls were to open, President Virgilio Barco exhorted Colombians to vote in defiance of the terrorism. ``To vote is to support democracy, to reject violence and to defend the rights that the terrorists want to snatch from us,'' Barco said in his nationally broadcast speech. He added, ``I do not have the slightest doubt that both the terrorist acts aimed at taking the lives of presidential candidates as well as those committed against other compatriots have been carried out to intimidate the popular will.'' Some Colombians said they planned to vote early _ to cut the time spent standing in line, thus reducing the risk of being killed or maimed in an attack. Colombia's drug war has overshadowed every other issue in the presidential campaign. In the past nine months, three presidential candidates, 262 policemen, 93 soldiers, three judges, 15 news media employees and about 1,700 other people have been slain. Bombs have exploded at schools, churches, shopping centers and supermarkets. One bomb destroyed a Colombian airliner, killing all 107 people aboard. In the two weeks leading up to Sunday's balloting, nine bombs exploded in four Colombian cities, killing 37 people and wounding more than 320. Few of the crimes have been solved, but suspicion for most of the killings has fallen on drug traffickers, who have private armies and billions of dollars in cocaine profits at their disposal. Right-wing death squads and leftist guerrillas also have played roles in the carnage. The army and police said 230,000 troops would be out in force for the election, and a curfew was imposed in the drug capital of Medellin following a wave of bombings and murders. Government officials have expressed fears that intimidation by traffickers would prevent some people from voting, and accused the drug lords of stepping up attacks to scare people. There are about 13.8 million eligible voters. Barco and his wife planned to vote as soon as the polls opened, as is traditional for the president. Barco's four-year term ends Aug. 7, and the constitution prohibits a president from serving two successive terms. There are 12 candidates for president. Only four are considered to have nationwide backing. The ruling Liberal Party's candidate, Cesar Gaviria, is considered the leading contender. He is the only candidate who has promised to continue Barco's tough policies against the traffickers, including extradition of drug traffickers to the United States. Gaviria replaced the party's front-running presidential contender, Luis Carlos Galan, who was assassinated last Aug. 18. It was the killing of Galan _ which authorities blamed on traffickers _ that set off the government's offensive against the drug trade, including the resumption of the government's extradition policy. One main presidential contender, Alvaro Gomez, has urged legalization of cocaine in the major drug-consuming countries. He says the only way to put the traffickers out of business is to deprive them of profits. Gomez, an independent, and the other two main candidates, Rodrigo Lloreda and Navarro Wolf, all say they would likely stop the extraditions. The Barco government has extradited 15 drug suspects to the United States in the past nine months. Gaviria says he would continue extraditions at least until Colombia is able to put traffickers in jail and keep them there. No other issue claimed anything approaching the attention given to the drug war. ``The traffickers' dark shadow of terrorism has blotted out all other issues,'' said Enrique Santos, whose family owns the Bogota daily El Tiempo, Colombia's largest newspaper. ``There is nothing philosophical about this election.'' Indeed, the candidates have scarcely mentioned such pressing issues as unemployment, inflation and the need for land reform. Unemployment is running 9 percent, according to government figures. Private economists say it is 20 percent. Inflation is running at 28 percent, up from 26 percent last year. Clara Lopez, a former Bogota city council president, says drug-related violence poses less of a threat than social injustice, which she says could lead to unrest. ``All of Colombia's problems originate with the inequitable distribution of land,'' said Lopez, a human rights activist who has campaigned for constitutional reforms. Colombians also decide Sunday whether a constituent assembly should be named to consider changes in the 1886 constitution. Proponents of the assembly say the constitution must be altered to make the judicial system stronger and to break up large land holdings. According to a 1970 census, the last that tracked land distribution, ownership of 68 percent of the land is concentrated in the hands of 4.3 percent of the population. But even that problem goes back to drug traffickers. The army has said traffickers own millions of acres of land. Gaviria and other presidential candidates, following Barco's lead, have insisted that the root of the problem lies with the insatiable appetite for cocaine in other countries, especially in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Tutu Says Huge Pro-Apartheid Demonstration No Surprise
DOC.BYLINE: With AM-South Africa, Bjt ^By JOE KAY
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Desmond Tutu said he was more surprised by the recent changes in South Africa than the fact that tens of thousands of pro-apartheid demonstrators turned out in Pretoria on Saturday to protest them. ``They've been supporting apartheid for so long,'' Tutu, South Africa's Anglican archbishop, told a news conference. ``What is surprising is that we should see a government that is willing to risk that.'' Since coming to power last year, South African President F.W. de Klerk has freed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela from prison, promised apartheid would end within five years and taken other measures to end discriminatory policies. Tutu said it's not surprising that whites who enjoyed privileges under apartheid would object to losing some of them. ``The surprising thing is that the government should in fact have broken loose from that kind of thinking,'' he said. Tens of thousands of whites shouted their support for white minority rule and condemned de Klerk at the rally Saturday in Pretoria. Tutu, in Cincinnati for a four-day visit, said if he had been able to address the demonstrators, he would have told them they cannot prevail. ``I'd say to them, `You do have the right to hold that rally, but ultimately it is self-defeating,''' he said. ``What in fact are you seeking to do? You are seeking to carve out for yourself a separate freedom. Now the world has discovered that freedom is indivisible.'' ``There's a spirit that cannot be quenched,'' he said, referring to recent changes in, for example, Eastern Europe. ``A repressive government, an unjust system, are based on a foundation that is fundamentally unstable.'' Tutu is spending the weekend meeting with religious leaders and representatives of the black community, and making numerous public appearances. The cleric, on a six-city trip through the United States, said he's enjoying the chance to visit a country with freedom and opportunities. ``You do get a sense of how wonderful it is _ despite all of the awful messes that are happening _ at how wonderful it is in fact to live in a free country,'' he said. ``Let's say a country that seeks to be ever more free.'' Tutu said he dreams of a day when diversity will be cherished in his country and liberties will be guaranteed. ``What we dream about is a country that will have a bill of rights that guarantees individual rights,'' he said. ``And then I hope that we would be absolutely libertarian, totally libertarian.''

DOC.HEAD: Party Host Charged In Death Of Teen Who Inhaled Laughing Gas
DOC.TEXT: A party host was charged with manslaughter in the death of a teen-age guest who apparently inhaled laughing gas, authorities said. Jonathan Sutton, 23, of suburban Homewood surrendered to Jefferson County authorities Friday night on charges stemming from the death of Kristi Ann Lowery, 18. He was released on $5,000 bond, a deputy said. The high school senior died May 20 after apparently inhaling undiluted nitrous oxide, commonly known as laughing gas, at the party, authorities said. The gas played a role in the woman's death, said Jefferson County Chief Deputy Coroner Jay Glass. When undiluted, nitrous oxide can cut off oyxgen to the brain or trigger irregular heartbeats, he said. Sutton surrendered on the advice of his attorney, J. Scott Boudreaux, who accused the district attorney's office of yielding to public pressure to bring charges. University of Alabama at Birmingham officials fired Sutton from his job as a university store clerk last week after he told Homewood police he had taken home the gas container linked to Miss Lowery's death, said university spokeswoman Pam Jones. Campus police charged him with theft of property, she said. Chief Deputy District Attorney Roger Brown said Boudreaux called him Friday asking if there were any other charges against his client. After being told Sutton was being charged with manslaughter, Boudreaux took him to the county jail, Brown said.

DOC.HEAD: Right Wing Vows to Resist End of White Minority Rule
LaserPhotos JOH1,3
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 11th graf, `He will...' to UPDATE with Tutu statement. Pickup pvs 12th graf, `Treurnicht's rally....' EDITS to TRIM
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of flag-waving whites staged the largest pro-apartheid rally since President F.W. de Klerk came to power last year and cheered a pledge by right-wing leaders to defend white power. Andries Treurnicht, leader of the main opposition Conservative Party, said whites would resist any effort to impose a black majority government and called for early elections to oust de Klerk. About 50,000 whites, including many women and children, attended the rally under deep blue skies at the Voortrekker Monument, a shrine to Afrikaner nationalism. Organizers claimed 150,000 people attended. ``Stay White'' and ``The struggle for a free state has begun,'' said some of the posters carried by protesters. ``The so-called New South Africa of forced integration, which the government is forcing on us, gives us no other choice but to defend our rights,'' Treurnicht said as the huge throng cheered and clapped. ``We shall not accept the threatened destruction of our nation's freedom, but will fight to restore that which has already been unjustly given away,'' he said. Treurnicht denounced Nelson Mandela and his African National Congress as Communists and terrorists. He claimed black nationalists would impose Communist dictatorship if they gained power. ``The ANC hates the Boer people and the white nation. They demand our land. They reject our right to exist,'' he said as the crowd screamed its approval. Mandela addressed a rally in the nearby black township of Atteridgeville, where he told about 40,000 cheering blacks that the right wing could not preserve white rule. ``Today, at this moment, in fact, Andries Treurnicht, that prophet of doom, is meeting over that hill ... in order to oppose the effort made by the ANC and the government to bring peace into this country,'' Mandela said. ``We say to Treurnicht, `We have defeated greater men than himself.' ``He will be defeated.'' In Cincinnati, Archbishop Desmond Tutu said if he had a chance to address the white demonstrators, he would have told them that freedom will prevail. ``I'd say to them you do have the right to hold that rally, but ultimately it is self-defeating,'' he said. ``What in fact are you seeking to do? You are seeking to carve out for yourself a separate freedom.'' ``The world has discovered that freedom is indivisible,'' said Tutu, South Africa's Anglican archbishop and Nobel peace laureate. Treurnicht's rally marked the launch of the right wing's ``Third Freedom Struggle,'' a reference to two 19th century wars against Britain. Treurnicht presented a Freedom Manifesto that called for nationwide struggle for a white state. He denounced de Klerk for moving to end white-minority rule and share power with the black majority. De Klerk, who came to power last August, legalized the ANC and released Mandela in February after 27 years in prison, but he has stopped short of supporting black majority rule. Treurnicht, who received a thunderous ovation from the crowd as he arrived in a horse-drawn carriage, was escorted by about 200 horsemen in a ``commando,'' or Afrikaner war party. The crowd waved hundreds of blue, red, white and green flags of the old Transvaal Republic, which was defeated by Britain in the Boer War. Afrikaners, whites of mainly Dutch descent, dominate South African politics. Scores of uniformed and armed members of ultra-right groups attended the rally, and some carried signs with slogans such as ``Hang Mandela.'' ``Of course I'm a racist. The blacks are racist. I know I'm better than blacks,'' said one right-winger who would not give his name. In Johannesburg, de Klerk predicted substantial changes in South Africa's relations with the rest of the world. He returned Saturday from 18 days of explaining his reform policies in Europe. ``I can report back to you today that substantial change in the relations of Europe with South Africa will come. And I believe through Europe, the international community will follow,'' he told about 1,000 cheering supporters at Jan Smuts Airport. The government cannot be forced to call elections until 1994 and de Klerk is confident he can carry out reforms and gain acceptance in that time. Treurnicht said little that was new and was vague on what the Conservatives would do if the government refuses to hold elections. He said his party would follow legal means of opposition. ``As long as there is a constitutional path open whereby we can regain political control, we will use that strategy to win a victory at the polling booth,'' he said. But Treurnicht did make veiled references to a white backlash if de Klerk ends white minority rule. ``Do not force our people to stand in your path and to challenge you to walk over us. ... There is no boat waiting for us in the harbor,'' he said. The government contends the right wing cannot stop the reforms begun by de Klerk. But officials admit privately that many whites are flocking to the Conservatives because of their opposition to ending white rule.

DOC.HEAD: Murder Suspect Returned to Delaware, Supplies Details in Third Slaying
DOC.TEXT: A young former fugitive who confessed to three slayings was returned to Delaware from Louisiana on Saturday, and ordered held without bond in the slayings of his parents 1{ years ago. Charles Cohen, 25, had eluded capture until Thursday when, facing simple battery and attempted robbery charges under an assumed name, he stunned spectators in a Louisiana courtroom with his confession. Cohen disappeared at the same time the bodies of his parents, Martin and Ethel, were discovered on Nov. 14, 1988, in their home in the northern Delaware town of Hockessin. Martin Cohen, 58, was director of the Delaware State Hospital, the state psychiatric hospital. His 63-year-old wife was an occupational therapist. Cohen has told police the identity of the third person he claims to have killed, Attorney General Charles Oberly told a news conference Saturday. Oberly would not release the identity of the person, but said the homicide did not occur in Delaware or a neighboring state. The state's top prosecutor said he expected police to confirm the details within 24 hours. Cohen managed to avoid capture despite publicity on the Fox network's weekly television show, ``America's Most Wanted.'' He had long hair and facial hair when he disappeared, but looked ``like an all-American boy'' when he was captured, New Castle County police chief Thomas Gordon said. Cohen, a former student at the University of Delaware, had been lead singer in a rock band in Illinois. Police were still tracing Cohen's path as a fugitive, but said he moved to New Orleans in mid-February from New York City. At the time of his arrest, Cohen identified himself as James McDowell, said Capt. Bob Garner, a sheriff's spokesman in Gretna, La. Cohen was closeted with New Castle County police from his arrival in Delaware around 1 p.m. until he was turned over for arraignment six hours later. Delaware Magistrate Paul Smith ordered Cohen held without bond on two first-degree murder counts, and Cohen was taken to Gander Hill Prison Saturday night, police said. His preliminary hearing was set for June 5.

DOC.HEAD: Severe Storm Whips Up Tornado, Knocks Out Power
DOC.TEXT: Rain, strong winds and lightning Saturday knocked out power to about 5,000 people, swelled rivers, blew over trees and whipped up a tornado, authorities said. No injuries or deaths were reported in the severe storm, which included a funnel cloud sighted in a small, rural community in Fayette County, about 30 miles southeast of Charleston. The storm left about 5,000 people in five counties without power before it subsided Saturday night. Meteorologist Barry Gooden of the National Weather Service said more rain was expected in the area Sunday. Jack Shaver, a spokesman for Appalachian Power Co., said high winds knocked trees into power lines and downed some poles. Emergency crews were sent out to restore service by early Sunday, he said. The state police said in a written statement that a tornado touched down in the Gauley Bridge community, where trees were blown over, power lines were downed and streets were covered by up to 3 feet of water. A tree knocked a power line onto the roof of the state police office at Gauley Bridge, cutting electricity and telephone service, the statement said. A dispatcher for the Fayette County Sheriff's Department said no storm-related injuries or deaths were reported. The Gauley Bridge fire department also had no such reports.

Mikhail S. Gorbachev says he'll keep hundreds of thousands of Soviet troops in eastern Germany and will review his policies on European arms control and security negotiations if a united Germany joins NATO. The Soviet president's comments Friday came six days before he discusses German unification with President Bush in Washington. It amounted to a new Kremlin bargaining chip, a message that the West would pay a high price for German membership in the Western military alliance. Gorbachev repeated the Soviet preference Friday that Germany belong to both the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. The Bush administration favors only NATO membership for a united Germany. Gorbachev also suggested Friday that a united Germany could follow France's lead and take part only in NATO political activities.

President Bush says he will use next week's summit with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to make the case for keeping Germany in NATO. The president, vacationing at his family compound at this oceanfront resort, late Friday night signed a $4 billion spending package that includes $720 million in emergency aid for Panama and Nicaragua. The president signed the measure despite misgivings about what the White House regards as pork-barrel add-ons by Congress and concerns about restrictions on his ability to enter into international agreements affecting NATO.

The Navy and independent analysts will conduct new tests over the next two weeks in the hopes of determining exactly what caused the explosion aboard the USS Iowa that claimed 47 lives. Congress called for the testing _ and the Navy said it would comply _ in light of congressional findings announced Friday that lawmakers said ``cast grave doubt'' on the Navy's official conclusion that a troubled sailor probably caused the blast last April 19, 1980.
