Officials of the General Accounting Office told members of the Senate Armed Services Committee on Friday that the Iowa explosion may well have been an accident. The Navy, in a report last September, concluded that gunner's mate Clayton Hartwig probably set off the April 19, 1989, explosion by inserting a chemical detonator between bags of powder.

Reform Judaism, one of the three major Jewish branches in the United States, is considering lifting age-old barriers against ordaining homosexuals as rabbis. But homosexual rabbis would be warned about dangers of making their sexual preference public. Reform Judaism, with 1.5 million members nationwide, would be the first U.S. Jewish branch to take allow homosexual rabbis. Adoption of the new ordination guidelines would go against traditional Jewish emphasis on procreation and aversion to homosexuality, dating to pre-biblical times. The proposal was drafted by a committee of the Central Conference of American Rabbis, representing the nation's 1,560 Reform rabbis, after four years of study, hearings and debate. Rabbi Joseph B. Glaser, the conference's executive vice president, said Friday he expects the proposal to be approved during the group's convention June 24-28 in Seattle.

DOC.HEAD: One Year Later: U.S. Businesses Hang On, Tourism Way Off
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial wires.
DOC.HEAD: Graphic CHINABIZ
DOC.TEXT: China's political repression hasn't altered the shift schedule for workers making Barbie doll accessories near Canton, McDonnell Douglas jetliners outside Shanghai or Jeep Cherokees in Beijing. But for other American businesses, ranging from defense contractor Grumman Corp. to tourism outfits like Lindblad Travel, the consequences of the year-old crackdown on dissent have been disappointing or worse. Their experiences show the mixed impact of the crushed Tiananmen uprising on the hundreds of U.S. companies and investors that have sought a foothold in the world's most populous nation since it emerged from isolation a decade ago. ``China has always been difficult to generalize about. It's a huge place,'' said Jerome Alan Cohen, a China specialist in the Hong Kong office of the international law firm Paul Weiss Rifkind Wharton & Garrison. ``Trade continues to go up, investment is plainly down,'' said Cohen, whose firm advises American and other foreign clients. ``You have fewer new projects coming into the pipeline. The results are only gradually becoming apparent.'' Other U.S-China specialists and business executives generally agree the combination of a political chill and a severe economic decline have made the country a more difficult place for foreign companies the past year. Many pending deals have stalled or unraveled, new investment has tumbled and the long-term outlook for improvement remains unclear. American visitors have slowed to a trickle. U.S.-Chinese commercial relations warmed somewhat on May 24, when President Bush extended China's most-favored-nation trading status for a year. The move, aimed at protecting $18 billion in two-way trade, was welcomed by U.S. farmers, toymakers and textile importers who stood to suffer had Bush done otherwise. American business attitudes toward China have hardened nevertheless. Any illusions that American entrepreneurs may have harbored about the potential of this market of a billion consumers were shattered by last June's violence. ``No one is saying, `Hey, China, there's something we haven't looked at yet,''' said Richard Brecher, manager of the investor advisory program for the United States-China Business Council, a Washington-based group that promotes American business interests in China. At the same time, Brecher said, ``I think there's a sense among most of the business community that we're dealing with a transitional government. It's a matter of holding on now, weathering the storm.'' No U.S. company operating in China before June has departed. Many say that after a short-lived disruption a year ago, their operations there are normal or close to it. At Mattel's two factories in southern Guangdong Province, for example, output of Barbie accessories, Disney items and preschool products accounts for about 20 percent of the toy giant's business, spokesman Glenn Bozarth said. Although the company could have switched production to other factories in Malaysia, Mexico or Europe under an emergency contingency plan last June, he said, ``we didn't invoke that because there wasn't a need.'' At McDonnell Douglas Corp.'s operation near Shanghai, where Chinese workers assemble MD-80 jetliners, the production schedule recently was extended by 20 aircraft. The operation, one of China's largest manufacturing ventures with a U.S. company, began in 1985 with a long-term contract to assemble 25 MD-80s. ``The fact is China has a very large requirement for airplanes,'' said Donald Hanson, spokesman for the company's Douglas Aircraft subsidiary. As for the political mood in the country, ``I don't think I can say it's had any major impact,'' he said. But some other high-profile ventures have slowed down. Chrysler Corp. has been forced to scale back the production schedule at its Jeep assembly plant in the Chinese capital, largely because of China's economic austerity controls, spokeswoman Karen Stewart said. ``We haven't gone backwards, but haven't gone forward as much as we would have liked,'' she said. ``With China, our policy is, we're there to stay for the long haul. You reach ebbs and flows.'' Grumman Corp. suffered when China scrapped a $256.8 million contract to modernize Chinese jet fighters with equipment built by the defense contractor. The mid-May cancellation was an indirect result of the Bush administration's suspension of military sales to the country last year. Still, said company spokesman Weyman B. Jones, Grumman remains a partner in a joint venture near Shanghai that plans to produce 500 fire trucks a year. Last year, U.S. companies signed 268 contracts for joint ventures and other projects, 43 more than a year earlier. But practically all 1989 contracts were completed before June and new ventures definitely have stalled. ``Between June and December, clearly there was a downturn,'' said Charles J. Conroy, a partner at Baker & McKenzie, a law firm that represents many businesses with interests in China. Conroy said some American companies have since begun to quietly explore new opportunities in China. But, he said, ``they're not megabillion-dollar investments like new airports or port infrastructure.'' Perhaps the biggest U.S. business victims of the past year have been tour operators. Most were overwhelmed by cancellations last summer, their busiest time of year, and face another dismal summer this year. United Airlines and Northwest Airlines, the two U.S. carriers to China, have both cut flights to one a week because of slack demand. ``The reason why people aren't going is not because they're afraid. It's moral indignation about what happened there,'' said Lars Eric Lindblad, whose Lindblad Travel company pioneered large-scale U.S. tours to China but folded in October, partly the result of mass cancellations. Lindblad nevertheless plans to lead a 484-passenger Ocean Cruise Lines tour to China on June 21, the first big U.S. vacation group to visit the country since the Tiananmen uprising. He said the tour is fully booked. Other tour operators said they've picked up some China business, mostly for the fall. Many expect tourism to resume in earnest eventually, but most are still smarting from the wallop they received a year ago. ``The group business just dropped. Everyone canceled,'' said Patricia Cunneen, head of EastQuest, a small New York-based travel concern that specializes in adventurous trips to Asia. Although her company survived, she said, ``A lot of businesses have closed. They call it the Tiananmen massacre here.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Meets With Scholars, Execs in Super Bowl Atmosphere
DOC.TEXT: When Mikhail Bernstam taught economics in Leningrad 20 years ago and expressed some distinctly non-Marxist ideas, his colleagues gave him puzzled, worried looks. ``My friends barely understood me. They thought I was crazy,'' says Bernstam, now a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution on the Stanford University campus. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's post-summit visit Monday to Hoover, a longtime bastion of anti-Communism, will give Bernstam the chance, finally, to offer his ``crazy'' notions to a more receptive countryman. Bernstam and five other scholars at Hoover _ the think tank that spawned the economic principles and some key figures in the Reagan and Bush administrations _ will offer papers to Gorbachev suggesting ways of solving the Soviet Union's enormous economic problems. If Gorbachev is coming to Stanford for advice and San Francisco for business, he'll find plenty of people eager to accommodate him _ though more than a few are skeptical of the success of his reform program. The academic and corporate communities playing host to Gorbachev expect him to make a strong pitch for support in converting the Soviet economy to a free-market system. The visit has charged the Bay area with a Super Bowl atmosphere, sending corporate executives scrambling for a chance to dine with him at a business luncheon _ some willing to pay thousands of dollars for a ticket. Fifteen companies co-sponsoring the event are paying $2,000 for two seats each, and up to $500 for additional seats. Labor leaders are complaining they may be left out. Phone lines are jammed at the Soviet consulate, Stanford, the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce and City Hall. T-shirts with Gorbachev's image and tackier souvenirs _ a ``Communist Party Animal'' T-shirt _ already are on sale, and billboards are planned to welcome the Soviet leader in the city and on the highways. ``This may even exceed the Super Bowl,'' predicted Stanford spokesman Joel Shurkin, who said the university had been bombarded with requests by 5,000 reporters to cover Gorbachev's speech at the 1,700-seat Memorial Auditorium. A lottery is planned to determine who gets to go, with preference to Stanford faculty and students. Silicon Valley is experiencing a ``Gorbasm,'' said Mark Muchnik, president of Global Development Corp., who has organized a Soviet Silicon Summit to encourage high-tech trade between the countries. Raisa Gorbachev's planned visit to an Oakland-based program that helps Soviet children doomed by heart defects, and the possibility that she'll visit some of the area's big tourist attractions, has sparked more excitement. ``Lots of people have invited her ... institutions, hospitals, homes,'' said Charlotte Mailliard Swig, San Francisco's chief of protocol. Armenians, Latvians, Estonians and Lithuanians are planning protests, some coming from hundreds of miles away to register complaints about Soviet policies. Gorbachev's audience at the luncheon in San Francisco will be with executives of 150 major companies in California, Washington and Oregon. At his request, the companies will represent a variety of industries _ telecommunications, computers, agribusiness, food processing, construction, oil, banking, hotels and tourism. Gorbachev's aides chose the companies from a list submitted by the Chamber of Commerce, which is co-host of the luncheon with Mayor Art Agnos and California Gov. George Deukmejian. ``The Soviets have an interest in positioning the Asian part of their country as a Pacific Rim player,'' said Carol Piasente, spokeswoman for the Chamber of Commerce. ``The purpose of this luncheon is to build a relationship between the West Coast companies and the Far Eastern part of the Soviet Union.'' Executives of some companies with longstanding ties to the Soviet Union, including AT&T, BankAmerica, Hewlett-Packard and Chevron, will attend the luncheon. Rep. Tom Campbell, R-Calif., said the Soviets have ``a desperate need'' for computers, fax machines, modems and other high-tech office equipment that are attracting them to Silicon Valley. And the interest is mutual. ``We are very concerned about losing one of the largest markets we'll ever see,'' said Campbell, who fears European and Asian companies will swoop in on the Soviets if American firms move too slowly. ``I don't see any risk to our defense and I do see economic benefits. One of the great dreams is we'll be so integrated economically that nobody would benefit from an attack,'' he said. Gorbachev's visit is ``more than a public relations gesture,'' said Bill Johnston, Palo Alto-based Hewlett-Packard's director of international planning and administration. ``He is clearly wooing the West, and certainly this area. He's trying to get his economy squared away and attract U.S. manufacturing expertise to the Soviet Union.'' Hewlett-Packard has had an office in Moscow for 18 years, and last week joined four other U.S. companies in a consortium with three Soviet health and medical research ministries. ``There are a lot of problems,'' Johnston said. ``The currency is a major issue. There is still considerable political and economic uncertainty, and the two are interlocked. They have a mess on their hands.'' To help Gorbachev clean up the mess, Hoover scholars will offer their ideas and willingness to join with Soviet officials to reshape the country. The one-page summaries offered to Gorbachev, who was lured to Hoover by former Secretary of State George Shultz, are written in Russian and will be followed by longer papers for his aides. ``We don't want to be so presumptive to suggest that we want to tell him how to run his country,'' said Hoover Director John Raisian. ``But we want to be cooperative and be prepared to have an offer (of assistance) ready if we were welcomed to have one.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wednesday AMs, May 30

DOC.HEAD: Baltic Tensions Hang Over Summit Like a Cloud
DOC.TEXT: A Baltic cloud hangs over the U.S.-Soviet summit as pressure builds on Lithuania to suspend its declaration of independence and return, at least temporarily, to the Soviet fold. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Bush, both hopeful of making progress on arms control and other issues, may find the Baltics a needling irritant when they begin a four-day summit Thursday. But Gorbachev may be moving to disperse what Bush calls ``a cloud of tension'' over the three Baltic republics' proclamations of independence. If Gorbachev succeeds, the summit forecast could be much sunnier. Late last week, Gorbachev said that if Lithuania suspended its March 11 declaration he would lift his punishing economic embargo and even compensate Lithuanians for its damage. The Soviet president also offered a road map for Lithuanian independence, saying it could be achieved under Kremlin rules within two years, three years earlier than he had said previously. In a meeting with Lithuanian lawmakers in Moscow, Gorbachev did not repeat his previous insistence that independence be sought only under the terms of a Soviet secession law. That law, which Baltic leaders dub ``the law to prevent secession,'' permits independence only after a five-year cooling-off period. But Gorbachev paired last week's carrot with a heavy stick, vowing to impose direct presidential rule on Lithuania if the independence declaration was not suspended. If he imposed presidential rule, Gorbachev could disband Lithuania's parliament, its first freely elected legislature in 50 years, replace the Lithuanian government with Moscow-appointed officials, and impose martial law. The Lithuanian parliament has so far offered only to suspend the effect of laws to implement independence and has adamantly refused to freeze the independence declaration itself. Baltic-Americans will use the summit to dramatize the cause of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, all of which lost their independence in a 1940 secret deal between Josef Stalin and Adolf Hitler. A rally is planned in Lafayette Park across from the White House before Gorbachev's arrival. One Lithuanian group will demonstrate outside the Soviet Embassy. Another will conduct a candlelight vigil there. Two mass demonstrations are planned on the steps of the Capitol. Bush acknowledged last week that the independence crisis ``certainly puts some tension on the summit'' and said he was ``unhappy about the state of play in the Baltics.'' But Bush has also said repeatedly that his discussions with Gorbachev on nuclear arms control are too important to be derailed. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said recently the independence crisis does cast a long shadow. But he says the administration is determined to prevent the summit's eclipse. ``There is too much at stake ... to dismiss cavalierly the potential for progress'' in U.S.-Soviet relations, Baker said. The euphoria that flared from Baltic ex-patriots worldwide when Lithuania issued its ringing declaration of independence evaporated in the warning rumble of Soviet tanks through the streets of Vilnius and in Gorbachev's orders to slow to a trickle the flow of oil and natural gas into the republic. But the Soviet economic embargo did not discourage the thirst for independence there or in neighboring Latvia and Estonia. The Estonian parliament on March 30 branded the Soviet Union an occupying power and vowed to restore full independence over time. On May 4, the Latvian parliament followed suit, declaring independence while trying to avoid an outright clash with Moscow by postponing the effective date pending completion of negotiations. Baltic leaders have contended that agreeing to Gorbachev's original demand that they seek independence under Soviet law would be to concede their incorporation into the Soviet Union was legal in the first place. ``Admitting that we must quit the Soviet Union under Soviet law would be to lose our most important asset, our status as an occupied country,'' said Tunne V. Kelam, chairman of the Council of Estonia, the executive committee of Estonia's independent parliament. ``When you are raped and robbed, you cannot ask for legal divorce; you were never married,'' Kelam said in an interview during a recent U.S. visit. The three Baltic republics have long been known in conservative circles in the United States as ``the captive nations.'' Outside the Baltic-American community, the most intense domestic pressure on Bush to embrace the independence cause has come from this direction. Bush and Baker have voiced a double-edged policy toward the Baltics: _Over 50 years, the United States has never recognized the forced incorporation of the three republics into the Soviet Union. It does not do so now. _But the United States will not extend formal diplomatic recognition until those republics control their own territory, institutions and political destiny. With a high-stakes agenda before him, Bush decided not to impose sanctions against the Soviets to make Gorbachev pay a price for his embargo against Lithuania. Upset by that decision, the Senate on May 2 voted 73-24 to put Bush on notice that congressional approval of a new U.S.-Soviet trade agreement prized by Moscow is unlikely until the embargo is lifted and talks begin on Lithuanian independence. Kazimiera Prunskiene, an economist and Lithuania's elected prime minister, said repeatedly during a U.S. visit last month that the West held the key to independence. Her prescription: Increase economic and political pressure on Gorbachev to free the Baltic republics while at the same time encouraging the democratic reforms fostered by Gorbachev's glasnost (openness) and perestroika (economic restructuring). A democratized Soviet Union, she reasons, will not cling to formerly independent nations annexed against their peoples' will. Dmitri Simes, an exiled Soviet scholar who is a senior associate of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, contends the real choice Gorbachev faces is not between perestroika and Lithuanian independence but between building Soviet democracy and saving the vast and rickety Soviet domain. But many Western leaders fault Lithuania for moving too rapidly, for giving fuel to Gorbachev's conservative opposition. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and French President Francois Mitterrand have urged Lithuania to suspend its declaration of independence and follow the dictates of the Soviet independence law. The Bush administration has all but endorsed this approach, nudging the Baltic republics to accept it. Gorbachev told Baker in Moscow earlier in the month that domestic pressures are such that he does not have ``a lot of room to maneuver'' on the Baltic crisis. There the stalemate stands. Vytautas Landsbergis, the president of the Lithuanian parliament, urged his countrymen last week to hold on and to survive ``as though we were in a surrounded fortress.'' Meanwhile, he and the leaders of Latvia and Estonia have appealed to Bush and Gorbachev ``to take our problems into their hearts'' as they view the world from the summit's heights.

DOC.HEAD: Vacation Season Sizzles With a Deluge of Mega-Movies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, Summer moviegoers ... Aug. 24., to UPDATE that `Wild at Heart' was top prize winner at Cannes.
DOC.TEXT: This summer's movie season is so competitive that film studios have been juggling release dates as if they were auditioning for the circus. With Madonna as a co-star and cameos by such stars as Dustin Hoffman and James Caan, ``Dick Tracy'' is the most hyped summer extravaganza. But it's going up against such probable hits as ``Total Recall,'' the science-fiction adventure starring Arnold Schwarzenegger, one of the movie industry's biggest box-office draws, and ``Back to the Future III,'' the last in the Michael J. Fox trilogy. There are other eagerly anticipated summer movies as well: ``Another 48 HRS.,'' sequel to the Eddie Murphy-Nick Nolte cop caper; Tom Cruise's car racing movie, ``Days of Thunder''; and ``Die Hard 2,'' a sequel to the Bruce Willis thriller. ``Total Recall,'' directed by Paul Verhoeven, whose most recent smash was 1987's futuristic thriller ``Robocop,'' was once set to open against ``Dick Tracy'' on June 15. Now it will debut June 1. ``Back to the Future III'' opened Friday to good reviews. ``Dick Tracy,'' starring and directed by Warren Beatty, will see whether audiences staggered by last summer's ``Batman'' are ready for another film inspired by a comic book. It also remains to be seen if Beatty, who has made only two movies in nine years, is a box-office draw. The Walt Disney Co.'s fortunes for the season are riding on ``Dick Tracy'' as well as the sci-fi ``Arachnophobia,'' ``Ducktales _ The Movie'' and the reissue of the classic ``Jungle Book.'' ``The Adventures of Ford Fairlane,'' stand-up comic Andrew Dice Clay's portrayal of a rock 'n' roll detective, originally slotted for a May and then a June premiere, won't arrive until July. Paramount Pictures moved ``Another 48 HRS.'' from June 27 to June 8, switching places with the studio's delayed ``Days of Thunder.'' Studio distribution executives worry 23,000 domestic screens aren't enough for all this summer's titles, which include about 40 major releases. And some wonder whether all the commotion is really worth it. ``It is not a good thing to rush films to the screen,'' said Robert Zemeckis, the director of ``Back to the Future Part III,'' which had been set to open Friday by Universal Pictures for more than a year. Universal considers the Memorial Day weekend, traditionally a heavy movie-going weekend, to be one of the best spots to launch a film with this much anticipation. Summer moviegoers have a tremendous choice, from the Mel Gibson-Goldie Hawn romantic adventure-comedy ``Bird on a Wire,'' which opened May 18 to good box office but mixed reviews, to David Lynch's ``Wild at Heart,'' opening Aug. 24, which won the top prize at the recent Cannes Film Festival. ``I think it's going to be a little wilder and a little woolier this summer,'' said Sid Ganis, president of Paramount's motion picture group. ``There are lots of big, good summer films opening this year.'' While most of the season's movies probably won't send critics scurrying for superlatives, the bumper crop is among the costliest ever. ``Total Recall'' cost a reported $60 million. ``Die Hard 2,'' with Willis trying to rescue his wife in an airport, reportedly burned up just a few dollars less. ``Days of Thunder,'' dubbed by some ``Top Car'' because it seems to resemble ``Top Gun,'' has raced through $50 million. With so much money being thrown at the screen in so few weeks, it's certain that several high-ticket movies will unspool to mostly empty houses. Will the busts include ``Robocop 2,'' ``Gremlins 2: The New Batch,'' ``Flight of the Intruder'' or ``Fire Birds,'' which opened Friday to poor reviews? Or will these take off, leaving other efforts in their wake? If there are any sure bets this summer _ and there aren't many, according to studio insiders _ they include ``Days of Thunder,'' ``Another 48 HRS.,'' ``Die Hard 2,'' ``Total Recall'' and ``Back to the Future Part III.'' A lot of prognosticators are keen on Beatty's ``Dick Tracy,'' but others aren't convinced the 53-year-old ``Ishtar'' veteran still has the directorial talent he showed in ``Reds,'' or the appeal he had years ago in ``Bonnie and Clyde'' and ``Shampoo.'' According to an informal poll of studio executives, possible summer sleepers include ``Presumed Innocent,'' ``Ghost,'' ``Problem Child'' and ``Arachnophobia.'' Disney, which has appended the new Roger Rabbit short ``Roller Coaster Rabbit'' to ``Dick Tracy,'' hopes audiences will be attracted to the studio's sequel-free lineup. ``We don't have any Roman numerals after any of our pictures,'' said Dick Cook, president of Disney's Buena Vista Pictures Distribution. To promote ``The Adventures of Ford Fairlane,'' 20th Century Fox will run trailers for the film with ``Die Hard 2,'' which opens July 4. The strategy, said Tom Sherak, president of domestic marketing and distribution for Fox, is to make Clay a more familiar face in Middle America. ``As the studios come up with better and better films, the pressure on the marketing and distribution people has never been greater,'' Sherak said. Si Kornblitt, Universal's executive vice president of worldwide marketing, said opening Bill Cosby's ``Ghost Dad'' opposite ``Days of Thunder'' might not be as masochistic as it looks. ``It takes guts to go against Tom Cruise, but we think we've got the picture to do it,'' he said. ``Ghost Dad,'' directed by Sidney Poitier, stars Cosby as a corporate father who spends more time in the office than at home. He drowns and then spends a few days looking for his body while putting together a merger and visiting his children. Taking a cue from Disney's move last summer of pitting ``Honey, I Shrunk the Kids'' against ``Batman,'' Universal hopes the family theme of ``Ghost Dad'' will appeal to audiences not so keen on car racing or Schwarzenegger's muscles. The action-adventure glut may benefit Samuel Goldwyn Co., whose ``Wild at Heart'' might offer relief to audiences shell-shocked from a summer of exploding bodies and car chases. ``There is an appetite driven by `Robocop,' `Gremlins' and `48 HRS.' for a distinctive offering _ a film that is neither a sequel nor a generic copy,'' said Tom Rothman, Goldwyn's head of worldwide production. He said just as TV viewers tuned into David Lynch's ``Twin Peaks'' because they were weary of network drivel, movie patrons should flock to Lynch's offbeat look at two young lovers on the road. Last summer was the richest in Hollywood history, with more than $2.04 billion worth of tickets sold from Memorial Day through Labor Day. The 1989 summer was exceptional because in an era of $6 tickets, admissions were up to more than 456 million, an increase of 40 million tickets from the previous summer. Five of last summer's films _ ``Batman,'' ``Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade,'' ``Lethal Weapon 2,'' ``Honey, I Shrunk the Kids'' and ``Ghostbusters II'' _ made more than $100 million apiece, with ``Batman'' becoming the fifth most popular film in movie history. This summer could top last year's. ``We think this summer on paper looks like it's going to be huge,'' said Greg Rutkowski, vice president of West operations for AMC Theatres, the nation's second-largest theater chain. ``The feeling in our company is it's going to be every bit as big as last summer. And we don't think business will be limited to four or five films as it was last summer.''

DOC.HEAD: Don't Expect First Ladies To Trade Recipes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf to include words ``tries to''; PICKS UP 9th graf, ``Barbara Bush ... her wit.''
DOC.TEXT: The first time Raisa Gorbachev met Barbara Bush, the two were sharing a limousine during the rush of events that surrounded the 1987 Washington summit between President Reagan and Raisa's husband, Mikhail. Mrs. Gorbachev apparently had been briefed that the wife of the then-vice president was a white-haired, grandmotherly homemaker. ``Oh, Barbara, I have to share with you a wonderful recipe for blueberry pie,'' Mrs. Gorbachev, a doctor of philosophy, told her hostess, the best known dropout from the Smith College Class of '47. The Soviet visitor described a rudimentary recipe that sounded as if it came from a script. Barbara Bush listened, then asked skeptically, ``Raisa, do you cook at home?'' ``Well, yes, sometimes, I do,'' replied Mrs. Gorbachev. ``Well, I never cook at home so let's talk about something else,'' said Mrs. Bush, and the two women proceeded to converse in a more relaxed _ and less stilted _ fashion. The anecdote, which Mrs. Bush herself enjoys telling, makes two points: _Raisa Gorbachev, ever the Marxist lecturer, tries to do her homework before she comes to a summit. _Barbara Bush is never at a loss for words, and no one, however high or mighty, is immune from her wit. The two first ladies will share the spotlight with their husbands Thursday when Bush welcomes Gorbachev to the White House. The wives will repair to the private residence for tea while their husbands talk in the Oval Office. That evening, the Bushes will play host to the Gorbachevs at a black-tie dinner. Friday, the first ladies will fly to Wellesley College in Massachusetts, where both will address the school's commencement. That night, the Gorbachevs will be hosts for the Bushes for dinner at the Soviet Embassy. Saturday, the women probably will accompany their husbands to Camp David, the presidential retreat in the Maryland mountains 75 miles away. Sunday, the Gorbachevs will fly to Minneapolis, where she will visit with a middle-class family, and then to California. Sharing the Wellesley podium was Mrs. Bush's idea. She tendered the invitation long before 150 seniors signed a petition questioning her selection as commencement speaker. The seniors challenged the wisdom of honoring ``a woman who has gained recognition through the achievements of her husband.'' Prominent feminists responded that they had no quarrel with the way Mrs. Bush chose to lead her life. Mrs. Bush herself called it ``no big deal. Even I was 20 once.'' Barbara Bush, 64, is a publisher's daughter from Rye, N.Y., who dropped out of college in 1944 to marry her teen-age sweetheart, George, a Navy pilot and war hero. She followed him to Yale and then Texas for a life in the oil fields. Apart from a wartime summer job in a bolt factory and a part-time stint at the Yale Co-op, Mrs. Bush devoted herself to home and family, raising five children _ a sixth, daughter Robin, died of leukemia when she was 3 years old _ and holding the family together through 29 moves in her husband's peripatetic career in business, politics and diplomacy. A lifelong volunteer, she adopted literacy as her personal cause when Bush became vice president in 1981. Since he was elected president 16 months ago, she has spoken out on the plight of AIDS victims but has avoided delivering her views in public on abortion and other controversial issues. Her down-to-earth ways, her obvious love of family, her full-size figure and her white hair have all endeared her to Americans across the political spectrum. Raisa Gorbachev, 58, is the Siberian-born daughter of a railway worker. She attended the Soviet Union's top academic institution, Moscow State University, where she met her future husband, a law student who lived in the same hostel. While her husband rose through the party ranks, she taught school and wrote a pioneering, sociology-like dissertation on life in rural Stavropol's collective farms. The Gorbachevs are known to have a daughter, who is a physician, and are believed to also have a son. When Gorbachev became the Communist Party's agriculture secretary in 1978, she joined the philosophy faculty at Moscow State. She stepped down when her husband became the party's general secretary in 1985. Strong-willed and stylish _ the British press once dubbed her ``Soviet realism's answer to Princess Diana'' _ she has been in the public eye far more than the wives of past Soviet leaders. While the coverage of her foreign trips has been far less extensive at home than abroad, her penchant for finer living has aroused some enmity. One of her husband's best-known opponents, maverick Boris Yeltsin, even criticized her in a 1987 speech to party leaders. Soon thereafter, Yeltsin was stripped of his party office. However Mrs. Bush and Mrs. Gorbachev get along, their relations will likely be better than those between Nancy Reagan and the Soviet first lady. The Nancy-Raisa feud was played out in soap opera fashion at summits whenever they met _ and once when they didn't. Mrs. Gorbachev showed up unexpectedly in Reykjavik, Iceland, for the hurriedly called 1986 summit while Mrs. Reagan, who had been told her counterpart would not come, stayed home. On her 1987 visit to Washington, Mrs. Gorbachev kept the Reagan White House guessing about her schedule. Mrs. Reagan had trouble pinning her down for a White House tour, and when she did come, she described the presidential mansion as more of ``a museum of American history'' than ``a regular house.'' In Moscow during the June 1988 summit, Mrs. Reagan described her testy relationship with Mrs. Gorbachev as a ``Mexican standoff.'' In her 1989 memoirs, ``My Turn,'' Mrs. Reagan wrote: ``My fundamental impression of Raisa Gorbachev was that she never stopped talking. Or lecturing, to be more accurate.'' As part of the Gorbachevs' tour of the United States, he is said to be trying to set up a breakfast meeting with Reagan in San Francisco. Whether Mrs. Reagan and Mrs. Gorbachev would join their husbands isn't known.

DOC.HEAD: Squeal of Fortune and Pig-Casso Art
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Expo runs June 2-4. PeTA is cq in 18th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Never let it be said that the swine industry lacks a sense of showmanship. The 1990 World Pork Expo will boast a ``Squeal of Fortune'' game, a ``Pig-Casso'' art show, pig races and exhibitions of Chinese swine with skin more crumpled than a commuter's suit on a steamy day. The show opens Saturday at the Iowa State Fairgrounds and is expected to attract more than 100,000 visitors, including representatives from about 60 countries, before it winds down on June 4. Those forking over the $5-a-person admission fee also will have a chance to pig out on more than 13 tons of pork to be dished out at the Big Grill _ a barbecue pit that's almost as long as a football field _ where about 200 volunteers will use pitchforks to tend to the ham, ribs and pork loins. Organizers hope to set a record for the world's largest pork barbecue, breaking the 12-ton mark set at last year's expo. This year's festivities come as hog farmers deal with concerns that such issues as food safety and animal rights could endanger their recently strong business. Pork prices are at heights last seen nearly eight years ago and profits have been steadily rising this year, according to Dan O'Brien, an economist at Iowa State University who specializes in livestock markets. The university's monthly survey of livestock operation profits says the most common hog farm in Iowa earned a profit of nearly $30 a head in April, compared with $12.56 a head in January. ``The mood of the industry has to be excited,'' says Mike Wehler, who raises hogs near Plain, Wis., and is president of the National Pork Producers Council, the nation's leading pork trade group. ``We could very well be headed for an all-time record year in terms of prices.'' With things going so well, the industry is wary of anything that could reverse the trend. ``From the producers standpoint, deterioration of the market is the No. 1 fear,'' Wehler says. Two primary concerns are food safety and animal rights. Not only are consumers asking more and more questions about the chemicals in their food, but they also are organizing boycotts. Memories of last year's alar uproar that hurt apple sales and halted use of the chemical are fresh in the minds of farmers. The pork industry has its own memories of the nitrite scare that plagued bacon sales a decade ago. ``We've all seen what can happen with demand for a product,'' Wehler says. In an attempt to avoid becoming a target again, the pork council has organized a quality assurance program to encourage farmers to adopt safe practices in the use of livestock medication and to highlight the dangers posed by tainted feed. The animal rights movement also is on the mind of livestock producers, especially as protests have spread to farm country. In Iowa this spring, pickets protested the treatment of animals during an appearance of the Moscow Circus at Ames. On Mothers Day, animal-rights activists marched outside a Des Moines dairy company to complain that calves are separated from their mothers and ill-treated. The cover of the May-June edition of PeTA News, a publication of the Washington-based People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, has a picture of a pig and a headline, ``Did Your `Food' Have a Face?'' The World Pork Expo has scheduled a seminar on animal rights. ``More and more producers need to know what the issue is and what it isn't,'' says pork council spokesman Charles Harness. Pork producers tend to label the issue one of ``animal care'' or ``animal welfare.'' ``We certainly believe in the proper treatment of animals. It's the ethical and moral thing to do,'' Harness says. ``We simply do not agree that animals have rights equal to humans.'' Wehler says the industry worries about ``extremists who want to remove meat from our diet.'' The pork council will use proceeds from the sale of raffle tickets in its Squeal of Fortune $25,000 sweepstakes to support efforts on behalf of producers in animal welfare, food safety and other industry issues. For those who just love pigs for pigs sake, there will be a competition for prizes in the Pig-Casso show of pig-oriented art or a chance to gawk at the entries featuring pigs in a variety of shapes and forms.

DOC.HEAD: Futures Brokers Hail Electronic Trading Pact
DOC.TEXT: Commodity brokers and their customers are the big winners in the agreement by Chicago's giant futures exchanges to share an electronic trading system. The unusual pact between the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange means the futures industry will avoid the high costs of duplicate networks _ costs that ultimately would be passed on to customers _ and the hassle of learning two systems. David Vogel, chairman of the Futures Industry Association, also agreed with the benefit touted by the exchanges when they announced the agreement this past Wednesday: by uniting instead of competing, the Chicago markets stand a better chance of maintaining their dominance of global futures trading as financial markets everywhere move toward round-the-clock trading. ``It looks like 24-hour electronic trading is going to come about and it will be multinational and competitive in nature,'' said Vogel, chief executive officer of LIT America Inc., a New York futures trading concern. ``I think it's very important that Americans be competitive here,'' he said. Ever since the Merc developed world currency futures in the early 1970s, touching off a worldwide explosion of financial futures and options products, the Chicago exchanges have seen global access as the key to continued U.S. leadership in the expanding marketplace. The problem can be boiled down to two words: time zones. Tokyo is about 16 hours ahead of Chicago, and London is six hours ahead. To attract business from both of those important financial centers, the Chicago markets ideally would have to be open around the clock. The Board of Trade initiated a three-hour night trading session for interest-rate futures early in 1987 to catch the opening of the Japanese business day. The exchange has declared night trading a success but concedes it would be impractical to keep its trading floor open 24 hours. In the fall of 1987, the Merc announced a different approach. In partnership with London-based Reuters Holdings PLC, the Merc would create an automated trading system called Globex that would operate when its trading floor is closed. Globex would enable traders around the world to buy and sell the Merc's products _ and those of other exchanges that chose to participate _ by tapping orders into computer terminals supplied by Reuters. The orders would be matched by a central computer, often called a ``black box.'' The Board of Trade initially opposed the concept and asked regulators to block it. But early last year the Board of Trade said it would develop its own electronic trading system, dubbed Aurora. Unlike the blind trade-matching technology of Globex, Aurora's screen would mimic a commodity trading pit and enable users to select their trading partners. The Board of Trade contended this was a superior concept and earmarked $25 million to develop the system. But critics said Aurora would be more susceptible to trading abuse. Many brokers, led by the Futures Industry Association, clamored for a single system. Last May, the exchanges agreed to explore the possibility of a shared system. ``The FIA ... from the very beginning promoted this dialogue and made it very clear that (a single or shared system) is what they desire,'' Vogel said. The agreement announced by the exchanges does not explain how the system will be shared. But it does say Reuters will be involved, prompting speculation it will be a black box system and that Aurora will exist only as a name under which the Board of Trade's products will be offered. The exchanges said they expect the system to be fully operational by November.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Automakers: Small Step into Potentially Huge Soviet Market
DOC.TEXT: Japan's motor vehicle exports to the Soviet Union quadrupled last year, but the nation's big carmakers don't expect a sudden breakthrough into the market even though local production falls millions short of pent-up demand. The main barrier for Japanese automakers _ as it has been for many Western businesses _ is that the Soviet ruble is not convertible into other currencies, making it difficult to repatriate any profits. Other problems include lack of repair facilities and other infrastructure-related matters, poor coordination among auto-related industries and outdated Soviet factories. But in a reflection of interest in the Soviet market, 10 Japanese automakers participated in a seven-day Japan auto industry exhibition in Moscow in April. It was the first industrial fair held solely by Japanese companies in the Soviet Union, said Takashi Murakami, an official of the Japan Association for Trade with the Soviet Union and Socialist Countries of Europe. Although prospects seem poor now, the Soviet market offers a powerful lure. Demand is estimated at 4 million cars a year, but only 1.2 million are produced. Soviet citizens wait several years just to get on a list to buy a car and then have to wait another year for delivery. Japan exported 4,561 motor vehicles to the Soviet Union last year, up from 1,313 in 1988, according to the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association. More than 90 percent of the 1989 total were buses and trucks. Japan's vehicle exports to the Soviet Union are dwarfed by its shipments to the United States, which took 2.43 million units last year. Murakami said Japan's Soviet vehicle exports will remain in the range of 4,000 to 5,000 a year because Soviet officials are giving higher priority to other consumer goods such as food and clothing. An official at Toyota, Japan's biggest automaker, said the company exported 2,541 vehicles, including 409 passenger cars, to the Soviet Union in 1989. Toyota participated in the Moscow industry exhibition in April but did not make a specific deal, the official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Mazda Motor Corp., Japan's fourth-largest automaker, recently said it will export its first cars to the Soviet Union _ 210 Mazda 323s, destined for a Soviet timber complex in Ilimsk, Siberia. Nissan Motor Corp., the No. 2 automaker, expects no sudden surge of exports in the near future, but demand could be strong in the long run, said a company official who spoke on condition of anonymity. Mitsui and Co., a big trading company which participated in the Moscow exhibition, expects auto exports to increase gradually along with the introduction of a market economy in the Soviet Union, according to a Mitsui official who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``It will be years before a (Soviet) individual can buy a new foreign car, though many are wanting one now,'' said the Mitsui official.

DOC.HEAD: Opposite Roads for Stocks, Real Estate
DOC.TEXT: The worlds of two of the nation's most popular investments _ stocks and real estate _ are about as far apart as they can get right now. The stock market has been forging ahead, reaching a succession of record highs over the past two weeks. The real estate and housing markets, on the other hand, are suffering a protracted period of weakness that extends into many parts of the country. Analysts are quick to point out that this divergence is by no means unique. In the 1970s, for example, real estate prices surged ahead on the crest of a wave of inflation, while the stock market languished for much of the time. In theory, at least, financial observers say the current disparity could persist for a similarly long time. But sooner or later, many feel, ripple effects from either market could exert an influence on the other. Just how and when that might occur is a subject of much debate on Wall Street. One theory holds that slumping real estate prices and housing starts reflect a squeeze on credit that somehow has failed to make an impression yet on investors in the stock market, but that sooner or later will prove impossible to ignore. On the opposite side of the argument, optimists say the woes of real estate and construction may well prompt the Federal Reserve eventually to adopt a stimulative credit policy, stoking the stock and bond markets with fuel for further gains. ``A drop in construction and real estate activity cuts a wide swath,'' said Michael Sherman, investment strategist at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ``It hits almost every owner of real estate, almost every vendor in the construction industry, and nearly every lender in the financial markets. The only beneficiaries are those few people who have held back before buying or building. ``In short, a major downturn in this area would be broadly deflationary, and the Fed would know that. ``As a consequence, if the current weakness we see emerging in construction continues and accelerates, monetary policy will have to change. As it does, it will enhance the outlook for financial assets.'' Talk of that sort helped stock prices extend their spring rally in the past week. Even with a setback on Friday, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 1.01 to 2,820.92, recording its fourth consecutive weekly gain. The New York Stock Exchange composite index edged up 0.16 to 193.71; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 5.29 to 453.60 and the American Stock Exchange market value index was up 3.52 at 359.84. Volume on the Big Board averaged 163.47 million shares a day, against 175.65 million the week before. In the eyes of James Grant, a newsletter publisher and vocal bear on the financial outlook, stocks look vulnerable to some of the same problems that have hurt real estate. ``The stock market is a creature of credit,'' he writes in the issue of Grant's Interest Rate Observer published Friday. ``It cares about the Treasury market. It depends even more on the cost and availability of business credit. ``The expansion of credit tends to be bullish, and the contraction of credit tends to be bearish. In the 1980s, reckless lenders expanded credit. In the 1990s, timid lenders will shrink it. ``It is only 1990, but the contraction is under way. It therefore stands to reason that stock prices are headed lower.''

DOC.HEAD: Boesky Puts on Show as Witness, More Dirty Details Emerge
DOC.TEXT: He lied more than he could remember, got a big tax break from cheating the stock market, kept an illegal fortune out of government hands and bribed fellow felons with pocket change to do his dirty laundry. Those were among the new details that embellished the portrait of former stock speculator Ivan F. Boesky under harsh questioning in a Manhattan federal courtroom this past week, and he wasn't even on trial. The gaunt 53-year-old inside trader, central figure in the biggest criminal scandal in Wall Street history, premiered as a star prosecution witness in the trial of John A. Mulheren Jr., a former friend and Wall Street professional accused of securities fraud. Boesky's first public appearance since completing a federal prison term last month had been eagerly awaited, largely because it finally afforded someone he'd implicated in his crimes the opportunity to confront him. The faceoff between Boesky and Mulheren's attorney Thomas Puccio, riddled with terse and acidic exchanges, provided more drama than scriptwriters for ``L.A. Law'' could ever have concocted. It was a defense lawyer's dream. Puccio spent hours seeking to skewer Boesky's moral values and his self-portrait as a reformed, impoverished and humbled ex-baron of the stock market who'd paid his debt to society. The witness admitted he'd lied repeatedly to investigators before his plea bargain and took a tax deduction for half his $100 million insider trading settlement with the government in 1986. He also admitted the settlement didn't include profits he'd earned from other insider trading, which by some estimates total many millions of dollars. One of the more telling admissions came in a seemingly innocuous detail about his life in the Lompoc federal prison camp, where he spent two years. Asked if he'd broken any rules there, Boesky admitted improperly paying other inmates quarters to wash his clothes. The New York tabloid press seized on it. ``Boesky Cleans Up'' and ``Two-Bit Boesky'' screamed the headlines in the New York Post. The Daily News called it ``Ivan's Dirty Laundry.'' Lawyers following the case said Puccio may have succeeded in undermining Boesky's credibility, but that did not mean Mulheren was any closer to acquittal. He faces 41 counts of securities fraud, mail fraud and other crimes. ``Ultimately the question for the jury is not Ivan Boesky alone. It's going to be government witnesses in the aggregate,'' said John C. Coffee Jr., a Columbia Law School professor. ``I'd be very surprised if the government rested its factual allegations on just Boesky's say-so.'' Stanley Arkin, a well-known defense attorney who has represented several traders implicated in the Wall Street fraud scandal, said federal prosecutors may have made Boesky testify early in the trial so the jury would forget about him after a couple of weeks. ``When the government feels it might have a credibility problem with a witness, they want to put him on first and get it over with,'' Arkin said. ``It's the strategy of letting time and other things heal the inadequacy of the lead witness.'' Others said it was possible jurors would focus on Boesky's performance because it was a dramatic point in an otherwise complicated trial. Some said Boesky's admissions about his life and his image as a squealer who cut a deal to save himself could be quite damaging to the government's case. ``Boesky sounds like he's being as evasive as hell,'' said Michael Feldberg, a New York defense attorney and former federal prosecutor. ``It sounds like he's not being terribly candid, just from the impression he's given. But ultimately the jury's going to decide that.'' In other business and economic news this past week: _More signs emerged of an economy that's sluggish but not near recession. High mortgage rates hurt home April sales in many parts of the country, the National Association of Realtors said. But the Commerce Department said consumer spending, a barometer of economic health, rose moderately last month. _An air fare skirmish flared just as the summer travel season got under way, good for consumers but not for the profitability of the airline industry. Major carriers vowed to match discounts started by United Airlines. _President Bush averted a major crisis with China by extending its most-favored nation trading status, enabling the country to sell goods in the United States at reduced tariffs. U.S. business that depend on China trade welcomed the move, but Congressional critics pledged to fight it, arguing that the Bush should punish the hardline Beijing government for its crackdown on dissent. _The government admitted the cost of the thrift bailout could nearly double to as much as $130 billion, which could force it to borrow enormous amounts of money and consequently put upward pressure on interest rates. By some estimates, the total cost of rescuing the nation's ailing savings & loans could reached $300 billion including interest.
